   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Poland</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Poland_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Poland (disambiguation)">Poland (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Polska" redirects here. For the dance, see <a href="/wiki/Polska_(dance)" title="Polska (dance)">Polska (dance)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Rzeczpospolita Polska" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Rzeczpospolita_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Rzeczpospolita (disambiguation)">Rzeczpospolita (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p>

       Country in Europe
      </div>

       Country in Central Europe
      </div>

            <li>2% <a href="/wiki/Poles#National_minorities" title="Poles">Others or not stated</a></li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row">Religion 
          <div style="font-weight:normal;display:inline;">
            (2019<sup id="cite_ref-2019_Eurobarometer_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2019_Eurobarometer-5">[4]</a></sup>)
          </div></th>
         <td>
          <div class="plainlist">
           <ul>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">90% <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">—86% <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Poland" title="Catholic Church in Poland">Catholicism</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">—4% Other <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">6% <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">No religion</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">1% <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Poland" title="Religion in Poland">Others</a></li>
            <li style="white-space:nowrap;">3% Unanswered</li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>

      <p><b>Poland</b> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">Polska</i> <span class="IPA" style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈpɔlska]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pl-Polska.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/98/Pl-Polska.ogg" class="internal" title="Pl-Polska.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Republic of Poland</b> (Polish: <i lang="pl"><a href="/wiki/Rzeczpospolita" title="Rzeczpospolita">Rzeczpospolita</a> Polska</i><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[c]</a></sup> <span class="IPA" style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ʐɛt͡ʂpɔˈspɔlita&nbsp;ˈpɔlska]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pl-Rzeczpospolita_Polska.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/56/Pl-Rzeczpospolita_Polska.ogg" class="internal" title="Pl-Rzeczpospolita Polska.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), is a country located in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[14]</a></sup> It is divided into 16 <a href="/wiki/Voivodeships_of_Poland" title="Voivodeships of Poland">administrative provinces</a>, covering an area of 312,696 square kilometres (120,733&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), and has a largely <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate seasonal</a> climate.<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> With a population of nearly 38.5&nbsp;million people, Poland is the fifth most populous <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> Poland's capital and largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland" title="List of cities and towns in Poland">metropolis</a> is <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA" title="Łódź">Łódź</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="Poznań">Poznań</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Szczecin" title="Szczecin">Szczecin</a>. </p>
      <p>Poland's topographically diverse territory extends from the beaches along the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Sudetes" title="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in its south. The country is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and Russia's <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad Oblast</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> to the south, and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> to the west.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[15]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">history</a> of human <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_and_protohistory_of_Poland" title="Prehistory and protohistory of Poland">activity on Polish soil</a> spans thousands of years. Throughout the <a href="/wiki/Late_antiquity" title="Late antiquity">late antiquity</a> period it became extensively diverse, with various cultures and tribes settling on the vast <a href="/wiki/North_European_Plain" title="North European Plain">Central European Plain</a>. However, it was the <a href="/wiki/Polans_(western)" title="Polans (western)">Western Polans</a> who dominated the region and gave <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Poland" title="Name of Poland">Poland its name</a>. The establishment of Polish statehood can be traced to 966, when the pagan <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Mieszko I of Poland">ruler</a> of a realm coextensive with the territory of present-day Poland embraced <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and converted to <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Catholicism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-A_Concise_History_of_Poland_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_Concise_History_of_Poland-20">[16]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)">Kingdom of Poland</a> was founded in 1025, and in 1569 it cemented its longstanding <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_union" title="Polish–Lithuanian union">political association</a> with <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Lithuania</a> by signing the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a>. This union formed the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, one of the largest (over 1,000,000 square kilometres – 400,000 square miles) and most populous nations of 16th and 17th century Europe, with a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">uniquely liberal</a> political system which adopted Europe's first modern constitution, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_3_May_1791" title="Constitution of 3 May 1791">Constitution of 3 May 1791</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With the passing of <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">prominence and prosperity</a>, the country was <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">partitioned by neighbouring states</a> at the end of the 18th century, and regained <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">independence</a> in 1918 with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>. After a series of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1918%E2%80%9339)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Poland (1918–39)">territorial conflicts</a>, the new multi-ethnic Poland restored its position as a key player in European politics. In September 1939, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> began with the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Germany</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviets</a> invading Poland in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>. Approximately six million Polish citizens, including three million of the <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Poland" title="The Holocaust in Poland">country's Jews</a>, perished during the course of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-szma_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-szma-25">[21]</a></sup> As a member of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Polish People's Republic</a> proclaimed forthwith was a chief signatory of the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Treaty</a> amidst global <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> tensions. In the wake of the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">1989 events</a>, notably through the emergence and contributions of the <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party" title="Polish United Workers' Party">communist government</a> was <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_communism_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Fall of communism in Poland">dissolved</a> and Poland re-established itself as a semi-presidential <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> republic. </p>
      <p>Poland is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_market" title="Developed market">developed market</a><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> and a regional power in Central Europe;<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup> it has the sixth largest economy in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">nominal GDP</a> and the fifth largest by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">GDP (PPP)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup> It provides very high standards of <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">living</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">safety</a><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_freedom" title="Economic freedom">economic freedom</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> as well as free <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland" title="Education in Poland">university education</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Healthcare in Poland">universal health care</a> system in accordance with EU standards.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[30]</a></sup> The country has 16 <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Heritage Sites of Poland">World Heritage Sites</a>, 15 of which are cultural.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[31]</a></sup> Poland is a member state of the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_Seas_Initiative" title="Three Seas Initiative">Three Seas Initiative</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">Visegrád Group</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Poland" title="Name of Poland">Name of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The origin of the name "Poland" derives from the <a href="/wiki/West_Slavs" title="West Slavs">West Slavic</a> tribe of <a href="/wiki/Polans_(western)" title="Polans (western)">Polans</a> (<i>Polanie</i>), who inhabited the <a href="/wiki/Warta" title="Warta">Warta</a> river basin of the present-day <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland" title="Greater Poland">Greater Poland</a> region starting in the mid-6th century. <sup id="cite_ref-:0_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[32]</a></sup> The origin of the name <i>Polanie</i> itself derives from the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Slavic">Proto-Slavic</a> word <i>pole</i> (field).<sup id="cite_ref-:0_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[32]</a></sup> In some languages, such as Hungarian, Lithuanian, Persian, Russian and Turkish, the country's <a href="/wiki/Exonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Exonym">name</a> is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Lendians" title="Lendians">Lendians</a> (<i>Lędzianie</i> or <i>Lachy</i>) who dwelled on the southeasternmost edge of present-day <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Poland" title="Lesser Poland">Lesser Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[32]</a></sup> Their name likewise derives from the <a href="/wiki/Old_Polish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Polish language">Old Polish</a> word <i>lęda</i> (open land or plain).<sup id="cite_ref-:0_36-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[32]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">History of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_protohistory">Prehistory and protohistory</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bronze-_and_Iron-Age_Poland" title="Bronze- and Iron-Age Poland">Bronze- and Iron-Age Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_Antiquity" class="mw-redirect" title="Poland in Antiquity">Poland in Antiquity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Early Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Slavs" title="West Slavs">West Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lechites" title="Lechites">Lechites</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_the_Early_Middle_Ages" title="Poland in the Early Middle Ages">Poland in the Early Middle Ages</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg/220px-Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg/330px-Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg/440px-Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Biskupin_brama_od_zewnatrz.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Reconstruction of a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lusatian_culture" title="Lusatian culture">Lusatian culture</a> settlement in <a href="/wiki/Biskupin" title="Biskupin">Biskupin</a>, c. 700 BC
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The early <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> in Poland began around 2400 BC, while the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> commenced in approximately 750 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup> During this time, the <a href="/wiki/Lusatian_culture" title="Lusatian culture">Lusatian culture</a>, spanning both the Bronze and Iron Ages, became particularly prominent. The most famous archaeological find from <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_and_protohistory_of_Poland" title="Prehistory and protohistory of Poland">the prehistory and protohistory of Poland</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Biskupin" title="Biskupin">Biskupin</a> fortified settlement (now reconstructed as an open-air museum), dating from the Lusatian culture of the late Bronze Age, around 748 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Throughout the <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">Antiquity</a> period, many distinct ancient ethnic groups populated the regions of what is now Poland in an era that dates from about 400 BC to 500 AD. These groups are identified as <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarmatians" title="Sarmatians">Sarmatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Slavic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic</a> tribes. Also, recent archeological findings in the <a href="/wiki/Kuyavia" title="Kuyavia">Kuyavia</a> region confirmed the presence of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Legions" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Legions">Roman Legions</a> on the territory of Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup> These were most likely expeditionary missions sent out to protect the <a href="/wiki/Amber" title="Amber">amber</a> trade. The exact time and routes of the original migration and settlement of <a href="/wiki/Slavic_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic peoples">Slavic peoples</a> lacks written records and can only be defined as fragmented.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup> The Slavic tribes who settled the territory of modern Poland migrated to the region in the 6th century AD. Up until the creation of <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Mieszko I of Poland">Mieszko's</a> state and his subsequent conversion to Christianity in 966 AD, the main religion of the numerous <a href="/wiki/West_Slavs" title="West Slavs">West Slavic</a> (Lechitic) tribes that inhabited the geographical area of present-day Poland was <a href="/wiki/Slavic_paganism" title="Slavic paganism">paganism</a>. With the <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a> the Polish rulers accepted <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a> and the religious authority of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Church</a>. However, the transition from paganism was not a smooth and instantaneous process for the rest of the population as evident from the <a href="/wiki/Pagan_reaction_in_Poland" title="Pagan reaction in Poland">pagan reaction of the 1030s</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Piast_dynasty">Piast dynasty</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_during_the_Piast_dynasty" title="History of Poland during the Piast dynasty">History of Poland during the Piast dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Poland" title="Christianization of Poland">Christianization of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Civitas_Schinesghe" title="Civitas Schinesghe">Civitas Schinesghe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gesta_principum_Polonorum" title="Gesta principum Polonorum">Gesta principum Polonorum</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)">Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Poland960.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/220px-Poland960.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/330px-Poland960.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Poland960.png/440px-Poland960.png 2x" data-file-width="520" data-file-height="513"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Poland960.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Poland under the rule of Duke <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I" title="Mieszko I">Mieszko I</a>, whose acceptance of <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a> marks the beginning of Polish statehood in 966
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland began to form into a recognizable unitary and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_entity" title="Territorial entity">territorial entity</a> around the middle of the 10th century under the <a href="/wiki/Piast_dynasty" title="Piast dynasty">Piast dynasty</a>. Poland's first <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">historically documented</a> ruler, <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Mieszko I of Poland">Mieszko I</a>, accepted <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, as the rightful religion of his realm, under the auspices of the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a> in 966. The bulk of <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Poland">the population converted</a> in the course of the next few centuries. In 1000, <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_I_Chrobry" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolesław I Chrobry">Boleslaw the Brave</a>, continuing the policy of his father Mieszko, held a <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Gniezno" title="Congress of Gniezno">Congress of Gniezno</a> and created the <a href="/wiki/Metropolis_(religious_jurisdiction)" title="Metropolis (religious jurisdiction)">metropolis</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gniezno" title="Gniezno">Gniezno</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">dioceses</a> of <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="Kołobrzeg">Kołobrzeg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a>. However, the pagan unrest led to the transfer of the capital to Kraków in 1038 by <a href="/wiki/Casimir_I_the_Restorer" title="Casimir I the Restorer">Casimir I the Restorer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg/170px-Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg/255px-Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg/340px-Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Darstellung_Mieszkos_und_Mathildes_von_Schwaben.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Earliest known contemporary depiction of a Polish monarch, King <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_II_Lambert" title="Mieszko II Lambert">Mieszko II Lambert</a> of Poland, who ruled between 1025 and 1031
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1109, Prince <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_III_Wrymouth" title="Bolesław III Wrymouth">Bolesław III Wrymouth</a> defeated the King of Germany <a href="/wiki/Henry_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Henry V, Holy Roman Emperor">Henry V</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hundsfeld" title="Battle of Hundsfeld">Battle of Hundsfeld</a>, stopping the German incursion into Poland. The clash between Bolesław III and Henry V was documented by <a href="/wiki/Gallus_Anonymus" title="Gallus Anonymus">Gallus Anonymus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gesta_principum_Polonorum" title="Gesta principum Polonorum">his 1118 chronicle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup> In 1138, Poland fragmented into several smaller duchies when Bolesław divided his lands among his sons. In 1226, <a href="/wiki/Konrad_I_of_Masovia" title="Konrad I of Masovia">Konrad I of Masovia</a>, one of the regional <a href="/wiki/Piast" class="mw-redirect" title="Piast">Piast</a> dukes, invited the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">Teutonic Knights</a> to help him fight the <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic</a> <a href="/wiki/Old_Prussians" title="Old Prussians">Prussian</a> pagans; a decision that led to centuries of warfare with the Knights. In 1264, the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Kalisz" title="Statute of Kalisz">Statute of Kalisz</a> or the General Charter of Jewish Liberties introduced numerous right for the Jews in Poland, leading to a nearly autonomous "nation within a nation".<sup id="cite_ref-Dembkowski/Lublin_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dembkowski/Lublin-45">[41]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the middle of the 13th century, the Silesian branch of the Piast dynasty (<a href="/wiki/Henry_I_the_Bearded" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry I the Bearded">Henry I the Bearded</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_II_the_Pious" title="Henry II the Pious">Henry II the Pious</a>, ruled 1238–1241) nearly succeeded in uniting the Polish lands, but the <a href="/wiki/First_Mongol_invasion_of_Poland" title="First Mongol invasion of Poland">Mongols</a> invaded the country from the east and defeated the combined Polish forces at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Legnica" title="Battle of Legnica">Battle of Legnica</a> where Duke Henry II the Pious died. In 1320, after a number of earlier unsuccessful attempts by regional rulers at uniting the Polish dukedoms, <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_I_the_Elbow-high" class="mw-redirect" title="Władysław I the Elbow-high">Władysław I</a> consolidated his power, took the throne and became the first king of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)">a reunified Poland</a>. His son, <a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III</a> (reigned 1333–1370), has a reputation as one of the greatest Polish kings, and gained wide recognition for improving the country's infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-Sokol1992-60_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sokol1992-60-46">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> He also extended royal protection to <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a>, and encouraged their immigration to Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-Sokol1992-60_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sokol1992-60-46">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> Casimir III realized that the nation needed a class of educated people, especially lawyers, who could codify the country's laws and administer the courts and offices. His efforts to create an institution of higher learning in Poland were finally rewarded when <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_V" title="Pope Urban V">Pope Urban V</a> granted him permission to open the <a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">University of Kraków</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/170px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="265" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/255px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG/340px-Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG 2x" data-file-width="470" data-file-height="734"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Casimir_the_Great_by_Leopold_L%C3%B6ffler.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III the Great</a> is the only Polish king to receive the title of <i>Great</i>. He built extensively during his reign, and reformed the Polish army along with the country's legal code, 1333–70.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">Golden Liberty</a> of the nobles began to develop under Casimir's rule, when in return for their <a href="/wiki/Pospolite_ruszenie" title="Pospolite ruszenie">military support</a>, the king made a series of concessions to the nobility and establishing their legal status as superior to that of the townsfolk. When Casimir the Great died in 1370, leaving no legitimate male heir, the <a href="/wiki/Piast_dynasty" title="Piast dynasty">Piast dynasty</a> came to an end. </p>
      <p>During the 13th and 14th centuries, Poland became a destination for German, Flemish and to a lesser extent Walloon, Danish and Scottish migrants. Also, Jews and Armenians began to settle and flourish in Poland during this era (see <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Jews in Poland">History of the Jews in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Poland" title="Armenians in Poland">Armenians in Poland</a>). </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a>, a plague that ravaged Europe from 1347 to 1351, did not significantly affect Poland, and the country was spared from a major outbreak of the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-REF03_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REF03-49">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> The reason for this was the decision of Casimir the Great to quarantine the nation's borders. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jagiellon_dynasty">Jagiellon dynasty</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_during_the_Jagiellon_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty">History of Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1385%E2%80%931569)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)">Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg/170px-Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg/255px-Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bb/Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg 2x" data-file-width="307" data-file-height="312"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Tannenberg.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a> was fought against the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">German Order of Teutonic Knights</a>, and resulted in a decisive victory for the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1385%E2%80%931569)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)">Kingdom of Poland</a>, 15 July 1410.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Jagiellon_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Jagiellon dynasty">Jagiellon dynasty</a> spanned the late <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Modern_history" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern history">Modern Era</a> of Polish history. Beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duke_of_Lithuania" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Duke of Lithuania">Lithuanian Grand Duke</a> <a href="/wiki/Jogaila" class="mw-redirect" title="Jogaila">Jogaila</a> (Władysław II Jagiełło), the Jagiellon dynasty (1386–1572) formed the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_union" title="Polish–Lithuanian union">Polish–Lithuanian union</a>. The partnership brought vast <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Lithuanian</a>-controlled <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_(people)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus' (people)">Rus' areas</a> into Poland's sphere of influence and proved beneficial for the Poles and Lithuanians, who coexisted and cooperated in one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">political entities</a> in Europe for the next four centuries. </p>
      <p>In the Baltic Sea region the struggle of Poland and Lithuania with the <a href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" class="mw-redirect" title="Teutonic Knights">Teutonic Knights</a> continued and culminated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald</a> in 1410, where a combined Polish-Lithuanian army inflicted a decisive victory against them.<sup id="cite_ref-Wyrozumski_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wyrozumski-51">[47]</a></sup> In 1466, after the <a href="/wiki/Thirteen_Years%27_War_(1454%E2%80%9366)" class="mw-redirect" title="Thirteen Years' War (1454–66)">Thirteen Years' War</a>, King <a href="/wiki/Casimir_IV_Jagiellon" title="Casimir IV Jagiellon">Casimir IV Jagiellon</a> gave royal consent to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Peace_of_Thorn_(1466)" title="Second Peace of Thorn (1466)">Peace of Thorn</a>, which created the future <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Prussia" title="Duchy of Prussia">Duchy of Prussia</a> under Polish suzerainty. The Jagiellon dynasty at one point also established dynastic control over the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bohemia" title="Kingdom of Bohemia">Bohemia</a> (1471 onwards) and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Hungary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Europe:_a_history_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europe:_a_history-52">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-britannica_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-53">[49]</a></sup> In the south, Poland confronted the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Tatars</a> (by whom they were attacked on 75 separate occasions between 1474 and 1569),<sup id="cite_ref-google_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google-54">[50]</a></sup> and in the east helped Lithuania fight the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a>. Some historians estimate that Crimean Tatar slave-raiding cost Poland-Lithuania one million of its population between the years of 1494 and 1694.<sup id="cite_ref-hit-u_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hit-u-55">[51]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Wawel_(crop).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg/290px-Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg/435px-Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg/580px-Wawel_%28crop%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="954" data-file-height="475"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Wawel_(crop).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Wawel_Castle" title="Wawel Castle">Wawel Castle</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>, seat of Polish kings from 1038 until the capital was moved to <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> in 1596. The royal residence is an example of <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a> architecture in Poland.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland was developing as a <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> state, with a predominantly agricultural economy and an increasingly powerful <a href="/wiki/Landed_nobility" title="Landed nobility">landed nobility</a>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Nihil_novi" title="Nihil novi">Nihil novi</a></i> act adopted by the Polish <a href="/wiki/General_sejm" class="mw-redirect" title="General sejm">Sejm</a> (parliament) in 1505, transferred most of the <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative power</a> from the monarch to the Sejm, an event which marked the beginning of the period known as "Golden Liberty", when the state was ruled by the "free and equal" <a href="/wiki/Szlachta" title="Szlachta">Polish nobility</a>. <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> movements made deep inroads into Polish Christianity, which resulted in the establishment of policies promoting religious tolerance, unique in Europe at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-LouthanCohen2011_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LouthanCohen2011-56">[52]</a></sup> This tolerance allowed the country to avoid most of the religious turmoil that spread over Europe during the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-LouthanCohen2011_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LouthanCohen2011-56">[52]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The European <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> evoked in late Jagiellon Poland (under kings <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_I_the_Old" title="Sigismund I the Old">Sigismund I the Old</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_II_Augustus" title="Sigismund II Augustus">Sigismund II Augustus</a>) a sense of urgency in the need to promote a <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">cultural awakening</a>, and during this period Polish culture and the nation's economy flourished. In 1543, <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>, an astronomer from <a href="/wiki/Toru%C5%84" title="Toruń">Toruń</a>, published his epochal work <i><a href="/wiki/De_revolutionibus_orbium_coelestium" title="De revolutionibus orbium coelestium">De revolutionibus orbium coelestium</a></i> (<i>On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres</i>) and thereby became the first proponent of a predictive mathematical model confirming the <a href="/wiki/Copernican_heliocentrism" title="Copernican heliocentrism">heliocentric theory</a>, which became the accepted basic model for the practice of modern astronomy. Another major figure associated with the era is the classicist poet <a href="/wiki/Jan_Kochanowski" title="Jan Kochanowski">Jan Kochanowski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gierowski_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gierowski-57">[53]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Polish.E2.80.93Lithuanian_Commonwealth"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Polish–Lithuanian_Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_in_the_Early_Modern_era_(1569%E2%80%931795)" title="History of Poland in the Early Modern era (1569–1795)">History of Poland in the Early Modern era (1569–1795)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Crown of the Kingdom of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">Sarmatism</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg/220px-Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg/330px-Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg/440px-Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg 2x" data-file-width="11393" data-file-height="7772"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Konfederacja_Warszawska.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Confederation" title="Warsaw Confederation">Warsaw Confederation</a> passed by the Polish national assembly <i>(Sejm Konwokacyjny)</i>, extended religious freedoms and tolerance in the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Commonwealth</a>, and was the first of its kind act in Europe, 28 January 1573.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The 1569 <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, a more closely unified federal state with an <a href="/wiki/Elective_monarchy" title="Elective monarchy">elective monarchy</a>, but which was governed largely by the nobility, through a system of <a href="/wiki/Sejmik" title="Sejmik">local assemblies</a> with a central parliament. The <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Confederation" title="Warsaw Confederation">Warsaw Confederation</a> (1573) guaranteed religious freedom for the Polish nobility <i>(szlachta)</i> and townsfolk <i>(mieszczanie)</i>. However, the <a href="/wiki/Peasant" title="Peasant">peasants</a> <i>(chłopi)</i> were still subject to severe limitations imposed on them by the nobility.<sup id="cite_ref-Dembkowski/Lublin_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dembkowski/Lublin-45">[41]</a></sup> The establishment of the Commonwealth coincided with a period of stability and prosperity in Poland, with the union thereafter becoming a European power and a major cultural entity, occupying approximately one million square kilometers of Central and Eastern Europe, as well as an agent for the dissemination of <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a> through <a href="/wiki/Polonization" title="Polonization">Polonization</a> into areas of modern-day Lithuania, Latvia, Ukraine, Belarus and western Russia. </p>
      <p>In the 16th and 17th centuries, <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Poland</a> suffered from a number of dynastic crises during the reigns of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Vasa" title="House of Vasa">Vasa</a> kings <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa" title="Sigismund III Vasa">Sigismund III</a> and <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_IV_Vasa" title="Władysław IV Vasa">Władysław IV</a> and found itself engaged in major conflicts with <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russia</a>, Sweden and the Ottoman Empire, as well as a series of minor <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> uprisings.<sup id="cite_ref-gierowski_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gierowski-58">[54]</a></sup> In 1610, a Polish army under the command of <a href="/wiki/Hetman" title="Hetman">Hetman</a> <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_%C5%BB%C3%B3%C5%82kiewski" title="Stanisław Żółkiewski">Stanisław Żółkiewski</a> seized <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> after winning the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Klushino" title="Battle of Klushino">Battle of Klushino</a>. In 1611, the Tsar of Russia <a href="/wiki/Shuysky_Tribute" title="Shuysky Tribute">paid homage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Poland">King of Poland</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg/300px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg/450px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg/600px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1411" data-file-height="1106"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_in_1635.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> at its greatest extent after the <a href="/wiki/Truce_of_Deulino" title="Truce of Deulino">Truce of Deulino</a>. During the first half of the 17th century, the Commonwealth covered an area of about 1,000,000 square kilometres (390,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the signing of <a href="/wiki/Truce_of_Deulino" title="Truce of Deulino">Truce of Deulino</a>, Poland had in the years 1618–1621 an area of about 1&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (390,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). </p>
      <p>From the middle of the 17th century, the nobles' democracy, suffering from internal disorder, gradually declined, thereby leaving the once powerful Commonwealth vulnerable to foreign intervention. Starting in 1648, the <a href="/wiki/Cossack" class="mw-redirect" title="Cossack">Cossack</a> <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">Khmelnytsky Uprising</a> engulfed the south and east, eventually leaving Ukraine divided, with the eastern part, lost by the Commonwealth, becoming a dependency of the Tsardom of Russia. This was followed by the <a href="/wiki/Deluge_(history)" title="Deluge (history)">'Deluge'</a>, a Swedish invasion of Poland, which marched through the Polish heartlands and ruined the country's population, culture and infrastructure—around four million of Poland's eleven million inhabitants died in famines and epidemics throughout the 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica1_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica1-59">[55]</a></sup> However, under <a href="/wiki/John_III_Sobieski" title="John III Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a> the Commonwealth's military prowess was re-established, and in 1683 Polish forces played a major role in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Army_(15th-19th_centuries)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Army (15th-19th centuries)">Ottoman Army</a>, commanded by <a href="/wiki/Kara_Mustafa_Pasha" title="Kara Mustafa Pasha">Kara Mustafa</a>, the Grand Vizier of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jan_III_Schultz.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/170px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/255px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Jan_III_Schultz.jpg/340px-Jan_III_Schultz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="564" data-file-height="758"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jan_III_Schultz.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>King <a href="/wiki/John_III_Sobieski" title="John III Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a> defeated the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Turks</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a> on 12 September 1683.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Sobieski's reign marked the end of the nation's golden era. Finding itself subjected to almost constant warfare and suffering enormous population losses as well as massive damage to its economy, the Commonwealth fell into decline. The government became ineffective as a result of large-scale internal conflicts (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Lubomirski_Rebellion" class="mw-redirect" title="Lubomirski Rebellion">Lubomirski Rebellion</a> against <a href="/wiki/John_II_Casimir_Vasa" title="John II Casimir Vasa">John II Casimir</a> and rebellious <a href="/wiki/Confederation_(Poland)" title="Confederation (Poland)">confederations</a>) and corrupted legislative processes. The nobility fell under the control of a handful of <i><a href="/wiki/Magnat_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magnat (Poland)">magnats</a></i>, and this, compounded with two relatively weak kings of the <a href="/wiki/Electorate_of_Saxony" title="Electorate of Saxony">Saxon</a> <a href="/wiki/House_of_Wettin" title="House of Wettin">Wettin dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Augustus_II_the_Strong" title="Augustus II the Strong">Augustus II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Augustus_III_of_Poland" title="Augustus III of Poland">Augustus III</a>, as well as the rise of <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> only served to worsen the Commonwealth's plight. Despite this The Commonwealth-Saxony personal union gave rise to the emergence of the Commonwealth's first reform movement, and laid the foundations for the <a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_in_Poland" title="Enlightenment in Poland">Polish Enlightenment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gierowski2_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gierowski2-60">[56]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the later part of the 18th century, the Commonwealth made attempts to implement fundamental internal reforms; with the second half of the century bringing a much improved economy, significant population growth and far-reaching progress in the areas of education, intellectual life, art, and especially toward the end of the period, evolution of the social and political system. The most populous capital city of Warsaw replaced <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a> (Danzig) as the leading centre of commerce, and the role of the more prosperous urban population increased. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Partitions">Partitions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1795%E2%80%931918)" title="History of Poland (1795–1918)">History of Poland (1795–1918)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">Partitions of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/170px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="243" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/255px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG/340px-Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1755" data-file-height="2510"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Stanis%C5%82aw_II_August_Poniatowski_in_coronation_clothes.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_Augustus" class="mw-redirect" title="Stanisław II Augustus">Stanisław II Augustus</a>, the last <a href="/wiki/King_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Poland">King of Poland</a>, ascended to the throne in 1764 and reigned until his abdication on 25 November 1795.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_elections_in_Poland" title="Royal elections in Poland">royal election</a> of 1764 resulted in the elevation of <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_August_Poniatowski" title="Stanisław August Poniatowski">Stanisław II August</a> (a Polish aristocrat connected to the <a href="/wiki/Czartoryski_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Czartoryski family">Czartoryski family</a> faction of <a href="/wiki/Magnates" class="mw-redirect" title="Magnates">magnates</a>) to the monarchy. However, as a one-time personal admirer of Empress <a href="/wiki/Catherine_II_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Catherine II of Russia">Catherine II of Russia</a>, the new king spent much of his reign torn between his desire to implement reforms necessary to save his nation, and his perceived necessity to remain in a political relationship with his Russian sponsor. This led to the formation of the 1768 <a href="/wiki/Bar_Confederation" title="Bar Confederation">Bar Confederation</a>, a <i>szlachta</i> rebellion directed against the Polish king and his Russian sponsors, which aimed to preserve Poland's independence and the szlachta's traditional privileges. Attempts at reform provoked the union's neighbours, and in 1772 the <a href="/wiki/First_Partition_of_Poland" title="First Partition of Poland">First Partition of the Commonwealth</a> by Prussia, Russia and Austria took place; an act which the "<a href="/wiki/Partition_Sejm" title="Partition Sejm">Partition Sejm</a>", under considerable duress, eventually "ratified" <i>fait accompli</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-wydawnictwo_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wydawnictwo-61">[57]</a></sup> Disregarding this loss, in 1773 the king established the <a href="/wiki/Commission_of_National_Education" title="Commission of National Education">Commission of National Education</a>, the first government education authority in Europe. Corporal punishment of children was officially prohibited in 1783. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/220px-Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/330px-Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG/440px-Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1538" data-file-height="1083"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Oath_of_confirmation_of_Constitution_of_the_3rd_May_1791.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791"><i>Constitution of 3 May</i></a>, enactment ceremony inside the Senate Chamber at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw" title="Royal Castle, Warsaw">Warsaw Royal Castle</a>, 1791
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Sejm" title="Great Sejm">Great Sejm</a> convened by Stanisław II August in 1788 successfully adopted the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791">3 May Constitution</a>, the first set of modern supreme national laws in Europe. However, this document, accused by detractors of harbouring revolutionary sympathies, generated strong opposition from the Commonwealth's nobles and conservatives as well as from Catherine II, who, determined to prevent the rebirth of a strong Commonwealth set about planning the final dismemberment of the Polish-Lithuanian state. Russia was aided in achieving its goal when the <a href="/wiki/Targowica_Confederation" title="Targowica Confederation">Targowica Confederation</a>, an organisation of Polish nobles, appealed to the Empress for help. In May 1792, Russian forces crossed the Commonwealth's frontier, thus beginning the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Russian_War_of_1792" title="Polish–Russian War of 1792">Polish-Russian War</a>. </p>
      <p>The defensive war fought by the Poles ended prematurely when the King, convinced of the futility of resistance, capitulated and joined the Targowica Confederation. The Confederation then took over the government. Russia and Prussia, fearing the mere existence of a Polish state, arranged for, and in 1793 executed, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Partition_of_Poland" title="Second Partition of Poland">Second Partition of the Commonwealth</a>, which left the country deprived of so much territory that it was practically incapable of independent existence. Eventually, in 1795, following the failed <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_Uprising" title="Kościuszko Uprising">Kościuszko Uprising</a>, the Commonwealth was <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">partitioned one last time</a> by all three of its more powerful neighbours, and with this, effectively ceased to exist.<sup id="cite_ref-gierowski3_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gierowski3-62">[58]</a></sup> The 18-century British statesman and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Burke" title="Edmund Burke">Edmund Burke</a> summed up the partitions: "No wise or honest man can approve of that partition, or can contemplate it without prognosticating great mischief from it to all countries at some future time."<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Era_of_insurrections">Era of insurrections</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Warsaw" title="Duchy of Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Posen" title="Grand Duchy of Posen">Grand Duchy of Posen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia_and_Lodomeria" title="Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria">Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Congress_Poland" title="Congress Poland">Congress Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/280px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="230" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/420px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png/560px-Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png 2x" data-file-width="1906" data-file-height="1568"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rzeczpospolita_Rozbiory_3.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">The partitions of Poland</a>, carried out by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> in <a href="/wiki/First_Partition_of_Poland" title="First Partition of Poland">1772</a>, <a href="/wiki/Second_Partition_of_Poland" title="Second Partition of Poland">1793</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">1795</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poles <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Poland" title="List of wars involving Poland">rebelled several times against the partitioners</a>, particularly near the end of the 18th century and the beginning of the 19th century. An unsuccessful attempt at defending Poland's sovereignty took place in 1794 during the <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_Uprising" title="Kościuszko Uprising">Kościuszko Uprising</a>, where a popular and distinguished general <a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko" title="Tadeusz Kościuszko">Tadeusz Kościuszko</a>, who had several years earlier served under <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">Washington</a> in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, led Polish insurrectionists against numerically superior Russian forces. Despite the victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Rac%C5%82awice" title="Battle of Racławice">Battle of Racławice</a>, his ultimate defeat ended Poland's independent existence <a href="/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland" title="Third Partition of Poland">for 123 years</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_(%C3%96aL).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/170px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/255px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg/340px-Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_%28%C3%96aL%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="1297"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Karl_G_Schweikart_-_Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko_(%C3%96aL).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Ko%C5%9Bciuszko" title="Tadeusz Kościuszko">Tadeusz Kościuszko</a> was a veteran and hero of both the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Russian_War_of_1792" title="Polish–Russian War of 1792">Polish</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American</a> wars of independence between 1765 and 1794.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1807, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleon I of France">Napoleon I of France</a> temporarily recreated a Polish state as the satellite <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Warsaw" title="Duchy of Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a>, after a successful <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland_Uprising_(1806)" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Poland Uprising (1806)">Greater Poland Uprising of 1806</a> against Prussian rule. But, after the failed <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, Poland was again split between the victorious powers at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> of 1815.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> The eastern part was ruled by the Russian <a href="/wiki/Tsar" title="Tsar">tsar</a> as <a href="/wiki/Congress_Poland" title="Congress Poland">Congress Poland</a>, which had a <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Constitution of the Kingdom of Poland">liberal constitution</a>. However, over time the Russian monarch reduced Polish freedoms, and Russia annexed the country in virtually all but name. Meanwhile, the Prussian controlled territory of Poland came under increased Germanization. Thus, in the 19th century, only Austrian-ruled <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a>, and particularly the <a href="/wiki/Free_City_of_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Free City of Kraków">Free City of Kraków</a>, allowed free Polish culture to flourish. </p>
      <p>Throughout the period of the partitions, political and cultural repression of the Polish nation led to the organisation of a number of uprisings against the authorities of the occupying Russian, Prussian and Austrian governments. In 1830, the <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">November Uprising</a> began in Warsaw when, led by Lieutenant <a href="/wiki/Piotr_Wysocki" title="Piotr Wysocki">Piotr Wysocki</a>, young <a href="/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer" title="Non-commissioned officer">non-commissioned officers</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Corps_of_Cadets_(Warsaw)" title="Corps of Cadets (Warsaw)">Officer Cadet School</a> in Warsaw revolted. They were joined by large segments of Polish society, and together forced Warsaw's Russian garrison to withdraw north of the city. </p>
      <p>Over the course of the next seven months, Polish forces successfully defeated the Russian armies of Field Marshal <a href="/wiki/Hans_Karl_von_Diebitsch" title="Hans Karl von Diebitsch">Hans Karl von Diebitsch</a> and a number of other Russian commanders; however, finding themselves in a position unsupported by any other foreign powers, save distant France and the newborn United States, and with Prussia and Austria refusing to allow the import of military supplies through their territories, the Poles accepted that the uprising was doomed to failure. Upon the surrender of Warsaw to General <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Paskievich" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Paskievich">Ivan Paskievich</a>, many Polish troops, feeling they could not go on, withdrew into Prussia and there laid down their arms. After the defeat, the semi-independent Congress Poland lost its constitution, army and legislative assembly, and was integrated more closely with the Russian Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg/220px-MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg/330px-MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg/440px-MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1860" data-file-height="1240"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MWP_1830_Arsenal.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Capture of the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Arsenal" title="Warsaw Arsenal">Warsaw Arsenal</a> by the Polish Army during the <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">November Uprising</a> against <a href="/wiki/Tsarist_autocracy" title="Tsarist autocracy">Tsarist autocracy</a>, 29 November 1830
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Spring_of_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Spring of Nations">Spring of Nations</a> (a series of revolutions which swept across Europe), Poles took up arms in the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland_Uprising_(1848)" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Poland Uprising (1848)">Greater Poland Uprising of 1848</a> to resist Prussian rule. Initially, the uprising manifested itself in the form of civil disobedience but eventually turned into an armed struggle when the Prussian military was sent in to pacify the region. Eventually, after several battles the uprising was suppressed by the Prussians, and the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Posen" title="Grand Duchy of Posen">Grand Duchy of Posen</a> was more completely incorporated into Prussia.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1863, a new Polish uprising against Russian rule began. The <a href="/wiki/January_Uprising" title="January Uprising">January Uprising</a> started out as a spontaneous protest by young Poles against <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> into the Imperial Russian Army. However, the insurrectionists, despite being joined by high-ranking Polish-Lithuanian officers and numerous politicians, were still severely outnumbered and lacking in foreign support. They were forced to resort to guerrilla warfare tactics and failed to win any major military victories. Afterwards no major uprising was witnessed in the Russian-controlled Congress Poland, and Poles resorted instead to fostering economic and cultural self-improvement. Congress Poland was rapidly industrialised towards the end of the 19th century, and successively transformed into the Empire's wealthiest and most developed subject.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite the political unrest experienced during the partitions, Poland did benefit from large-scale industrialisation and modernisation programs, instituted by the occupying powers, which helped it develop into a more economically coherent and viable entity. This was particularly true in Greater Poland, Silesia and Eastern Pomerania controlled by Prussia (later becoming a part of the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a>); areas which eventually, thanks largely to the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland_Uprising_(1918%E2%80%931919)" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Poland Uprising (1918–1919)">Greater Poland Uprising of 1918</a> and <a href="/wiki/Silesian_Uprisings" title="Silesian Uprisings">Silesian Uprisings</a>, were reconstituted as a part of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>, becoming the country's most prosperous regions.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Polish_Republic">Second Polish Republic</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1918%E2%80%9339)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Poland (1918–39)">History of Poland (1918–39)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1916%E2%80%9318)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Poland (1916–18)">Kingdom of Poland (1916–18)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">Battle of Warsaw (1920)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_(-1930).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/170px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="234" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/255px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg/340px-J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_%28-1930%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1649"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski_(-1930).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Naczelnik_pa%C5%84stwa" class="mw-redirect" title="Naczelnik państwa">Chief of State</a> Marshal <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="Józef Piłsudski">Józef Piłsudski</a> was a hero of the Polish independence campaign and the nation's premiere statesman between 1918 until his death on 12 May 1935.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, all the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> agreed on the reconstitution of Poland that United States President <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a> proclaimed in Point 13 of his <a href="/wiki/Fourteen_Points" title="Fourteen Points">Fourteen Points</a>. A total of 2 million Polish troops fought with the armies of the three occupying powers, and 450,000 died. Shortly after the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany_(Compi%C3%A8gne)" class="mw-redirect" title="Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)">armistice with Germany in November 1918</a>, Poland regained its independence as the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a> (<i>II Rzeczpospolita Polska</i>). It reaffirmed its independence after <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Poland" title="List of wars involving Poland">a series of military conflicts</a>, the most notable being the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="Polish–Soviet War">Polish–Soviet War</a> (1919–21) when Poland inflicted a crushing defeat on the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">Battle of Warsaw</a>, an event which is considered to have halted the advance of Communism into Europe and forced <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a> to rethink his objective of achieving global socialism. The event is often referred to as the "Miracle at the Vistula".<sup id="cite_ref-Głos_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Głos-72">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During this period, Poland successfully managed to fuse the territories of the three former partitioning powers into a cohesive nation state.
