Railways were restructured to direct traffic towards <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> instead of the former imperial capitals, a new network of national roads was gradually built up and a <a href="/wiki/Gdynia" title="Gdynia">major seaport</a> was opened on the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic</a> Coast, so as to allow Polish exports and imports to bypass the politically charged <a href="/wiki/Free_City_of_Danzig" title="Free City of Danzig">Free City of Danzig</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:RzeczpospolitaII.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/RzeczpospolitaII.png/220px-RzeczpospolitaII.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/RzeczpospolitaII.png/330px-RzeczpospolitaII.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/RzeczpospolitaII.png/440px-RzeczpospolitaII.png 2x" data-file-width="1112" data-file-height="1069"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RzeczpospolitaII.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Poland during the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">Interwar period</a>, 1921–39
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The inter-war period heralded in a new era of Polish politics. Whilst Polish political activists had faced heavy censorship in the decades up until the First World War, the country now found itself trying to establish a new political tradition. For this reason, many exiled Polish activists, such as <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski" title="Ignacy Jan Paderewski">Ignacy Paderewski</a> (who would later become prime minister) returned home to help; a significant number of them then went on to take key positions in the newly formed political and governmental structures. Tragedy struck in 1922 when <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Narutowicz" title="Gabriel Narutowicz">Gabriel Narutowicz</a>, inaugural holder of the presidency, was assassinated at the <a href="/wiki/Zach%C4%99ta" title="Zachęta">Zachęta</a> Gallery in Warsaw by a painter and right-wing nationalist <a href="/wiki/Eligiusz_Niewiadomski" title="Eligiusz Niewiadomski">Eligiusz Niewiadomski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bitter_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bitter-73">[69]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1926, a <a href="/wiki/May_Coup_(Poland)" title="May Coup (Poland)">May coup</a>, led by the hero of the Polish independence campaign Marshal <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="Józef Piłsudski">Józef Piłsudski</a>, turned rule of the Second Polish Republic over to the nonpartisan <a href="/wiki/Sanacja" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanacja">Sanacja</a> (<i>Healing</i>) movement in an effort to prevent radical political organizations on both the left and the right from destabilizing the country.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[d]</a></sup> The movement functioned with relative stability until Piłsudski's death in 1935. Following Marshall Piłsudski's death, Sanation split into several competing factions.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> By the late 1930s, due to increased threats posed by political extremism inside the country, the Polish government became increasingly heavy-handed, banning a number of radical organizations, including communist and ultra-nationalist political parties, which threatened the stability of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[74]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As a subsequent result of the <a href="/wiki/Munich_Agreement" title="Munich Agreement">Munich Agreement</a> in 1938, Czechoslovakia ceded to Poland the small 350 sq mi <a href="/wiki/Zaolzie" title="Zaolzie">Zaolzie</a> region. The area was a point of contention between the Polish and Czechoslovak governments in the past and the two countries <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Czechoslovak_War" title="Polish–Czechoslovak War">fought a brief seven-day war over it in 1919</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%9345)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Poland (1939–45)">History of Poland (1939–45)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_contribution_to_World_War_II" title="Polish contribution to World War II">Polish contribution to World War II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/War_crimes_in_occupied_Poland_during_World_War_II" title="War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II">War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:7TP_Polish_Tank.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/220px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/330px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/7TP_Polish_Tank.png/440px-7TP_Polish_Tank.png 2x" data-file-width="704" data-file-height="497"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:7TP_Polish_Tank.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_(Second_Polish_Republic)" title="Polish Armed Forces (Second Polish Republic)">Polish army's</a> <a href="/wiki/7TP" title="7TP">7TP</a> tanks on military manoeuvres shortly before the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a> in 1939.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> began with the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_German" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi German">Nazi German</a> <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> on 1 September 1939, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">Soviet invasion of Poland</a> on 17 September. On 28 September 1939, <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Warsaw_(1939)" title="Siege of Warsaw (1939)">Warsaw fell</a>. As agreed in the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>, Poland was split into two zones, <a href="/wiki/Polish_areas_annexed_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany">one occupied by Nazi Germany</a>, the other by <a href="/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union" title="Territories of Poland annexed by the Soviet Union">the Soviet Union</a>. In 1939–41, the Soviets deported hundreds of thousands of Poles. The Soviet <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">NKVD</a> executed thousands of Polish prisoners of war (inter alia <a href="/wiki/Katyn_massacre" title="Katyn massacre">Katyn massacre</a>) ahead of the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-81">[76]</a></sup> German planners had in November 1939 called for "the complete destruction of all Poles" and their fate as outlined in the genocidal <i><a href="/wiki/Generalplan_Ost" title="Generalplan Ost">Generalplan Ost</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[77]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Polish intelligence operatives proved extremely valuable to the Allies, providing much of the intelligence from Europe and beyond,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[78]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_Cipher_Bureau" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Cipher Bureau">Polish code breakers</a> were responsible for <a href="/wiki/Cryptanalysis_of_the_Enigma" title="Cryptanalysis of the Enigma">cracking the Enigma cypher</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[e]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland made the fourth-largest troop contribution in Europe<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[f]</a></sup> and its troops served both the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Government_in_Exile" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Government in Exile">Polish Government in Exile</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West" title="Polish Armed Forces in the West">west</a> and Soviet leadership in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_East" title="Polish Armed Forces in the East">east</a>. Polish troops played an important role in the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Normandy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">Italian</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_African_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="North African Campaign">North African Campaigns</a> and are particularly remembered for the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino" title="Battle of Monte Cassino">Battle of Monte Cassino</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tobruk_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tobruk-90">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-including_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-including-91">[84]</a></sup> In the east, the Soviet-backed <a href="/wiki/First_Polish_Army_(1944%E2%80%931945)" title="First Polish Army (1944–1945)">Polish 1st Army</a> distinguished itself in the battles for <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising" title="Warsaw Uprising">Warsaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">Berlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lerski1996-2_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski1996-2-92">[85]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pilots_of_No._303_(Polish)_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes,_October_1940._CH1535.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/220px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/330px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg/440px-Pilots_of_No._303_%28Polish%29_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes%2C_October_1940._CH1535.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1278" data-file-height="956"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pilots_of_No._303_(Polish)_Squadron_RAF_with_one_of_their_Hawker_Hurricanes,_October_1940._CH1535.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/No._303_Polish_Fighter_Squadron" class="mw-redirect" title="No. 303 Polish Fighter Squadron">303 Polish Fighter Squadron</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a>, October 1940
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Polish_resistance_movement_in_World_War_II" title="Polish resistance movement in World War II">wartime resistance movement</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Armia_Krajowa" class="mw-redirect" title="Armia Krajowa">Armia Krajowa</a> (<i>Home Army</i>), fought against German occupation. It was one of the three largest resistance movements of the entire war,<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[g]</a></sup> and encompassed a range of clandestine activities, which functioned as an <a href="/wiki/Polish_Underground_State" title="Polish Underground State">underground state</a> complete with <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland_during_World_War_II" title="Education in Poland during World War II">degree-awarding universities</a> and <a href="/wiki/Special_Courts" title="Special Courts">a court system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Salm42_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salm42-100">[92]</a></sup> The resistance was loyal to the exiled government and generally resented the idea of a communist Poland; for this reason, in the summer of 1944 it initiated <a href="/wiki/Operation_Tempest" title="Operation Tempest">Operation Tempest</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising" title="Warsaw Uprising">Warsaw Uprising</a> that begun on 1 August 1944 is the best known operation.<sup id="cite_ref-Lerski1996-2_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski1996-2-92">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Soviets_and_AK_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soviets_and_AK-101">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nazi German forces under orders from <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> set up six German <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camp" title="Extermination camp">extermination camps</a> in occupied Poland, including <a href="/wiki/Treblinka_extermination_camp" title="Treblinka extermination camp">Treblinka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Majdanek_concentration_camp" title="Majdanek concentration camp">Majdanek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">Auschwitz</a>. The Germans <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_train" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust train">transported millions of Jews</a> from across occupied Europe to be murdered in those camps.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[95]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/220px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG" decoding="async" width="220" height="237" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/330px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG/440px-WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG 2x" data-file-width="2007" data-file-height="2161"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:WW2-Holocaust-Poland.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_occupied_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="The Holocaust in occupied Poland">the Holocaust in German occupied Poland</a> with deportation routes and massacre sites. Major <a href="/wiki/Jewish_ghettos_in_German-occupied_Poland" title="Jewish ghettos in German-occupied Poland">ghettos</a> are marked with yellow stars. Nazi <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camps" class="mw-redirect" title="Extermination camps">extermination camps</a> are marked with white skulls in black squares. The border in 1941 between <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> is marked in red.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Altogether, 3 million Polish Jews<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[97]</a></sup> – approximately 90% of Poland's pre-war Jewry – and between 1.8 and 2.8 million ethnic Poles<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[100]</a></sup> were killed during the German <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)">occupation of Poland</a>, including between 50,000 and 100,000 members of the Polish <a href="/wiki/Intelligentsia" title="Intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> – academics, doctors, lawyers, nobility and priesthood. During the Warsaw Uprising alone, over 150,000 Polish civilians were killed, most were murdered by the Germans during the <a href="/wiki/Wola_massacre" title="Wola massacre">Wola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ochota_massacre" title="Ochota massacre">Ochota</a> massacres.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[102]</a></sup> Around 150,000 Polish civilians were killed by Soviets between 1939 and 1941 during the Soviet Union's occupation of eastern Poland (<a href="/wiki/Kresy" title="Kresy">Kresy</a>), and another estimated 100,000 Poles were murdered by the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Insurgent_Army" title="Ukrainian Insurgent Army">Ukrainian Insurgent Army</a> (UPA) between 1943 and 1944 in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Massacres_of_Poles_in_Volhynia_and_Eastern_Galicia" title="Massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia">Wołyń Massacres</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[104]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">Of all the countries</a> in the war, Poland lost the highest percentage of its citizens: around 6 million perished – more than one-sixth of Poland's pre-war population – <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust in Poland">half of them</a> Polish Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-szma_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-szma-25">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[106]</a></sup> About 90% of deaths were non-military in nature.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[107]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1945, Poland's borders <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_Poland_immediately_after_World_War_II" title="Territorial changes of Poland immediately after World War II">were shifted westwards</a>. Over two million Polish inhabitants of <a href="/wiki/Kresy" title="Kresy">Kresy</a> <a href="/wiki/Polish_population_transfers_(1944%E2%80%9346)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish population transfers (1944–46)">were expelled</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Curzon_Line" title="Curzon Line">Curzon Line</a> by Stalin.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[108]</a></sup> The western border became the <a href="/wiki/Oder-Neisse_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Oder-Neisse line">Oder-Neisse line</a>. As a result, Poland's territory was reduced by 20%, or 77,500 square kilometres (29,900&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). The shift forced the migration of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_evacuation_and_expulsion" title="World War II evacuation and expulsion">millions of other people</a>, most of whom were Poles, Germans, Ukrainians, and Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc5_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc5-119">[111]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-war_communism">Post-war communism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1945%E2%80%931989)" title="History of Poland (1945–1989)">History of Poland (1945–1989)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Solidarity" title="History of Solidarity">History of Solidarity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish_Round_Table_Agreement" title="Polish Round Table Agreement">Polish Round Table Agreement</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg/170px-Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg/255px-Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/9e/Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg 2x" data-file-width="259" data-file-height="385"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solidarity_poster_1989.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>At <a href="/wiki/High_Noon" title="High Noon">High Noon</a>, 4 June 1989</i> — political poster featuring <a href="/wiki/Gary_Cooper" title="Gary Cooper">Gary Cooper</a> to encourage votes for the <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a> party in the <a href="/wiki/Contract_Sejm" title="Contract Sejm">1989 elections</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the insistence of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> sanctioned the formation of a new provisional pro-Communist coalition government in Moscow, which ignored the <a href="/wiki/Polish_government-in-exile" title="Polish government-in-exile">Polish government-in-exile</a> based in London. This action angered many Poles who considered it a <a href="/wiki/Yalta_betrayal" class="mw-redirect" title="Yalta betrayal">betrayal</a> by the Allies. In 1944, Stalin had made guarantees to <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Churchill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a> that he would maintain Poland's sovereignty and allow democratic elections to take place. However, upon achieving victory in 1945, the elections organized by the occupying Soviet authorities were falsified and were used to provide a veneer of legitimacy for Soviet hegemony over Polish affairs. The Soviet Union instituted a new <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist</a> government in Poland, analogous to much of the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>. <a href="/wiki/Anti-Communism_in_the_Communist_Bloc" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-Communism in the Communist Bloc">As elsewhere in Communist Europe</a>, the Soviet influence over Poland was met with <a href="/wiki/Cursed_soldiers" title="Cursed soldiers">armed resistance</a> from the outset which continued into the 1950s. </p>
      <p>Despite widespread objections, the new Polish government accepted the Soviet annexation of the pre-war eastern regions of Poland<sup id="cite_ref-indianapolis_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indianapolis-120">[112]</a></sup> (in particular the cities of <a href="/wiki/Wilno" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilno">Wilno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lw%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Lwów">Lwów</a>) and agreed to the permanent garrisoning of <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> units on Poland's territory. Military alignment within the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> throughout the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> came about as a direct result of this change in Poland's political culture. In the European scene, it came to characterize the full-fledged integration of Poland into the brotherhood of communist nations. </p>
      <p>The new communist government took control with the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Small_Constitution_of_1947" title="Small Constitution of 1947">Small Constitution</a> on 19 February 1947. The <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Polish People's Republic</a> (<i>Polska Rzeczpospolita Ludowa</i>) <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland">was officially proclaimed in 1952</a>. In 1956, after the death of <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_Bierut" title="Bolesław Bierut">Bolesław Bierut</a>, the régime of <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Gomu%C5%82ka" title="Władysław Gomułka">Władysław Gomułka</a> became temporarily more liberal, freeing many people from prison and expanding some personal freedoms. <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Collectivization in the Polish People's Republic">Collectivization in the Polish People's Republic</a> failed. A similar situation repeated itself in the 1970s under <a href="/wiki/Edward_Gierek" title="Edward Gierek">Edward Gierek</a>, but most of the time persecution of <a href="/wiki/Anti-communist_resistance_in_Poland" title="Anti-communist resistance in Poland">anti-communist opposition</a> groups persisted. Despite this, Poland was at the time considered to be one of the least oppressive states of the Eastern Bloc.<sup id="cite_ref-PWN_historia_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PWN_historia-121">[113]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Labour turmoil in 1980 led to the formation of the independent trade union "<a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a>" ("<i>Solidarność</i>"), which over time became a political force. Despite persecution and imposition of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Poland" title="Martial law in Poland">martial law in 1981</a>, it eroded the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party" title="Polish United Workers' Party">Polish United Workers' Party</a> and by 1989 had triumphed in Poland's first <a href="/wiki/Contract_Sejm" title="Contract Sejm">partially free and democratic parliamentary elections</a> since the end of the Second World War. <a href="/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa" title="Lech Wałęsa">Lech Wałęsa</a>, a Solidarity candidate, eventually <a href="/wiki/1990_Polish_presidential_election" title="1990 Polish presidential election">won the presidency in 1990</a>. The Solidarity movement heralded the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">collapse of communist regimes and parties across Europe</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1990s_to_present">1990s to present</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1989%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Poland (1989–present)">History of Poland (1989–present)</a> and <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">2004 enlargement of the European Union</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_PL_flags.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/EU_and_PL_flags.jpg/200px-EU_and_PL_flags.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/EU_and_PL_flags.jpg/300px-EU_and_PL_flags.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/EU_and_PL_flags.jpg/400px-EU_and_PL_flags.jpg 2x" data-file-width="460" data-file-height="340"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_PL_flags.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Poland became a member state of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> on 1 May 2004.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">shock therapy</a> programme, initiated by <a href="/wiki/Leszek_Balcerowicz" title="Leszek Balcerowicz">Leszek Balcerowicz</a> in the early 1990s, enabled the country to transform its socialist-style planned economy into a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>. As with other post-communist countries, Poland suffered declines in social and economic standards,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[114]</a></sup> but it became the first post-communist country to reach its pre-1989 GDP levels, which it achieved by 1995 thanks largely to its booming economy.<sup id="cite_ref-WHY_POLAND?_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHY_POLAND?-123">[115]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most visibly, there were numerous improvements in human rights, such as <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Internet censorship by country">internet freedom</a> (no censorship), civil liberties (1st class) and political rights (1st class), as ranked by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> non-governmental organization. In 1991, Poland became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">Visegrád Group</a> and joined the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> (NATO) alliance in 1999 along with the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>. Poles then voted to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in <a href="/wiki/Referendums_in_Poland" title="Referendums in Poland">a referendum</a> in June 2003, with <a href="/wiki/Poland_in_the_European_Union" title="Poland in the European Union">Poland becoming a full member</a> on 1 May 2004. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/170px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/255px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg/340px-Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Flowers_in_front_of_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Warsaw.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Flowers in front of the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Warsaw" title="Presidential Palace, Warsaw">Presidential Palace</a> following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Polish_Air_Force_Tu-154_crash" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash">death of Poland's top government officials</a> in a plane crash over Smolensk in Russia, 10 April 2010
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland joined the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> in 2007, as a result of which, <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Poland" title="Borders of Poland">the country's borders</a> with other member states of the European Union have been dismantled, allowing for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_movement#European_Union" title="Freedom of movement">full freedom of movement</a> within most of the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Europe's_border-free_zone_expands_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europe's_border-free_zone_expands-124">[116]</a></sup> In contrast to this, a section of Poland's eastern border now constitutes the external EU border with <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, Russia and Ukraine. That border has become increasingly well protected, and has led in part to the coining of the phrase <a href="/wiki/Fortress_Europe#Modern_times" title="Fortress Europe">'Fortress Europe'</a>, in reference to the seeming 'impossibility' of gaining entry to the EU for citizens of the <a href="/wiki/Former_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Former Soviet Union">former Soviet Union</a>. </p>
      <p>In an effort to strengthen military cooperation with its neighbors, Poland set up the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Battlegroup" title="Visegrád Battlegroup">Visegrád Battlegroup</a> with Hungary, Czech Republic and Slovakia, with a total of 3,000 troops ready for deployment. Also, in eastern Poland, it formed the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian%E2%80%93Polish%E2%80%93Ukrainian_Brigade" title="Lithuanian–Polish–Ukrainian Brigade">LITPOLUKRBRIG</a> battle groups with Lithuania and Ukraine. These battle groups will operate outside of NATO and within the European defense initiative framework.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[117]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 10 April 2010, the President of the Republic of Poland, <a href="/wiki/Lech_Kaczy%C5%84ski" title="Lech Kaczyński">Lech Kaczyński</a>, along with 89 other high-ranking Polish officials <a href="/wiki/2010_Polish_Air_Force_Tu-154_crash" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash">died in a plane crash</a> near <a href="/wiki/Smolensk" title="Smolensk">Smolensk</a>, Russia. The president's party was on their way to attend an annual service of commemoration for the victims of the <a href="/wiki/Katyn_massacre" title="Katyn massacre">Katyń massacre</a> when the tragedy took place. </p>
      <p>In 2011, the ruling <a href="/wiki/Civic_Platform" title="Civic Platform">Civic Platform</a> won <a href="/wiki/2011_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2011 Polish parliamentary election">parliamentary elections</a>. Poland joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> in 2012, as well as organised the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">UEFA Euro 2012</a> (along with Ukraine). In 2013, Poland also became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Development_Assistance_Committee" title="Development Assistance Committee">Development Assistance Committee</a>. In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Poland" title="Prime Minister of Poland">Prime Minister of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a>, was chosen to be <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, and resigned as prime minister. The <a href="/wiki/2015_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2015 Polish parliamentary election">2015</a> and <a href="/wiki/2019_Polish_parliamentary_election" title="2019 Polish parliamentary election">2019 elections</a> were won by the conservative <a href="/wiki/Law_and_Justice" title="Law and Justice">Law and Justice</a> Party (PiS),<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[119]</a></sup> resulting in <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%93present_Polish_constitutional_crisis" title="2015–present Polish constitutional crisis">increased friction</a> between Poland and the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-128">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:3_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-129">[121]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Poland" title="Geography of Poland">Geography of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Poland_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/220px-Poland_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/330px-Poland_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Poland_topo.jpg/440px-Poland_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1364"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Poland_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">Topographic</a> map of Poland
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland's vast territory covers approximately 312,696&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (120,733&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), of which 98.52% is dry land and 1.48% is water.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[122]</a></sup> Extending across several geographical regions, the country is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">9th-largest by area in Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">69th largest in the world</a>. Topographically, Poland is diverse and has access to the sea, the mountains and open terrain.<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-131">[123]</a></sup> Although most of the central parts of the country are flat, there is an abundance of lakes, rivers, hills, swamps, beaches, islands and forests elsewhere.<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-131">[123]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the north-west is the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic</a> seacoast spanning from the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pomerania" title="Bay of Pomerania">Bay of Pomerania</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_Bay" title="Gdańsk Bay">Gulf of Gdańsk</a>. The coast is marked by several <a href="/wiki/Spit_(landform)" title="Spit (landform)">spits</a>, coastal lakes (former bays that have been cut off from the sea), and <a href="/wiki/Sand_dunes" class="mw-redirect" title="Sand dunes">dunes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[124]</a></sup> The largely straight coastline is indented by the <a href="/wiki/Szczecin_Lagoon" title="Szczecin Lagoon">Szczecin Lagoon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Puck" title="Bay of Puck">Bay of Puck</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Lagoon" title="Vistula Lagoon">Vistula Lagoon</a>. </p>
      <p>The central and northern parts of the country lie within the <a href="/wiki/North_European_Plain" title="North European Plain">North European Plain</a>. Rising above these lowlands is a geographical region comprising four hilly districts of <a href="/wiki/Moraine" title="Moraine">moraines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moraine-dammed_lake" title="Moraine-dammed lake">moraine-dammed lakes</a> formed during and after the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary_glaciation" title="Quaternary glaciation">Pleistocene ice age</a>, notably the <a href="/wiki/Pomerania" title="Pomerania">Pomeranian</a> Lake District, the Greater Polish Lake District, the <a href="/wiki/Kashubia" title="Kashubia">Kashubian</a> Lake District, and the <a href="/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District" title="Masurian Lake District">Masurian Lake District</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto6_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-133">[125]</a></sup> The Masurian Lake District is the largest of the four and covers much of north-eastern Poland. The lake districts form a series of moraine belts along the southern shore of the Baltic Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-auto6_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-133">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South of the Northern European Plain are the regions of <a href="/wiki/Lusatia" title="Lusatia">Lusatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silesia" title="Silesia">Silesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Masovia" class="mw-redirect" title="Masovia">Masovia</a>, which are marked by broad ice-age river valleys.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[126]</a></sup> The extreme south of Poland is mountainous; it runs from the <a href="/wiki/Sudetes" title="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> in the west to the and the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the east. The highest part of the Carpathian massif is the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountain</a> range, along Poland's southern border.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[127]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/220px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/330px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg/440px-Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="3000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Morskie_Oko_o_poranku.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Morskie_Oko" title="Morskie Oko">Morskie Oko</a> at the foothill of <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountains</a> in southern Poland which average 2,000 metres (6,600 ft) in elevation
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The geological structure of Poland has been shaped by the <a href="/wiki/Continental_collision" title="Continental collision">continental collision</a> of Europe and Africa over the past 60&nbsp;million years and, more recently, by the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary" title="Quaternary">Quaternary</a> glaciations of northern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[128]</a></sup> Both processes shaped the Sudetes and the Carpathian Mountains. The moraine landscape of northern Poland contains soils made up mostly of sand or <a href="/wiki/Loam" title="Loam">loam</a>, while the ice age river valleys of the south often contain <a href="/wiki/Loess" title="Loess">loess</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Polish_Jura" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Jura">Polish Jura</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pieniny" title="Pieniny">Pieniny</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Tatras" title="Western Tatras">Western Tatras</a> consist of <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>, whereas the <a href="/wiki/High_Tatras" title="High Tatras">High Tatras</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Beskids" title="Beskids">Beskids</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Karkonosze" class="mw-redirect" title="Karkonosze">Karkonosze</a> mountain ranges are made up mainly of <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basalt" title="Basalt">basalts</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Polish_Jura_Chain" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Jura Chain">Polish Jura Chain</a> has some of the oldest rock formations on the continent of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[129]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland has over 70 mountains over 2,000 metres (6,600 feet) in elevation, all situated in the <a href="/wiki/Tatras" class="mw-redirect" title="Tatras">Tatras</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[130]</a></sup> Poland's highest point is the north-western summit of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rysy" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Rysy">Mount Rysy</a> at 2,499 metres (8,199&nbsp;ft) in elevation. At its foot lie the mountain lakes of <a href="/wiki/Czarny_Staw_pod_Rysami" title="Czarny Staw pod Rysami">Czarny Staw</a> (Black Lake) and <a href="/wiki/Morskie_Oko" title="Morskie Oko">Morskie Oko</a> (Eye of the Sea), both naturally-made <a href="/wiki/Tarn_(lake)" title="Tarn (lake)">tarns</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[131]</a></sup> Other notable uplands include the <a href="/wiki/Pieniny" title="Pieniny">Pieniny</a> and <a href="/wiki/Holy_Cross_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Cross Mountains">Holy Cross Mountains</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Table_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Table Mountains">Table Mountains</a> noted for their unusual rock formations, the <a href="/wiki/Bieszczady_Mountains" title="Bieszczady Mountains">Bieszczady</a> in the far southeast of the country in which the highest peak is <a href="/wiki/Tarnica" title="Tarnica">Tarnica</a> at 1,346 metres (4,416&nbsp;ft),<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[132]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Gorce_Mountains" title="Gorce Mountains">Gorce Mountains</a> whose highest point is <a href="/wiki/Turbacz" title="Turbacz">Turbacz</a> at 1,310 metres (4,298&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[133]</a></sup> The highest point of the Sudeten massif is <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Anie%C5%BCka" class="mw-redirect" title="Śnieżka">Mount Śnieżka</a> (1,603.3 metres (5,260&nbsp;ft)), shared with the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[134]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG/220px-Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG/330px-Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG/440px-Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3500" data-file-height="2333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Na_Szczeli%C5%84cu_Wielkim_3.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Table_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Table Mountains">Table Mountains</a> are part of the <a href="/wiki/Sudetes" title="Sudetes">Sudetes</a> range in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesia" title="Lower Silesia">Lower Silesia</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The lowest point in Poland – at 1.8 metres (5.9&nbsp;ft) below sea level – is at <a href="/wiki/Raczki_Elbl%C4%85skie" title="Raczki Elbląskie">Raczki Elbląskie</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Elbl%C4%85g" title="Elbląg">Elbląg</a> in the Vistula Delta.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[135]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Zag%C5%82%C4%99bie_D%C4%85browskie" class="mw-redirect" title="Zagłębie Dąbrowskie">Zagłębie Dąbrowskie</a> (the Coal Fields of <a href="/wiki/D%C4%85browa_G%C3%B3rnicza" title="Dąbrowa Górnicza">Dąbrowa</a>) region in the <a href="/wiki/Silesian_Voivodeship" title="Silesian Voivodeship">Silesian Voivodeship</a> in southern Poland is an area of sparsely vegetated sand known as the <a href="/wiki/B%C5%82%C4%99d%C3%B3w_Desert" title="Błędów Desert">Błędów Desert</a>. It covers an area of 32 square kilometres (12&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[136]</a></sup> It is not a natural desert and was formed by human activity from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> onwards.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[137]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Baltic Sea activity in <a href="/wiki/S%C5%82owi%C5%84ski_National_Park" title="Słowiński National Park">Słowiński National Park</a> created <a href="/wiki/Sand_dunes" class="mw-redirect" title="Sand dunes">sand dunes</a> which in the course of time separated the bay from the sea creating two lakes. As waves and wind carry sand inland the dunes slowly move, at a rate of 3 to 10 metres (9.8 to 32.8&nbsp;ft) per year. Some dunes reach the height of up to 30 metres (98&nbsp;ft). The highest peak of the park is Rowokol at 115 metres or 377 feet <a href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[138]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Waters">Waters</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rivers_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Rivers of Poland">Rivers of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg/220px-Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg/330px-Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg/440px-Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Opactwo_Benedyktyn%C3%B3w_w_Ty%C5%84cu_w_zimowej_szacie.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Vistula_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Vistula River">Vistula</a> is the longest river in Poland, flowing the entire length of the country for 1,047 kilometres (651 mi).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The longest rivers are the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Vistula River">Vistula</a> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">Wisła</i>), 1,047 kilometres (651&nbsp;mi) long; the <a href="/wiki/Oder_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Oder River">Oder</a> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">Odra</i>) which forms part of Poland's western border, 854 kilometres (531&nbsp;mi) long; its tributary, the <a href="/wiki/Warta" title="Warta">Warta</a>, 808 kilometres (502&nbsp;mi) long; and the <a href="/wiki/Bug_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Bug River">Bug</a>, a tributary of the Vistula, 772 kilometres (480&nbsp;mi) long. The Vistula and the Oder flow into the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, as do numerous smaller rivers in Pomerania.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[139]</a></sup> Poland's lengthy waterways have been used since early times for navigation; the <a href="/wiki/Viking" class="mw-redirect" title="Viking">Vikings</a> ventured up the Polish rivers in their <a href="/wiki/Longship" title="Longship">longships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[140]</a></sup> In the Middle Ages and in early modern times, the shipment of tangible goods down the Vistula toward <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a> and onward to other parts of Europe took on great importance.<sup id="cite_ref-Snyder-111_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Snyder-111-149">[141]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With almost ten thousand closed bodies of water covering more than 1 hectare (2.47 acres) each, Poland has one of the highest numbers of lakes in the world. In Europe, only <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> has a greater density of lakes.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[142]</a></sup> The largest lakes, covering more than 100 square kilometres (39&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), are <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aniardwy" title="Śniardwy">Lake Śniardwy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Mamry" title="Lake Mamry">Lake Mamry</a> in <a href="/wiki/Masuria" title="Masuria">Masuria</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/%C5%81ebsko_Lake" title="Łebsko Lake">Lake Łebsko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Drawsko_Lake" title="Drawsko Lake">Lake Drawsko</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pomerania" title="Pomerania">Pomerania</a>. The lake with the greatest depth—of more than 100 metres (328&nbsp;ft)—is <a href="/wiki/Ha%C5%84cza" title="Hańcza">Lake Hańcza</a> in the Wigry Lake District, east of Masuria in <a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship">Podlaskie Voivodeship</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg/220px-Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg/330px-Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg/440px-Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="550"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Olecko_Jezioro_Oleckie_Wielkie.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District" title="Masurian Lake District">Masurian Lake District</a>, located in the <a href="/wiki/Masuria" title="Masuria">Masuria</a> region of Poland, contains more than 2,000 lakes.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Polish Baltic coast is approximately 770 kilometres (478&nbsp;mi) long and extends from <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Świnoujście">Świnoujście</a> on the islands of <a href="/wiki/Usedom" title="Usedom">Usedom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wolin" title="Wolin">Wolin</a> in the west to <a href="/wiki/Krynica_Morska" title="Krynica Morska">Krynica Morska</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Spit" title="Vistula Spit">Vistula Spit</a> in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[143]</a></sup> For the most part, Poland has a smooth coastline, which has been shaped by the continual movement of sand by currents and winds. This continual <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deposition_(geology)" title="Deposition (geology)">deposition</a> has formed cliffs, dunes, and spits, many of which have migrated landwards to close off former lagoons, such as <a href="/wiki/%C5%81ebsko_Lake" title="Łebsko Lake">Łebsko Lake</a> in the Słowiński National Park. </p>
      <p>The largest spits are <a href="/wiki/Hel_Peninsula" title="Hel Peninsula">Hel Peninsula</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Spit" title="Vistula Spit">Vistula Spit</a>. The coast line is varied also by <a href="/wiki/Szczecin_Lagoon" title="Szczecin Lagoon">Szczecin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Lagoon" title="Vistula Lagoon">Vistula Lagoons</a> and several lakes, including <a href="/wiki/Jamno_(lake)" title="Jamno (lake)">Jamno</a>. The largest Polish Baltic island is <a href="/wiki/Wolin" title="Wolin">Wolin</a>, located within <a href="/wiki/Wolin_National_Park" title="Wolin National Park">Wolin National Park</a>. The largest sea <a href="/wiki/Harbour" class="mw-redirect" title="Harbour">harbours</a> are <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Szczecin" title="Port of Szczecin">Szczecin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Port of Świnoujście">Świnoujście</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gdynia" title="Port of Gdynia">Gdynia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Police" title="Port of Police">Police</a> and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="Port of Kołobrzeg">Kołobrzeg</a> and the main coastal resorts – <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Świnoujście">Świnoujście</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mi%C4%99dzyzdroje" title="Międzyzdroje">Międzydzdroje</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="Kołobrzeg">Kołobrzeg</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%81eba" title="Łeba">Łeba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sopot" title="Sopot">Sopot</a>, <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82awowo" title="Władysławowo">Władysławowo</a> and the Hel Peninsula. </p>
      <p>In the valley of <a href="/wiki/Pilica_(river)" title="Pilica (river)">Pilica</a> river in <a href="/wiki/Tomasz%C3%B3w_Mazowiecki" title="Tomaszów Mazowiecki">Tomaszów Mazowiecki</a> there is a unique natural <a href="/wiki/Spring_(hydrology)" title="Spring (hydrology)">karst spring</a> of water containing calcium salts, that is an object of protection at <a href="/wiki/Niebieskie_%C5%B9r%C3%B3d%C5%82a_Nature_Reserve" title="Niebieskie Źródła Nature Reserve">Blue Springs Nature Reserve</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sulej%C3%B3w_Landscape_Park" title="Sulejów Landscape Park">Sulejów Landscape Park</a>. The red waves are absorbed by water, hence only blue and green are reflected from the bottom of the spring, giving the water atypical colour.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[144]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Land_use">Land use</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg/220px-2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg/330px-2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg/440px-2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4028" data-file-height="2668"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2014_Pole_uprawne_w_Raszkowie.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">Wheat</a> fields in <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland" title="Greater Poland">Greater Poland</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Forests cover about 29.6% of Poland's land area based on international standards.<sup id="cite_ref-Lasy_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lasy-153">[145]</a></sup> Its overall percentage is still increasing. <a href="/wiki/Forests_of_Poland" title="Forests of Poland">Forests of Poland</a> are managed by the national program of reforestation (KPZL), aiming at an increase of forest-cover to 33% in 2050. The largest forest complex in Poland is <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesian_Wilderness" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower Silesian Wilderness">Lower Silesian Wilderness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lasy_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lasy-153">[145]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>More than 1% of Poland's territory, 3,145 square kilometres (1,214&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), is protected within 23 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="List of national parks of Poland">Polish national parks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[146]</a></sup> Three more national parks are projected for <a href="/wiki/Masuria" title="Masuria">Masuria</a>, the Polish Jura, and the eastern <a href="/wiki/Beskids" title="Beskids">Beskids</a>. In addition, <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">wetlands</a> along lakes and rivers in central Poland are legally protected, as are coastal areas in the north. There are 123 areas designated as <a href="/wiki/Landscape_Park_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Landscape Park (Poland)">landscape parks</a>, along with numerous <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Poland" title="Protected areas of Poland">protected areas</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a> network.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[147]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, approximately 16,400,000 hectares (164,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>) of land was occupied by farms and farmsteads, over half of Poland's total area.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[148]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg/220px-Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg/330px-Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg/440px-Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="912" data-file-height="608"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bia%C5%82owieski_Park_Narodowy03_23a.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="Białowieża Forest">Białowieża Forest</a>, an ancient woodland in eastern Poland and a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>, is home to 800 wild <a href="/wiki/Wisent" class="mw-redirect" title="Wisent">wisent</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">Phytogeographically</a>, Poland belongs to the Central European province of the <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">Circumboreal Region</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a>, the territory of <a href="/wiki/Ecoregions_in_Poland" title="Ecoregions in Poland">Poland belongs to three Palearctic Ecoregions</a> of the continental forest spanning Central and Northern European <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest">temperate broadleaf and mixed forest</a> ecoregions as well as the Carpathian <a href="/wiki/Montane" class="mw-redirect" title="Montane">montane</a> conifer forest. The most common <a href="/wiki/Deciduous_trees" class="mw-redirect" title="Deciduous trees">deciduous trees</a> found across the country are <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maple" title="Maple">maple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beech" title="Beech">beech</a>; among common conifers are <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">spruce</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fir" title="Fir">fir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[149]</a></sup> An estimated 68.7% of all forests are <a href="/wiki/Coniferous" class="mw-redirect" title="Coniferous">coniferous</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland has historically been home to rare species of animals as well as the two largest European mammals — the <a href="/wiki/European_bison" title="European bison">wisent</a> (<i>żubr</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Aurochs" title="Aurochs">aurochs</a> (<i>tur</i>). The last aurochs of Europe became extinct in 1627 in the Polish <a href="/wiki/Jaktor%C3%B3w" title="Jaktorów">Jaktorów Forest</a>, while the wisent survived until the 20th century only at <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="Białowieża Forest">Białowieża</a>. It has been since reintroduced to other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[151]</a></sup> Other wild species include the <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a> in Białowieża, in the Tatras, and in the Beskids, the <a href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray wolf">gray wolf</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">Eurasian lynx</a> in various forests, the <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a> in northern Poland, and the <a href="/wiki/Beaver" title="Beaver">beaver</a> in Masuria, Pomerania, and Podlaskie.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[152]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:White_Stork_(Ciconia_ciconia),_Zajki_meadows,_Eastern_Poland.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg/220px-White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg/330px-White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg/440px-White_Stork_%28Ciconia_ciconia%29%2C_Zajki_meadows%2C_Eastern_Poland.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4058" data-file-height="3043"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:White_Stork_(Ciconia_ciconia),_Zajki_meadows,_Eastern_Poland.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Poland is host to the largest <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">white stork</a> population in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Poland.pl_–_White_Stork_–_About_White_Stork_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Poland.pl_–_White_Stork_–_About_White_Stork-161">[153]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Game animals such as <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a> are found in most woodlands. Eastern Poland abounds in ancient woods, like the Białowieża Forest, that have not been disturbed by human or industrial activity. There are also large forested areas in the mountains, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Poland" title="Greater Poland">Greater Poland</a>, Pomerania, <a href="/wiki/Lubusz_Land" title="Lubusz Land">Lubusz Land</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesia" title="Lower Silesia">Lower Silesia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Lubusz_Voivodeship" title="Lubusz Voivodeship">Lubusz Voivodeship</a> is currently the most arboraceous province in the country; 52% of its territory is occupied by forests.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[154]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland is also a significant breeding ground for a variety of European <a href="/wiki/Migratory_birds" class="mw-redirect" title="Migratory birds">migratory birds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[155]</a></sup> One quarter of the global population of <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">white storks</a> (40,000 breeding pairs) live in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[156]</a></sup> particularly in the lake districts and the wetlands along the <a href="/wiki/Biebrza" title="Biebrza">Biebrza</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Narew" title="Narew">Narew</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Warta" title="Warta">Warta</a>, which are part of nature reserves or national parks. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <p>The climate is mostly <a href="/wiki/Temperateness" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperateness">temperate</a> throughout the country. The climate is <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> in the north-west and becomes gradually warmer and <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a> towards the south-east. Summers are generally warm, with average temperatures between 18 and 30&nbsp;°C (64.4 and 86.0&nbsp;°F) depending on the region. Winters are rather cold, with average temperatures around 3&nbsp;°C (37.4&nbsp;°F) in the northwest and −6&nbsp;°C (21&nbsp;°F) in the northeast. <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> falls throughout the year, although, especially in the east, winter is drier than summer.<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-165">[157]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The warmest region in Poland is <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesian_Voivodeship" title="Lower Silesian Voivodeship">Lower Silesia</a> in the southwest of the country, where temperatures in the summer average between 24 and 32&nbsp;°C (75 and 90&nbsp;°F) but can go as high as 34 to 39&nbsp;°C (93.2 to 102.2&nbsp;°F) on some days in the warmest months of July and August. The warmest cities in Poland are <a href="/wiki/Tarn%C3%B3w" title="Tarnów">Tarnów</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Poland_Voivodeship" title="Lesser Poland Voivodeship">Lesser Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a> in Lower Silesia. The average temperatures in Wrocław are 20&nbsp;°C (68&nbsp;°F) in the summer and 0&nbsp;°C (32.0&nbsp;°F) in the winter, but <a href="/wiki/Tarn%C3%B3w" title="Tarnów">Tarnów</a> has the longest summer in all of Poland, which lasts for 115 days, from mid-May to mid-September. The coldest region of Poland is in the northeast, around the area of <a href="/wiki/Suwa%C5%82ki" title="Suwałki">Suwałki</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship">Podlaskie Voivodeship</a>, where the climate is affected by <a href="/wiki/Cold_front" title="Cold front">cold fronts</a> coming from <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>. The average temperature in the winter in Podlaskie ranges from −6 to −4&nbsp;°C (21 to 25&nbsp;°F). The biggest impact of the <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> is observed in <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Świnoujście">Świnoujście</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> seashore area from <a href="/wiki/Police,_West_Pomeranian_Voivodeship" title="Police, West Pomeranian Voivodeship">Police</a> to <a href="/wiki/S%C5%82upsk" title="Słupsk">Słupsk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[158]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto;">
