      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces" title="Polish Armed Forces">Polish Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_Defence_Force_(Poland)" title="Territorial Defence Force (Poland)">Territorial Defence Force (Poland)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_(48).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/220px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/330px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg/440px-F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_%2848%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="533"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:F-16_Jastrz%C4%85b_(48).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Polish_Air_Force" title="Polish Air Force">Polish Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon" class="mw-redirect" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon">F-16s</a>, a single-engine <a href="/wiki/Multirole_combat_aircraft" title="Multirole combat aircraft">multirole</a> <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">fighter aircraft</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces" title="Polish Armed Forces">Polish Armed Forces</a> are composed of five branches – <a href="/wiki/Polish_Land_Forces" title="Polish Land Forces">Land Forces</a> (<i>Wojska Lądowe</i>), <a href="/wiki/Polish_Navy" title="Polish Navy">Navy</a> (<i>Marynarka Wojenna</i>), <a href="/wiki/Polish_Air_Force" title="Polish Air Force">Air Force</a> (<i>Siły Powietrzne</i>), <a href="/wiki/Special_forces_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Special forces of Poland">Special Forces</a> (<i>Wojska Specjalne</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_Defence_Force_(Poland)" title="Territorial Defence Force (Poland)">Territorial Defence Force</a> (<i>Wojska Obrony Terytorialnej</i>). The military is subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of National Defence of the Republic of Poland">Ministry of National Defence of the Republic of Poland</a>. However, its commander-in-chief in peacetime is the President of the Republic, who nominates officers, the Minister for National Defence and the chief of staff.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2018, the Polish Armed Forces have a combined strength of 144,142 soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[193]</a></sup> The Polish Navy primarily operates on the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> and conducts operations such as maritime patrol, search and rescue for the section of the Baltic under Polish sovereignty, as well as <a href="/wiki/Hydrography" title="Hydrography">hydrographic measurements</a> and research. The Polish Air Force routinely takes part in <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Air_Policing" title="Baltic Air Policing">Baltic Air Policing</a> assignments. In 2003, the <a href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon" class="mw-redirect" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon">F-16C</a> Block 52 was selected as the new general multi-role fighter for the air force. In January 2020, Poland has approved the delivery for <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_F-35_Lightning_II" title="Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II">F-35 Lightning II</a> combat aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[195]</a></sup> Poland is currently spending 2% of its GDP on defence (approximately US$13.5 billion in 2020), which is expected to grow to 2.5% by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[196]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/SIPRI" class="mw-redirect" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a>, the country exported EUR€487 million worth of arms and armaments to other countries, primarily to the United States, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, France and <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[197]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Polish_SOF,_Lisbon,_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_(22182255143).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg/220px-Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg/330px-Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg/440px-Polish_SOF%2C_Lisbon%2C_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_%2822182255143%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="1500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Polish_SOF,_Lisbon,_NATO_Trident_Juncture_15_(22182255143).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Soldier from the Polish Naval Special Forces Unit, <a href="/wiki/JW_GROM" title="JW GROM">JW GROM</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The mission of the armed forces is the defence of Poland's territorial integrity and Polish interests abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-mil_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mil-206">[198]</a></sup> The country's national security goal is to further integrate with <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and European defence, economic, and political institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-mil_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mil-206">[198]</a></sup> Compulsory <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">military service</a> for men was discontinued in 2008. From 2007, until conscription ended in 2008, the mandatory service was nine months.<sup id="cite_ref-Poland_ends_army_conscription_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Poland_ends_army_conscription-207">[199]</a></sup> Polish military doctrine reflects the same defensive nature as that of its NATO partners and the country actively hosts NATO's <a href="/wiki/Military_exercises" class="mw-redirect" title="Military exercises">military exercises</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[200]</a></sup> From 1953 to 2009 Poland was a large contributor to various <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> peacekeeping missions.<sup id="cite_ref-mil_206-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mil-206">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Polska_zakończyła_udział_w_misjach_po_auspicjami_ONZ_–_Wiadomości_z_kraju_i_ze_świata_–_Gazeta_Prawna_–_Partner_pracodawcy,_narzędzie_specjalisty_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Polska_zakończyła_udział_w_misjach_po_auspicjami_ONZ_–_Wiadomości_z_kraju_i_ze_świata_–_Gazeta_Prawna_–_Partner_pracodawcy,_narzędzie_specjalisty-209">[201]</a></sup> The Polish Armed Forces took part in the <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>, deploying 2,500 soldiers in the south of that country and commanding the 17-nation <a href="/wiki/Multinational_force_in_Iraq" class="mw-redirect" title="Multinational force in Iraq">multinational force in Iraq</a>. Poland also maintains troops in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>; 1,650 soldiers were deployed in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_emergency_services">Law enforcement and emergency services</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Poland" title="Law enforcement in Poland">Law enforcement in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services_in_Poland" title="Emergency medical services in Poland">Emergency medical services in Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/State_Fire_Service" title="State Fire Service">State Fire Service</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/220px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/330px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG/440px-Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2784" data-file-height="1952"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter_Policja_Krakow_G719.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter" title="Mercedes-Benz Sprinter">Mercedes-Benz Sprinter</a> patrol van belonging to the Polish <a href="/wiki/Policja" class="mw-redirect" title="Policja">State Police Service</a> (<i>Policja</i>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Law enforcement in Poland is performed by several agencies which are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_and_Administration_(Poland)" title="Ministry of Interior and Administration (Poland)">Ministry of Interior and Administration</a> – the <a href="/wiki/Policja" class="mw-redirect" title="Policja">State Police</a> (<i>Policja</i>), assigned to investigate crimes or transgression; the <a href="/wiki/City_Guard_(Poland)" title="City Guard (Poland)">Municipal City Guard</a>, which maintains public order; and several specialized agencies, such as the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Border_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Border Guard">Polish Border Guard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-211">[203]</a></sup> Private security firms are also common, although they possess no legal authority to arrest or detain a suspect.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-211">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[204]</a></sup> Municipal guards are primarily headed by provincial, regional or city councils; individual guards are not permitted to carry <a href="/wiki/Firearms" class="mw-redirect" title="Firearms">firearms</a> unless instructed by their superior commanding officer or commandant.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Internal_Security_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal Security Agency">Internal Security Agency</a> (ABW, or ISA in English) is the chief <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_agency" title="Intelligence agency">counter-intelligence instrument</a> safeguarding Poland's internal security, along with <a href="/wiki/Agencja_Wywiadu" title="Agencja Wywiadu">Agencja Wywiadu</a> (AW) which identifies threats and collects secret information abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[206]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Centralne_Biuro_%C5%9Aledcze_Policji" title="Centralne Biuro Śledcze Policji">Central Investigation Bureau of Police</a> (CBŚP) and the <a href="/wiki/Central_Anticorruption_Bureau" title="Central Anticorruption Bureau">Central Anticorruption Bureau</a> (CBA) are responsible for countering organized crime and corruption in state and private institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[208]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Emergency services in Poland consist of the <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services_in_Poland" title="Emergency medical services in Poland">emergency medical services</a>, <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue#Poland" title="Search and rescue">search and rescue</a> units of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces" title="Polish Armed Forces">Polish Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/State_Fire_Service" title="State Fire Service">State Fire Service</a>. Emergency medical services in Poland are provided for by local and regional governments.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>All emergency services personnel are uniformed and security services can be easily recognized during regular patrols in both large urban areas or smaller suburban localities.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[210]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Poland" title="Economy of Poland">Economy of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="infobox" style="font-size: 90%; border: 1px solid #999; width: 325px;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr style="background:#f5f5f5"> 
         <th colspan="3">
          <div class="center">
           <div class="floatnone">
            <a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Panorama siekierkowski.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg/310px-Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="127" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg/465px-Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg/620px-Panorama_siekierkowski.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7237" data-file-height="2973"></a>
           </div>
          </div>
          <hr>
          <center>
           Economic indicators
          </center> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP (PPP)</a></td> 
         <td>$1.353 trillion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-IMFWEOPL_14-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOPL-14">[11]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Nominal <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a></td> 
         <td>$607 billion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-IMFWEOPL_14-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOPL-14">[11]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>Real GDP growth</td> 
         <td>4.1% <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[211]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Consumer_price_index" title="Consumer price index">CPI</a> inflation</td> 
         <td>2.2% <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[212]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Employment-to-population_ratio" title="Employment-to-population ratio">Employment-to-population ratio</a></td> 
         <td>55% <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[213]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">Unemployment</a></td> 
         <td>3.4% <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[214]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/National_debt" class="mw-redirect" title="National debt">Total public debt</a></td> 
         <td>$274 billion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[215]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Poland's economy and <a href="/wiki/Gross_Domestic_Product" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross Domestic Product">Gross Domestic Product</a> (GDP) is currently the sixth largest in the European Union by <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union" title="Economy of the European Union">nominal standards</a>, and the fifth largest by <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Europe_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Europe by GDP (PPP)">purchasing power parity</a>. It is also one of the fastest growing within the Union.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[216]</a></sup> Around 60% of the employed population belongs to the tertiary <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a>, 30% to industry and manufacturing, and the remaining 10% to the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural</a> sector.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[217]</a></sup> Although Poland is a member of EU's <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">single market</a>, the country has not adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> as legal tender and maintains its own currency – the <a href="/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty" title="Polish złoty">Polish złoty</a> (zł, PLN). </p>
      <p>Poland is the regional economic leader in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>, with nearly 40 per cent of the 500 biggest companies in the region (by revenues) as well as a <a href="/wiki/Globalisation_index" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalisation index">high globalisation rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Polish_economy_seen_as_stable_and_competitive_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Polish_economy_seen_as_stable_and_competitive-226">[218]</a></sup> The country's largest firms compose the <a href="/wiki/WIG20" title="WIG20">WIG20</a> and <a href="/wiki/WIG30" title="WIG30">WIG30</a> <a href="/wiki/Stock_market_index" title="Stock market index">indexes</a>, which is traded on the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange" title="Warsaw Stock Exchange">Warsaw Stock Exchange</a>. According to reports made by the <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Poland" title="National Bank of Poland">National Bank of Poland</a>, the value of Polish foreign direct investments reached almost 300 billion <a href="/wiki/Polish_z%C5%82oty" title="Polish złoty">PLN</a> at the end of 2014. The <a href="/wiki/Central_Statistical_Office_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Statistical Office (Poland)">Central Statistical Office</a> estimated that in 2014 there were 1,437 Polish corporations with interests in 3,194 foreign entities.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[219]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Having a strong domestic market, low private debt, low unemployment rate, flexible currency, and not being dependent on a single export sector, Poland is the only European economy to have avoided the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">recession of 2008</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Global_Competitiveness_Report_2010–2011_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Global_Competitiveness_Report_2010–2011-228">[220]</a></sup> The country is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">20th largest exporter</a> of goods and services in the world and its most successful exports include machinery, furniture, food products, clothing, shoes, cosmetics and videogames.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-229">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[223]</a></sup> These account to approximately 56% of the total GDP, as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_229-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-229">[221]</a></sup> Poland's largest trading partners include Germany, Czech Republic, United Kingdom, France and Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[225]</a></sup> Warsaw leads Central Europe in foreign investment.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[226]</a></sup> In September 2018, the unemployment rate was estimated at 5.7%, one of the lowest in the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[227]</a></sup> In 2019, Poland passed a law that would exempt workers under the age of 26 from <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">income tax</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[228]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg/220px-Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg/330px-Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg/440px-Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2927" data-file-height="2154"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gie%C5%82da_Papier%C3%B3w_Warto%C5%9Bciowych_w_Warszawie_ul._Ksi%C4%85%C5%BC%C4%99ca_2020.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Stock_Exchange" title="Warsaw Stock Exchange">Warsaw Stock Exchange</a> is the largest exchange by market capitalization in <a href="/wiki/East-Central_Europe" title="East-Central Europe">East-Central Europe</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Polish banking sector is the largest in the region,<sup id="cite_ref-TWI-2011_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TWI-2011-237">[229]</a></sup> with 32.3 branches per 100,000 adults.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-datatopics/poland_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-datatopics/poland-239">[231]</a></sup> The banks are the largest and most developed sector of the country's <a href="/wiki/Financial_market" title="Financial market">financial markets</a>. They are regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Financial_Supervision_Authority_(Poland)" title="Financial Supervision Authority (Poland)">Polish Financial Supervision Authority</a>. Poland's banking sector has approximately 5 national banks, a network of nearly 600 cooperative banks and 18 branches of foreign-owned banks. In addition, foreign investors have controlling stakes in nearly 40 commercial banks, which make up 68% of the banking capital.<sup id="cite_ref-TWI-2011_237-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TWI-2011-237">[229]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Products and goods manufactured in Poland include: electronics, buses and trams (<a href="/wiki/Solaris_Bus_%26_Coach" title="Solaris Bus &amp; Coach">Solaris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solbus" title="Solbus">Solbus</a>), helicopters and planes (<a href="/wiki/PZL_%C5%9Awidnik" class="mw-redirect" title="PZL Świdnik">PZL Świdnik</a>, <a href="/wiki/PZL_Mielec" title="PZL Mielec">PZL Mielec</a>), trains (<a href="/wiki/Pesa_SA" class="mw-redirect" title="Pesa SA">Pesa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newag" title="Newag">Newag</a>), ships (<a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_Shipyard" title="Gdańsk Shipyard">Gdańsk Shipyard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Szczecin_Shipyard" title="Szczecin Shipyard">Szczecin Shipyard</a>), military equipment (<a href="/wiki/FB_%22%C5%81ucznik%22_Radom" title="FB &quot;Łucznik&quot; Radom">FB "Łucznik" Radom</a>, <a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bumar_%C5%81ab%C4%99dy" class="extiw" title="pl:Bumar Łabędy">Bumar-Łabędy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jelcz" title="Jelcz">Jelcz</a>), medicines (<a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zak%C5%82ady_Farmaceutyczne_Polpharma" class="extiw" title="pl:Zakłady Farmaceutyczne Polpharma">Polpharma</a>, <a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polfa_Warszawa" class="extiw" title="pl:Polfa Warszawa">Polfa</a>), food (<a href="/wiki/Tymbark_(company)" title="Tymbark (company)">Tymbark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hortex" title="Hortex">Hortex</a>, <a href="/wiki/E._Wedel" title="E. Wedel">E. Wedel</a>), clothes (<a href="/wiki/LPP_(company)" title="LPP (company)">LLP</a>), glass, pottery (<a href="/wiki/Boleslawiec_Pottery" class="mw-redirect" title="Boleslawiec Pottery">Bolesławiec</a>), chemical products and others. Well-known brands and companies include <a href="/wiki/Alior_Bank" title="Alior Bank">Alior Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/PKN_Orlen" title="PKN Orlen">Orlen</a>&amp;<a href="/wiki/Grupa_Lotos" title="Grupa Lotos">Lotos Group</a>, <a href="/wiki/Inglot_Cosmetics" title="Inglot Cosmetics">Inglot Cosmetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plus_(telecommunications_Poland)" title="Plus (telecommunications Poland)">Plus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Play_(telecommunications)" title="Play (telecommunications)">Play</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brainly" title="Brainly">Brainly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Netguru" title="Netguru">Netguru</a>, <a href="/wiki/GOG.com" title="GOG.com">GOG.com</a>, <a href="/wiki/CD_Projekt" title="CD Projekt">CD Projekt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trefl" title="Trefl">Trefl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Allegro_(website)" title="Allegro (website)">Allegro</a>. Poland is also one of the world's biggest producers of <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, furniture, automotive parts and <a href="/wiki/Soft_drink" title="Soft drink">soft drink</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[234]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Poland" title="Tourism in Poland">Tourism in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Heritage Sites of Poland">List of World Heritage Sites of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Historic_Monuments_(Poland)" title="List of Historic Monuments (Poland)">List of Historic Monuments (Poland)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Poland" title="Seven Wonders of Poland">Seven Wonders of Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Polish_Mountains" title="Crown of Polish Mountains">Crown of Polish Mountains</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg/220px-Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg/330px-Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg/440px-Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1392" data-file-height="933"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ratusz_Zamosc.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Zamo%C5%9B%C4%87" title="Zamość">Old City of Zamość</a> is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland experienced a significant increase in the number of tourists after joining the European Union in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-Travel_And_Tourism_in_Poland_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Travel_And_Tourism_in_Poland-243">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[236]</a></sup> With nearly 21 million international arrivals in 2019, tourism contributes considerably to the overall economy and makes up a relatively large proportion of the country's service market.<sup id="cite_ref-unwto.org/en/press-release_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unwto.org/en/press-release-245">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[238]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tourist attractions in Poland vary, from the mountains in the south to the sandy beaches in the north, with a trail of nearly every architectural style. The most visited city is <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>, which was the former capital of Poland and serves as a relic of the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Golden_Age" title="Polish Golden Age">Polish Golden Age</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a>. Kraków also held <a href="/wiki/Royal_coronations_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal coronations in Poland">royal coronations</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_monarchs" title="List of Polish monarchs">most Polish kings and monarchs</a> at <a href="/wiki/Wawel" class="mw-redirect" title="Wawel">Wawel</a>, the nation's chief historical landmark. Among other notable sites in the country is <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a>, one of the oldest cities in Poland which was a model for the founding of Kraków. Wrocław is famous for its <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw%27s_dwarfs" title="Wrocław's dwarfs">dwarfs</a>, a large <a href="/wiki/Market_square" title="Market square">market square</a> with two <a href="/wiki/Town_hall" title="Town hall">town halls</a>, and the oldest <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_Zoo" title="Wrocław Zoo">Zoological Gardens</a> with one of the world's largest number of animal <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a>. The Polish capital <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> and its historical <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town" title="Warsaw Old Town">Old Town</a> were entirely reconstructed after <a href="/wiki/Planned_destruction_of_Warsaw" class="mw-redirect" title="Planned destruction of Warsaw">wartime destruction</a>. Other cities attracting countless tourists include <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="Poznań">Poznań</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lublin" title="Lublin">Lublin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toru%C5%84" title="Toruń">Toruń</a> as well as the site of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz_concentration_camp" title="Auschwitz concentration camp">Auschwitz concentration camp</a> in <a href="/wiki/O%C5%9Bwi%C4%99cim" title="Oświęcim">Oświęcim</a>. A notable highlight is the 13th-century <a href="/wiki/Wieliczka_Salt_Mine" title="Wieliczka Salt Mine">Wieliczka Salt Mine</a> with its labyrinthine tunnels, a <a href="/wiki/Underground_lake" title="Underground lake">subterranean lake</a> and chapels carved by miners out of <a href="/wiki/Rock_salt" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock salt">rock salt</a> beneath the ground. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afrykarium_tunel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Afrykarium_tunel.jpg/220px-Afrykarium_tunel.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Afrykarium_tunel.jpg/330px-Afrykarium_tunel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Afrykarium_tunel.jpg/440px-Afrykarium_tunel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1999" data-file-height="1499"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afrykarium_tunel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Aquarium in the <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_Zoo" title="Wrocław Zoo">Zoological Garden</a> in <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland's main tourist offerings include outdoor activities such as <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sailing" title="Sailing">sailing</a>, mountain <a href="/wiki/Hiking" title="Hiking">hiking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climbing" title="Climbing">climbing</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Agritourism" title="Agritourism">agritourism</a>, sightseeing <a href="/wiki/List_of_Historic_Monuments_(Poland)" title="List of Historic Monuments (Poland)">historical monuments</a>. Tourist destinations include the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> coast in the north; the <a href="/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District" title="Masurian Lake District">Masurian Lake District</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="Białowieża Forest">Białowieża Forest</a> in the east; on the south <a href="/wiki/Karkonosze" class="mw-redirect" title="Karkonosze">Karkonosze</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Table_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Table Mountains">Table Mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tatra_Mountains" title="Tatra Mountains">Tatra Mountains</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Rysy" title="Rysy">Rysy</a> – the highest peak of Poland, and <a href="/wiki/Orla_Per%C4%87" title="Orla Perć">Eagle's Path</a> mountain trail are located. The <a href="/wiki/Pieniny" title="Pieniny">Pieniny</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bieszczady_Mountains" title="Bieszczady Mountains">Bieszczady Mountains</a> lie in the extreme south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-turism_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turism-247">[239]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_castles_in_Poland" title="List of castles in Poland">over 100 castles</a> in the country, most in the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Silesian_Voivodeship" title="Lower Silesian Voivodeship">Lower Silesian Voivodeship</a> (inter alia <a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Szlak_Zamk%C3%B3w_Piastowskich" class="extiw" title="pl:Szlak Zamków Piastowskich">The Piast Castles Trail</a>), and also on the <a href="/wiki/Trail_of_the_Eagles%27_Nests" class="mw-redirect" title="Trail of the Eagles' Nests">Trail of the Eagles' Nests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[240]</a></sup> The largest castle in the world by land area is situated in <a href="/wiki/Malbork_Castle" title="Malbork Castle">Malbork</a>, in north-central Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[241]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Poland" title="Energy in Poland">Energy in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coal_mining_in_Poland" title="Coal mining in Poland">Coal mining in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg/220px-Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg/330px-Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg/440px-Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="799" data-file-height="509"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Elektrownia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Be%C5%82chat%C3%B3w_Power_Station" title="Bełchatów Power Station">Bełchatów Power Station</a> is a lignite-fired power station that produces 27–28 TWh of electricity per year or twenty per cent of the total power generation in Poland.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The electricity generation sector in Poland is largely <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil-fuel</a>–based. Many power plants nationwide use Poland's position as a major European exporter of coal to their advantage by continuing to use coal as the primary raw material in the production of their energy. In 2013, Poland scored 48 out of 129 states in the Energy Sustainability Index.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Sustainability_Index_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Sustainability_Index-250">[242]</a></sup> The three largest Polish coal mining firms (<a href="/wiki/W%C4%99glokoks" title="Węglokoks">Węglokoks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kompania_W%C4%99glowa" title="Kompania Węglowa">Kompania Węglowa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jastrz%C4%99bska_Sp%C3%B3%C5%82ka_W%C4%99glowa" title="Jastrzębska Spółka Węglowa">JSW</a>) extract around 100 million tonnes of coal annually. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">Renewable forms of energy</a> account for a smaller proportion of Poland's full energy generation capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-EU_Commission_–_Energy_factsheet_P74_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_Commission_–_Energy_factsheet_P74-251">[243]</a></sup> However, the national government has set targets for the development of renewable energy sources in Poland (the share of energy from renewable sources in the gross final energy consumption in 2019 was – 12,18%). Increasing the share of energy from renewable sources is to be achieved with the help of <a href="/wiki/Biofuel" title="Biofuel">biofuels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Photovoltaics" title="Photovoltaics">photovoltaics</a>, construction of land and sea <a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">wind farms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric">hydroelectric</a> stations and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a>. </p>
      <p>Poland has around 164,800,000,000 m<sup>3</sup> of proven natural gas reserves and around 96,380,000 barrels of proven oil reserves. These reserves are exploited by energy supply companies such as <a href="/wiki/PKN_Orlen" title="PKN Orlen">PKN Orlen</a> ("the only Polish company listed in the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a>"), <a href="/wiki/PGNiG" title="PGNiG">PGNiG</a>. However, the small amounts of fossil fuels naturally occurring in Poland are insufficient to satisfy the full energy consumption needs of the population. Consequently the country is a net importer of oil and natural gas. Therefore, since the second decade of the 21st century, Poland has been strongly developing the so-called North Gate in which the most important components are the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Pipe" title="Baltic Pipe">Baltic Pipe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie_LNG_terminal" title="Świnoujście LNG terminal">Świnoujście LNG terminal</a> and Floating Storage and Regasification Unit in <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of Gdańsk">Port of Gdańsk</a>. </p>
      <p>The 5 largest companies supplying Poland electricity are <a href="/wiki/Polska_Grupa_Energetyczna" class="mw-redirect" title="Polska Grupa Energetyczna">PGE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tauron_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Tauron Group">Tauron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enea_SA" title="Enea SA">Enea</a>, <a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energa" class="extiw" title="pl:Energa">Energa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Innogy" title="Innogy">Innogy Poland</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Poland" title="Transport in Poland">Transport in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Poland" title="List of airports in Poland">List of airports in Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">Highways in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_(2)_Lichen99.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/220px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/330px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg/440px-WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_%282%29_Lichen99.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3072"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:WK15_Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_(2)_Lichen99.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Polish_State_Railways" title="Polish State Railways">PKP Intercity</a> <a href="/wiki/New_Pendolino" title="New Pendolino">Pendolino</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_railway_station" title="Wrocław Główny railway station">Wrocław railway station</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Transport in Poland is provided by means of <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Poland" title="Rail transport in Poland">rail</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roads_and_expressways_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Roads and expressways in Poland">road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_Merchant_Navy" title="Polish Merchant Navy">marine shipping</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Poland" title="List of airports in Poland">air travel</a>. The country is part of EU's <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> and is an important transport hub along neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> due to its strategic position in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[244]</a></sup> Some of the longest European routes, including the <a href="/wiki/European_route_E40" title="European route E40">E40</a>, run through Poland. </p>
      <p>The country has a good network of <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">highways</a>, composed of <a href="/wiki/Limited-access_road" title="Limited-access road">express roads</a> and <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">motorways</a>. At the start of 2020, Poland had 4,146.5&nbsp;km (2,576.5&nbsp;mi) of highways in use.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[245]</a></sup> In addition, all local and regional roads are monitored by the National Road Rebuilding Programme, which aims to improve the quality of travel in the countryside and suburban localities.<sup id="cite_ref-National_Road_Rebuilding_Program_(Polish)_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-National_Road_Rebuilding_Program_(Polish)-254">[246]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, the nation had 18,513 kilometres (11,503&nbsp;mi) of railway track, the third longest in Europe after <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[247]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish_State_Railways" title="Polish State Railways">Polish State Railways</a> (PKP) is the dominant railway operator in the country. In December 2014, Poland began to implement <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Poland" title="High-speed rail in Poland">high–speed rail routes</a> connecting major Polish cities,<sup id="cite_ref-dec23_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dec23-256">[248]</a></sup> and started passenger service using the <a href="/wiki/New_Pendolino" title="New Pendolino">New Pendolino</a> train, operating at 200&nbsp;km/h on the <a href="/wiki/PKP_rail_line_4" class="mw-redirect" title="PKP rail line 4">Central Rail Line</a> (CMK). Polish regulations allow trains without <a href="/wiki/European_Train_Control_System" title="European Train Control System">ETCS</a> to travel at speeds up to 160&nbsp;km/h, trains with ETCS1 up to 200&nbsp;km/h, and trains with ETCS2 at over 200&nbsp;km/h. Most inter-regional connections rail routes in Poland are operated by <a href="/wiki/PKP_Intercity" title="PKP Intercity">PKP Intercity</a>, whilst regional trains are run by a number of private operators, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Polregio" title="Polregio">Polregio</a>. The largest passenger <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">train station</a> in terms of the number of travelers is <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw_G%C5%82%C3%B3wny_railway_station" title="Wrocław Główny railway station">Wrocław Główny</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_(24747512573).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg/220px-LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg/330px-LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg/440px-LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_%2824747512573%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3561" data-file-height="2384"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:LOT_Polish_Airlines_Boing_787-8_SP-LRD_NRT_(24747512573).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines" title="LOT Polish Airlines">LOT Polish Airlines</a> is Poland's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a>, originally established in 1928.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The air and maritime transport markets in Poland are largely well developed. Poland has a number of international airports, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Chopin_Airport" title="Warsaw Chopin Airport">Warsaw Chopin Airport</a>, the primary global hub for <a href="/wiki/LOT_Polish_Airlines" title="LOT Polish Airlines">LOT Polish Airlines</a>. It was established in 1928 from a merger of <a href="/wiki/Aerolloyd" class="mw-redirect" title="Aerolloyd">Aerolloyd</a> (1922) and <a href="/wiki/Aero_(Polish_airline)" title="Aero (Polish airline)">Aero</a> (1925). Other major airports with international connections include <a href="/wiki/John_Paul_II_International_Airport_Krak%C3%B3w%E2%80%93Balice" class="mw-redirect" title="John Paul II International Airport Kraków–Balice">John Paul II International Airport Kraków–Balice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copernicus_Airport_Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Copernicus Airport Wrocław">Copernicus Airport Wrocław</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa_Airport" title="Gdańsk Lech Wałęsa Airport">Gdańsk Lech Wałęsa Airport</a>. Poland has begun preparations for a construction that can handle 100 million passengers of the <a href="/wiki/New_Central_Polish_Airport" title="New Central Polish Airport">Central Communication Port</a>. </p>
      <p>Seaports exist all along Poland's Baltic coast, with most freight operations using <a href="/wiki/Port_of_%C5%9Awinouj%C5%9Bcie" title="Port of Świnoujście">Świnoujście</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Police" title="Port of Police">Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Szczecin" title="Port of Szczecin">Szczecin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ko%C5%82obrzeg" title="Port of Kołobrzeg">Kołobrzeg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gdynia" title="Port of Gdynia">Gdynia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elbl%C4%85g" title="Elbląg">Elbląg</a> as their base. Passenger ferries link Poland with <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> all year round; these services are provided from Gdańsk and Świnoujście by <a href="/wiki/Polferries" title="Polferries">Polferries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stena_Line" title="Stena Line">Stena Line</a> from Gdynia and <a href="/wiki/Unity_Line" title="Unity Line">Unity Line</a> from the Świnoujście. The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Gda%C5%84sk" title="Port of Gdańsk">Port of Gdańsk</a> is the only port in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> adapted to receive oceanic vessels. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_science_and_technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish science and technology">Polish science and technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poles#Science_and_technology" title="Poles">Poles §&nbsp;Science and technology</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marie_Curie_c1920.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Marie_Curie_c1920.png/150px-Marie_Curie_c1920.png" decoding="async" width="150" height="206" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Marie_Curie_c1920.png/225px-Marie_Curie_c1920.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Marie_Curie_c1920.png/300px-Marie_Curie_c1920.png 2x" data-file-width="453" data-file-height="622"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marie_Curie_c1920.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Physicist and chemist <a href="/wiki/Marie_Curie" title="Marie Curie">Maria Skłodowska-Curie</a> was the first person to win two <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prizes</a>. She also established Poland's <a href="/wiki/Curie_Institute_(Warsaw)" class="mw-redirect" title="Curie Institute (Warsaw)">Radium Institute</a> in 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-A_century_of_X-rays_and_radioactivity_in_medicine:_with_emphasis_on_photographic_records_of_the_early_years_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_century_of_X-rays_and_radioactivity_in_medicine:_with_emphasis_on_photographic_records_of_the_early_years-257">[249]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Over the course of history, the Polish people have made considerable contributions in the fields of science, technology and mathematics.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[250]</a></sup> Perhaps the most renowned Pole to support this theory was <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a> (<i>Mikołaj Kopernik</i>), who triggered the <a href="/wiki/Copernican_Revolution" title="Copernican Revolution">Copernican Revolution</a> by placing the <a href="/wiki/Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism">Sun rather than the Earth at the center of the universe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[251]</a></sup> He also derived a <a href="/wiki/Quantity_theory_of_money" title="Quantity theory of money">quantity theory of money</a>, which made him a pioneer of economics. Copernicus' achievements and discoveries are considered the basis of Polish culture and cultural identity.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[252]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland's tertiary education institutions; traditional <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Poland" title="List of universities in Poland">universities</a>, as well as technical, medical, and economic institutions, employ around tens of thousands of researchers and staff members. There are hundreds of research and development institutes.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[253]</a></sup> However, in the 19th and 20th centuries many Polish scientists worked abroad; one of the most important of these exiles was <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sk%C5%82odowska-Curie" class="mw-redirect" title="Maria Skłodowska-Curie">Maria Skłodowska-Curie</a>, a physicist and chemist who lived much of her life in France. In 1925 she established Poland's <a href="/wiki/Curie_Institute_(Warsaw)" class="mw-redirect" title="Curie Institute (Warsaw)">Radium Institute</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-A_century_of_X-rays_and_radioactivity_in_medicine:_with_emphasis_on_photographic_records_of_the_early_years_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_century_of_X-rays_and_radioactivity_in_medicine:_with_emphasis_on_photographic_records_of_the_early_years-257">[249]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/170px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/255px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg/340px-Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1001"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nikolaus_Kopernikus.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>, the 16th century Polish astronomer who formulated the <a href="/wiki/Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism">heliocentric</a> model of the solar system that placed the Sun rather than the Earth at its center
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the first half of the 20th century, Poland was a flourishing centre of mathematics. Outstanding Polish mathematicians formed the <a href="/wiki/Lw%C3%B3w_School_of_Mathematics" title="Lwów School of Mathematics">Lwów School of Mathematics</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Banach" title="Stefan Banach">Stefan Banach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Mazur" title="Stanisław Mazur">Stanisław Mazur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Steinhaus" title="Hugo Steinhaus">Hugo Steinhaus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Ulam" class="mw-redirect" title="Stanisław Ulam">Stanisław Ulam</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_School_of_Mathematics" class="mw-redirect" title="Warsaw School of Mathematics">Warsaw School of Mathematics</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Tarski" title="Alfred Tarski">Alfred Tarski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Kuratowski" title="Kazimierz Kuratowski">Kazimierz Kuratowski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wac%C5%82aw_Sierpi%C5%84ski" title="Wacław Sierpiński">Wacław Sierpiński</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antoni_Zygmund" title="Antoni Zygmund">Antoni Zygmund</a>). Numerous mathematicians, scientists, chemists or economists emigrated due to historic vicissitudes, among them <a href="/wiki/Benoit_Mandelbrot" title="Benoit Mandelbrot">Benoit Mandelbrot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Hurwicz" title="Leonid Hurwicz">Leonid Hurwicz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Tarski" title="Alfred Tarski">Alfred Tarski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Rotblat" title="Joseph Rotblat">Joseph Rotblat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prize</a> laureates <a href="/wiki/Roald_Hoffmann" title="Roald Hoffmann">Roald Hoffmann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georges_Charpak" title="Georges Charpak">Georges Charpak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tadeusz_Reichstein" title="Tadeusz Reichstein">Tadeusz Reichstein</a>. In the 1930s, mathematician and cryptologist <a href="/wiki/Marian_Rejewski" title="Marian Rejewski">Marian Rejewski</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Bomba_(cryptography)" title="Bomba (cryptography)">Cryptographic Bomb</a> which formed the basis of the effort that allowed the Allies to crack the <a href="/wiki/Enigma_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Enigma code">Enigma code</a>. </p>
      <p>Over 40 research and development centers and 4,500 researchers make Poland the biggest research and development hub in Central and Eastern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-262">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[255]</a></sup> Multinational companies such as: ABB, <a href="/wiki/Delphi_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="Delphi Corporation">Delphi</a>, <a href="/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline" title="GlaxoSmithKline">GlaxoSmithKline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hewlett%E2%80%93Packard" class="mw-redirect" title="Hewlett–Packard">Hewlett–Packard</a>, <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a>, <a href="/wiki/LG_Electronics" title="LG Electronics">LG Electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> all have set up research and development centres in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-264">[256]</a></sup> Companies chose Poland because of the availability of highly qualified labour force, presence of universities, support of authorities, and the largest market in East-Central Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-262">[254]</a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/KPMG" title="KPMG">KPMG</a> report from 2011, 80% of Poland's current investors are content with their choice and willing to reinvest.<sup id="cite_ref-Why_Poland?_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Why_Poland?-265">[257]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Poland" title="Demographics of Poland">Demographics of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Poland" title="List of cities and towns in Poland">List of cities and towns in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_in_Poland" title="Metropolitan areas in Poland">Metropolitan areas in Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish diaspora</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">8</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Bydgoszcz" title="Bydgoszcz">Bydgoszcz</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kuyavian-Pomeranian_Voivodeship" title="Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship">Kuyavian-Pomeranian</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">348,190 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Lublin" title="Lublin">Lublin</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Lublin_Voivodeship" title="Lublin Voivodeship">Lublin</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">339,784 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82ystok" title="Białystok">Białystok</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Podlaskie_Voivodeship" title="Podlaskie Voivodeship">Podlaskie</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">297,554 </td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <p>Poland, with approximately 38.5 million inhabitants, has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">eighth-largest population in Europe</a> and the fifth-largest in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. It has a population density of 122 inhabitants per square kilometre (328 per square mile). The <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> in 2020 was estimated at 1.44 children born to a woman, a considerable rise from previous years.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[258]</a></sup> In contrast, the total fertility rate in 1925 was 4.68.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[259]</a></sup> Furthermore, Poland's population is aging significantly and the median age in 2018 was 41.1 years.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-268">[260]</a></sup> The crude death rate in 2020 stood at 10.3 per 1,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[261]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Poland.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/240px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/360px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Population_of_Poland.svg/480px-Population_of_Poland.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="659" data-file-height="384"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Poland.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population of Poland from 1900 to 2010 in millions of inhabitants
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Around 60% of <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a> and Polish citizens reside in urban areas or major cities and 40% in more rural zones.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-268">[260]</a></sup> The most populous administrative province or state is the <a href="/wiki/Masovian_Voivodeship" title="Masovian Voivodeship">Masovian Voivodeship</a> and the most populous city is the capital, <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, at 1.8 million inhabitants with a further 3.1 million people living in its <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_metropolitan_area" title="Warsaw metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Katowice_urban_area" title="Katowice urban area">Upper Silesian metropolitan area</a> around <a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a> is the largest urban <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">conurbation</a> in Poland with up to 5.3 million residents.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[262]</a></sup> The least populous and the smallest province in size is the <a href="/wiki/Opole_Voivodeship" title="Opole Voivodeship">Opole Voivodeship</a>, with just under 1 million people living within its borders. Hence, a substantial portion of the total population is concentrated in the south of Poland, roughly between the cities of <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>. </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Polish_census_of_2011" title="Polish census of 2011">2011 Polish census</a>, 37,310,341 (96.88%) people reported <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Polish</a> identity, 435,750 (1.13%) <a href="/wiki/Silesians" title="Silesians">Silesian</a>, 17,746 (0.04%) <a href="/wiki/Kashubians" title="Kashubians">Kashubian</a> and 74,464 (0.19%) <a href="/wiki/German_minority_in_Poland" title="German minority in Poland">German</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Poles#National_minorities" title="Poles">identities</a> were reported by 163,363 people (0.41%) and 521,470 people (1.35%) did not specify any nationality.<sup id="cite_ref-GUS97_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GUS97-3">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GUS98_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GUS98-4">[3]</a></sup> Once prominent but now statistically insignificant minority groups include <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Jews in Poland">Polish Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lipka_Tatars" title="Lipka Tatars">Lipka Tatars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Poland" title="Armenians in Poland">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Poland" title="Greeks in Poland">Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lemkos" title="Lemkos">Lemkos</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Romani_people_in_Poland" title="Romani people in Poland">Romani people</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Vietnamese in Poland">Vietnamese</a>. Ethnic Poles themselves can be divided into many diverse <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Poland" title="Regions of Poland">regional</a> <a href="/wiki/Ethnography" title="Ethnography">ethnographic</a> sub-groups, most notable being the <a href="/wiki/Kashubians" title="Kashubians">Kashubians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silesians" title="Silesians">Silesians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gorals" title="Gorals">Gorals</a> (Highlanders). The statistics do not include recently arrived migrant workers.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[264]</a></sup> More than 1.7 million Ukrainian citizens worked legally in Poland in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There is a very strong <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish diaspora</a> around the world, notably in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Americans" title="Polish Americans">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles_in_Germany" title="Poles in Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Poles in the United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_Canadians" title="Polish Canadians">Canada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Centers_of_Polish_Immigration_in_the_World_–_USA_and_Germany_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Centers_of_Polish_Immigration_in_the_World_–_USA_and_Germany-274">[266]</a></sup> A strong Polish minority is still present in the territories (<i><a href="/wiki/Kresy" title="Kresy">Kresy</a></i>) of contemporary western Ukraine, Belarus, Lithuania and <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> which were occupied or administered by Poland centuries earlier. Altogether, the number of ethnic Poles living abroad is estimated to be around 20&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-Polish_Diaspora_(Polonia)_Worldwide_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Polish_Diaspora_(Polonia)_Worldwide-275">[267]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Poland" title="Languages of Poland">Languages of Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bilingual_communes_in_Poland" title="Bilingual communes in Poland">Bilingual communes in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/240px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/360px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg/480px-Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2778" data-file-height="1461"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dolina_Jadwigi_znak.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>Dolina Jadwigi</i> — a <a href="/wiki/Bilingual" class="mw-redirect" title="Bilingual">bilingual</a> Polish-<a href="/wiki/Kashubian_language" title="Kashubian language">Kashubian</a> road sign with the village name
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> is the only <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official</a> and predominant spoken language in Poland, but it is also used throughout the world by <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish minorities</a> in other countries as well as being one of the official <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">languages of the European Union</a>. The deaf communities use <a href="/wiki/Polish_Sign_Language" title="Polish Sign Language">Polish Sign Language</a> belonging to the <a href="/wiki/German_Sign_Language" title="German Sign Language">German family of Sign Languages</a>. Polish is also a <a href="/wiki/Second_language" title="Second language">second language</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, where it is taught in schools and universities.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[268]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[269]</a></sup> Contemporary Poland is a linguistically <a href="/wiki/Homogeneous" class="mw-redirect" title="Homogeneous">homogeneous</a> nation, with nearly 97% of respondents declaring Polish as their mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[271]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland's once multi-ethnic population communicated in numerous languages and <a href="/wiki/Lect" class="mw-redirect" title="Lect">lects</a> which faded or disappeared along the course of history. There are currently 15<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[272]</a></sup> minority languages in Poland, including one recognized regional language, <a href="/wiki/Kashubian_language" title="Kashubian language">Kashubian</a>, which is spoken by around 366,000 people in the northern regions of <a href="/wiki/Kashubia" title="Kashubia">Kashubia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pomerania" title="Pomerania">Pomerania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[273]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[274]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[275]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Languages having the status of national minority's language are Armenian, Belarusian, Czech, German, Yiddish, Hebrew, Lithuanian, Russian, Slovak and Ukrainian. Languages having the status of ethnic minority's language are <a href="/wiki/Karaim_language" title="Karaim language">Karaim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rusyn_language" title="Rusyn language">Lemko-Rusyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tatar_language" title="Tatar language">Tatar</a> and two <a href="/wiki/Romani_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Romani languages">Romani languages</a>; <a href="/wiki/Polska_Roma" title="Polska Roma">Polska Roma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bergitka_Roma" title="Bergitka Roma">Bergitka Roma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[276]</a></sup> Official recognition of a language provides certain rights under conditions prescribed by Polish law, including education and state financial support for promoting that language. Poland recognized <a href="/wiki/Bilingual_communes_in_Poland" title="Bilingual communes in Poland">secondary administrative languages or auxiliary languages in bilingual municipalities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[277]</a></sup> Currently, German and Kashubian hold such status in 19 municipalities (<i><a href="/wiki/Gmina" title="Gmina">gminas</a></i>), Belarusian in 9 and Lithuanian in 1. Bilingual signs, names and advertisements are commonplace in those localities. <a href="/wiki/Silesian_language" title="Silesian language">Silesian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wymysorys_language" title="Wymysorys language">Wymysorys</a> (Vilamovian) are not legally recognized or acknowledged as separate languages with a minority status. </p>
      <p>More than 50% of Polish citizens declare at least basic knowledge of the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> (38%).<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Religions in Poland (2015)</th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Roman Catholic</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:SteelBlue; width:92.9%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">92.9%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Irreligion</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:3.1%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">3.1%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">No answer</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:gold; width:2.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other faiths</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:MediumAquaMarine; width:1.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr>
           <td colspan="5" style="padding:5px; text-align:left;">Numbers from the Central Statistical Office:<sup id="cite_ref-GUS2016_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GUS2016-288">[280]</a></sup></td>
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Poland" title="Religion in Poland">Religion in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the 2015 census, 92.9% of all Polish citizens adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church in Poland">Roman Catholic Church</a>. An estimated 94.2% of the population are believers and 3.1% are <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">irreligious</a>, making Poland one of the more devout countries in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-289">[281]</a></sup> Around 61.6% of all respondents outlined that religion is of high or very high importance.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-289">[281]</a></sup> However, church attendance has decreased in recent years; only 38% of worshippers attended <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">mass</a> regularly on Sunday in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[282]</a></sup> Freedom of religion is guaranteed by the Polish Constitution,<sup id="cite_ref-Wyznania_religijne_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wyznania_religijne-291">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-www10_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www10-292">[284]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Concordat" title="Concordat">concordat</a> guarantees the teaching of religion in state schools.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[285]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
