        <a href="/wiki/File:Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg/220px-Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg/330px-Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg/440px-Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3744" data-file-height="2058"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Odnowa_w_Duchu_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tym_-_Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_2011.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_Monastery" title="Jasna Góra Monastery">Jasna Góra Monastery</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cz%C4%99stochowa" title="Częstochowa">Częstochowa</a> is a shrine to the <a href="/wiki/Black_Madonna" title="Black Madonna">Black Madonna</a>, and a major pilgrimage site for Poland's many Catholics.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>For centuries the tribes inhabiting the lands of modern-day Poland have practiced various forms of <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">paganism</a> known as <i><a href="/wiki/Slavic_Native_Faith" title="Slavic Native Faith">Rodzimowierstwo</a></i>, or "native faith".<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[286]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[288]</a></sup> In the year 966, Duke <a href="/wiki/Mieszko_I" title="Mieszko I">Mieszko I</a> converted to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, and submitted to the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[289]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[290]</a></sup> This event came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Poland" title="Christianization of Poland">Baptism of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[293]</a></sup> However, this did not put an end to pagan beliefs in the country. The persistence was demonstrated by a series of rebellions in the 1030s known as the <a href="/wiki/Pagan_reaction_in_Poland" title="Pagan reaction in Poland">pagan reaction</a>, which also showed elements of a peasant uprising against medieval <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[294]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[295]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_(12727135684).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg/170px-Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg/255px-Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg/340px-Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_%2812727135684%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="6000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Luxembourg-5151_-_Pope_John_Paul_II_(12727135684).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">John Paul II</a> was the first <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Pole</a> to become a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a> Pope. He held the papacy between 1978 and 2005.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Religious tolerance was an important part of Polish political culture, though it <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Wielu%C5%84" title="Edict of Wieluń">varied</a> at times. In 1264, the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Kalisz" title="Statute of Kalisz">Statute of Kalisz</a> granted <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> unprecedented legal rights not found anywhere in Europe. In 1573, the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Confederation" title="Warsaw Confederation">Warsaw Confederation</a> marked the formal beginning of extensive religious freedoms in Poland. It was partially influenced by the 1572 <a href="/wiki/St._Bartholomew%27s_Day_Massacre" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre">St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre</a> in <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, which prompted the nobility to prevent the monarch from carrying out reprehensible atrocities in Poland based on religious affiliation.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[296]</a></sup> The religious tolerance also spurred many theological movements such as the Calvinist <a href="/wiki/Polish_Brethren" title="Polish Brethren">Polish Brethren</a>, a number of Protestant groups and <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a> like <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_%C5%81yszczy%C5%84ski" title="Kazimierz Łyszczyński">Casimir Liszinski</a>, one of the first atheist thinkers in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[297]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anabaptist" class="mw-redirect" title="Anabaptist">Anabaptists</a> fleeing 16th-century persecution in the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and Germany settled in Poland and became known as the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_delta_Mennonites" title="Vistula delta Mennonites">Vistula delta Mennonites</a>. From 16 October 1978 until his death on 2 April 2005, Cardinal <a href="/wiki/John_Paul_II" class="mw-redirect" title="John Paul II">Karol Józef Wojtyła</a> was head of the Roman Catholic Church as <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> John Paul II.<sup id="cite_ref-About_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About-306">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Domínguez_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Domínguez-307">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Communism_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Communism-308">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Contemporary religious minorities include <a href="/wiki/Polish_Orthodox_Church" title="Polish Orthodox Church">Christian Orthodox</a> (506,800),<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> various <a href="/wiki/Protestants" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestants">Protestants</a> (150,000) — including 77,500 <a href="/wiki/Lutherans" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutherans">Lutherans</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical-Augsburg_Church_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelical-Augsburg Church in Poland">Evangelical-Augsburg Church</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> 23,000 <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostals</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pentecostal_Church_in_Poland" title="Pentecostal Church in Poland">Pentecostal Church in Poland</a>, 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Adventists" class="mw-redirect" title="Adventists">Adventists</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist Church</a> and other smaller <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical</a> denominations<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> — <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> (126,827),<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariavite_Church" title="Mariavite Church">Mariavites</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Jews in Poland">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Poland" title="Islam in Poland">Muslims</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Modern_Paganism" title="Modern Paganism">neopagans</a>, some of whom are members of the <a href="/wiki/Native_Polish_Church" title="Native Polish Church">Native Polish Church</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG/220px-Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG/330px-Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG/440px-Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Inside_old_synagogue_Krakow.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Old_Synagogue,_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Synagogue, Kraków">Old Synagogue</a> of <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a> is the oldest standing synagogue in Poland. <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism" title="Hasidic Judaism">Hasidic Judaism</a> originated in the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> during the 18th century.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Famous sites of Roman Catholic pilgrimage in Poland include the <a href="/wiki/Jasna_G%C3%B3ra_Monastery" title="Jasna Góra Monastery">Monastery of Jasna Góra</a> in the city of <a href="/wiki/Cz%C4%99stochowa" title="Częstochowa">Częstochowa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Liche%C5%84" title="Basilica of Our Lady of Licheń">Basilica of Our Lady of Licheń</a>, Kraków's <a href="/wiki/Divine_Mercy_Sanctuary,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="Divine Mercy Sanctuary, Kraków">Sanctuary of Divine Mercy</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awi%C4%99ta_Lipka_Sanctuary" title="Święta Lipka Sanctuary">Święta Lipka</a> (Holy Linden) in <a href="/wiki/Masuria" title="Masuria">Masuria</a>. Tourists also visit the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Father_John_Paul_II_Family_Home_in_Wadowice" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Father John Paul II Family Home in Wadowice">family home of John Paul II</a> in <a href="/wiki/Wadowice" title="Wadowice">Wadowice</a> outside <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>. <a href="/wiki/Christ_the_King_(%C5%9Awiebodzin)" class="mw-redirect" title="Christ the King (Świebodzin)">Christ the King</a> in <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awiebodzin" title="Świebodzin">Świebodzin</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_statues_by_height" class="mw-redirect" title="List of statues by height">tallest</a> statue of Jesus in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[301]</a></sup> Christian Orthodox pilgrims visit Mount Grabarka near <a href="/wiki/Grabarka-Klasztor" title="Grabarka-Klasztor">Grabarka-Klasztor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Hasidic Jews">Hasidic Jews</a> travel annually to the grave of a great <a href="/wiki/Elimelech_of_Lizhensk" title="Elimelech of Lizhensk">rabbi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Le%C5%BCajsk" title="Leżajsk">Leżajsk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Poland" title="Health in Poland">Health in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Medical service providers and <a href="/wiki/Hospitals" class="mw-redirect" title="Hospitals">hospitals</a> (<i>szpitale</i>) in Poland are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_of_the_Republic_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Health of the Republic of Poland">Ministry of Health</a>; it provides administrative oversight and scrutiny of general medical practice, and is obliged to maintain a high standard of <a href="/wiki/Hygiene" title="Hygiene">hygiene</a> and patient care. Poland has a <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal healthcare system</a> based on an all-inclusive <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance" title="Health insurance">insurance system</a>; state subsidised healthcare is available to all citizens covered by the general health insurance program of the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Fund" title="National Health Fund">National Health Fund</a> (NFZ). Private medical complexes exist nationwide; over 50% of the population uses both public and private sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[303]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[304]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-justlanded_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-justlanded-313">[305]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Hospitals are organised according to the regional administrative structure, resultantly most towns, <a href="/wiki/Powiat" title="Powiat">counties</a> or <a href="/wiki/Gmina" title="Gmina">municipalities</a> possess their own provincial hospital or medical <a href="/wiki/Clinic" title="Clinic">clinics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[306]</a></sup> There are six types of hospital facilities, each with a particular area of medical expertise – I Grade Hospitals for <a href="/wiki/General_surgery" title="General surgery">general surgery</a>, internal illnesses and <a href="/wiki/Obstetrics" title="Obstetrics">obstetrics</a>; II Grade Hospitals for child surgery, <a href="/wiki/Neurology" title="Neurology">neurology</a>, cardiology and <a href="/wiki/Ophthalmology" title="Ophthalmology">ophthalmology</a>; III Grade Hospitals including <a href="/wiki/Teaching_hospitals" class="mw-redirect" title="Teaching hospitals">teaching hospitals</a> for infectious diseases, <a href="/wiki/Nephrology" title="Nephrology">nephrology</a>, orthopedics, toxicology and transplantology; Oncology Hospitals for cancer treatment and <a href="/wiki/Brachytherapy" title="Brachytherapy">brachytherapy</a>; Pediatric Hospitals for child care; and Nationwide Hospitals for general and <a href="/wiki/Acute_care" title="Acute care">acute care</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[307]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/HDI" class="mw-redirect" title="HDI">Human Development Report</a> from 2020, the average life expectancy at birth is 79 years (around 75 years for an infant male and 83 years for an infant female);<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[308]</a></sup> the country has a low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a> (4 per 1,000 births).<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[309]</a></sup> In 2019, the principal cause of death was <a href="/wiki/Ischemic_heart_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Ischemic heart disease">ischemic heart disease</a>; diseases of the <a href="/wiki/Circulatory_system" title="Circulatory system">circulatory system</a> accounted for 45% of all deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[311]</a></sup> In the same year, Poland was also the 15th-largest importer of <a href="/wiki/Medications" class="mw-redirect" title="Medications">medications</a> and pharmaceutical products.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[312]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Poland" title="Education in Poland">Education in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities in Poland">Universities in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/300px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/450px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg/600px-Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="3055"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jagiellonian_University_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">Jagiellonian University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Jagiellonian_University" title="Jagiellonian University">Jagiellonian University</a> founded in 1364 by <a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great" title="Casimir III the Great">Casimir III</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a> was the first institution of higher learning established in Poland, and is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">oldest universities</a> still in continuous operation.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[313]</a></sup> Poland's <a href="/wiki/Commission_of_National_Education" title="Commission of National Education">Commission of National Education</a> (<i>Komisja Edukacji Narodowej</i>), established in 1773, was the world's first state ministry of education.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The framework for <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">secondary schooling</a> in contemporary Poland is established by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Poland)" title="Ministry of National Education (Poland)">Ministry of National Education</a>. Kindergarten attendance is optional for children aged between three and five, with one year being <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory</a> for six-year-olds.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-325">[317]</a></sup> Primary education traditionally begins at the age of seven, although children aged six can attend at the request of their parents or guardians.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_325-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-325">[317]</a></sup> Elementary school spans eight grades, at the end of which an obligatory three-part exam on Polish, mathematics and a foreign language is to be undertaken.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[318]</a></sup> Secondary schooling is dependent on student preference – either a four-year high school (<i><a href="/wiki/General_education_liceum" title="General education liceum">liceum</a></i>), a five-year technical school (<i><a href="/wiki/Technikum_(Polish_education)" title="Technikum (Polish education)">technikum</a></i>) or various <a href="/wiki/Vocational_school" title="Vocational school">vocational studies</a> (<i>szkoła branżowa</i>) can be pursued by each individual pupil.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_325-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-325">[317]</a></sup> A liceum or technikum is concluded with a maturity exit exam (<i><a href="/wiki/Matura" title="Matura">matura</a></i>), which must be passed in order to apply for a university or other institutions of higher learning.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[319]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The standards of <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher</a> <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a> are imposed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Science_and_Higher_Education_(Poland)" title="Ministry of Science and Higher Education (Poland)">Ministry of Science and Higher Education</a>. In Poland, there are over 500 university-level institutions,<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[320]</a></sup> with technical, medical, economic, agricultural, pedagogical, theological, musical, maritime and military faculties.<sup id="cite_ref-studies.info_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-studies.info-329">[321]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Warsaw" title="University of Warsaw">University of Warsaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Polytechnic" class="mw-redirect" title="Warsaw Polytechnic">Warsaw Polytechnic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Wroc%C5%82aw" title="University of Wrocław">University of Wrocław</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz_University_in_Pozna%C5%84" title="Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań">Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_University_of_Technology" title="Gdańsk University of Technology">University of Technology in Gdańsk</a> are among the most prominent.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[322]</a></sup> There are three conventional <a href="/wiki/Academic_degree" title="Academic degree">academic degrees</a> in Poland – <i><a href="/wiki/Licentiate_(degree)" title="Licentiate (degree)">licencjat</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">inżynier</a></i> (first cycle qualification), <i><a href="/wiki/Magister_(degree)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magister (degree)">magister</a></i> (second cycle qualification) and <i><a href="/wiki/PhD" class="mw-redirect" title="PhD">doktor</a></i> (third cycle qualification).<sup id="cite_ref-The_impact_of_the_1999_education_reform_in_Poland_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_impact_of_the_1999_education_reform_in_Poland-331">[323]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a>, coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>, ranked Poland's educational system higher than the OECD average; the study showed that students in Poland perform better academically than in most OECD countries.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[324]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Poland" title="Culture of Poland">Culture of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/220px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/330px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg/440px-Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="2740"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sigismund%27s_Chapel_01_AB.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Poland" title="Coat of arms of Poland">Polish White Eagle</a> is Poland's enduring <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Poland" title="National symbols of Poland">national and cultural symbol</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The culture of Poland is closely connected with its intricate 1,000-year <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">history</a> and forms an important constituent in <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">western civilization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-amazon_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-amazon-333">[325]</a></sup> The Poles take great <a href="/wiki/Patriotism" title="Patriotism">pride</a> in their national identity which is often associated with the colours white and red, and exuded by the expression <i>biało-czerwoni</i> ("whitereds").<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[326]</a></sup> National symbols, chiefly the crowned <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_eagle" title="White-tailed eagle">white-tailed eagle</a>, are often visible on clothing, insignia and emblems. The appreciation of Poland's traditions and cultural heritage is commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Polonophilia" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonophilia">Polonophilia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[327]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With origins in the customs of the tribal <a href="/wiki/Lechites" title="Lechites">Lechites</a>, over time the culture of Poland has been influenced by its connection to <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a> and trends, as well as developing its own unique traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">Sarmatism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA-336">[328]</a></sup> The people of Poland have traditionally been seen as hospitable to artists from abroad and eager to follow cultural and artistic trends popular in foreign countries, for instance, the 16th- and 17th-century tradition of <a href="/wiki/Coffin_portraits" class="mw-redirect" title="Coffin portraits">coffin portraits</a> (<i>portret trumienny</i>) was only observed in Poland and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Egypt" title="Roman Egypt">Roman Egypt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[329]</a></sup> In the 19th and 20th centuries the Polish focus on cultural advancement often took precedence over political and economic activity. These factors have contributed to the versatile nature of Polish art.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA-336">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The architectural monuments of great importance are protected by the <a href="/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_of_Poland" title="National Heritage Board of Poland">National Heritage Board of Poland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[330]</a></sup> Over 100 of the country's most significant tangible wonders were enlisted onto the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Historic_Monuments_(Poland)" title="List of Historic Monuments (Poland)">Historic Monuments Register</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[331]</a></sup> with further 16 being recognized by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> as World Heritage Sites. Poland is renowned for its brick Gothic castles, <a href="/wiki/Granary" title="Granary">granaries</a> and churches as well as diversely-styled <a href="/wiki/Tenements" class="mw-redirect" title="Tenements">tenements</a>, market squares and <a href="/wiki/Ratusz" title="Ratusz">town halls</a>. The majority of Polish cities founded on <a href="/wiki/Magdeburg_rights" title="Magdeburg rights">Magdeburg Law</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> evolved around central marketplaces, a distinguishable urban characteristic which can be observed to this day.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[332]</a></sup> Medieval and Renaissance <a href="/wiki/Cloth_hall" title="Cloth hall">cloth halls</a> were once an abundant feature of many towns.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[333]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_traditions">Holidays and traditions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Christmas_in_Poland" title="Christmas in Poland">Christmas in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos,_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz,_Gniezno,_Polonia,_2017-11-01,_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/220px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/330px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg/440px-Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos%2C_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz%2C_Gniezno%2C_Polonia%2C_2017-11-01%2C_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8140" data-file-height="5427"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Celebraci%C3%B3n_de_Todos_los_Santos,_cementerio_de_la_Santa_Cruz,_Gniezno,_Polonia,_2017-11-01,_DD_10-12_HDR.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day" title="All Saints' Day">All Saints' Day</a> on 1 November is one of the most important public holidays in Poland.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are 13 government-approved annual public holidays – <a href="/wiki/New_Year" title="New Year">New Year</a> on 1 January, <a href="/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday)" title="Epiphany (holiday)">Three Kings' Day</a> on 6 January, <a href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Easter Sunday">Easter Sunday</a> and <a href="/wiki/Easter_Monday" title="Easter Monday">Easter Monday</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">Labour Day</a> on 1 May, <a href="/wiki/3_May_Constitution_Day" title="3 May Constitution Day">Constitution Day</a> on 3 May, <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feast_of_Corpus_Christi" title="Feast of Corpus Christi">Corpus Christi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_Day_(Poland)" title="Armed Forces Day (Poland)">Armed Forces Day</a> on 15 August, <a href="/wiki/All_Saints%27_Day" title="All Saints' Day">All Saints' Day</a> on 1 November, <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Poland)" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence Day (Poland)">Independence Day</a> on 11 November and <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmastide</a> on 25 and 26 December.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[334]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Particular traditions and superstitious customs observed in Poland are not found elsewhere in Europe. Though <a href="/wiki/Christmas_Eve" title="Christmas Eve">Christmas Eve</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Wigilia" title="Wigilia">Wigilia</a></i>) is not a public holiday, it remains the most memorable day in the entire year. <a href="/wiki/Christmas_trees" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas trees">Trees</a> are decorated on 24 December, hay is placed under the tablecloth to resemble Jesus' <a href="/wiki/Manger" title="Manger">manger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_wafer" title="Christmas wafer">Christmas wafers</a> (<i>opłatek</i>) are shared between gathered guests and a <a href="/wiki/Twelve-dish_Christmas_Eve_supper" title="Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper">twelve-dish meatless supper</a> is served that same evening when the <a href="/wiki/Star_of_Bethlehem" title="Star of Bethlehem">first star</a> appears.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[335]</a></sup> An empty plate and seat are symbolically left at the table for an unexpected guest.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[336]</a></sup> On occasion, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_carols" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas carols">carolers</a> journey around smaller towns with a folk <a href="/wiki/Turo%C5%84" title="Turoń">Turoń</a> creature until the <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">Lent</a> period.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[337]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A widely-popular <a href="/wiki/P%C4%85czki" title="Pączki">doughnut</a> and sweet pastry feast occurs on <a href="/wiki/Fat_Thursday" title="Fat Thursday">Fat Thursday</a>, usually 52 days prior to <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-346">[338]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg" title="Easter egg">Eggs</a> for <a href="/wiki/Easter_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Easter Sunday">Holy Sunday</a> are painted and placed in decorated <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Awi%C4%99conka" title="Święconka">baskets</a> that are previously blessed by clergymen in churches on <a href="/wiki/Easter_Saturday" title="Easter Saturday">Easter Saturday</a>. Easter Monday is celebrated with pagan <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Amigus-dyngus" title="Śmigus-dyngus">dyngus</a></i> festivities, where the youth is engaged in water fights and some girls are gently spanked by colleagues with <a href="/wiki/Pussy_willow" title="Pussy willow">pussy willows</a> to stimulate fertility.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto_346-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-346">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Cemeteries and graves of the deceased are annually visited by family members on All Saints' Day; tombstones are cleaned as a sign of respect and candles are lit to honour the dead on an unprecedented scale.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[340]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Poland" title="Music of Poland">Music of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:300px;max-width:300px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="Fryderyk Chopin" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/150px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg" decoding="async" width="150" height="215" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/225px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg/300px-Frederic_Chopin_photo.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1014" data-file-height="1455"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="Frédéric Chopin">Fryderyk Chopin</a> was a renowned classical composer and virtuoso pianist.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw,_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Artur Rubinstein" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/142px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="215" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/213px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg/284px-Optreden_Arthur_Rubinstein_in_Concertgebouw%2C_Bestanddeelnr_913-5228.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2406" data-file-height="3648"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Rubinstein" title="Arthur Rubinstein">Artur Rubinstein</a> was one of the greatest concert pianists of the 20th century.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Artists from Poland, including famous musicians such as <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="Frédéric Chopin">Chopin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artur_Rubinstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Artur Rubinstein">Rubinstein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski" title="Ignacy Jan Paderewski">Paderewski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Penderecki" title="Krzysztof Penderecki">Penderecki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Wieniawski" title="Henryk Wieniawski">Wieniawski</a>, and traditional, regionalized <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk composers</a> create a lively and diverse music scene, which even recognizes its own music genres, such as <a href="/wiki/Sung_poetry" title="Sung poetry">sung poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Disco_polo" title="Disco polo">disco polo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[341]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The origins of Polish music can be traced to the 13th century; manuscripts have been found in <a href="/wiki/Stary_S%C4%85cz" title="Stary Sącz">Stary Sącz</a> containing <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">polyphonic</a> compositions related to the Parisian <a href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_School" class="mw-redirect" title="Notre Dame School">Notre Dame School</a>. Other early compositions, such as the melody of <i><a href="/wiki/Bogurodzica" title="Bogurodzica">Bogurodzica</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/God_Is_Born" title="God Is Born">God Is Born</a></i> (a coronation <a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonaise (dance)">polonaise tune</a> for Polish kings by an unknown composer), may also date back to this period, however, the first known notable composer, <a href="/wiki/Miko%C5%82aj_z_Radomia" title="Mikołaj z Radomia">Nicholas of Radom</a>, lived in the 15th century. <a href="/wiki/Diomedes_Cato" title="Diomedes Cato">Diomedes Cato</a>, a native-born Italian who lived in Kraków, became a renowned lutenist at the court of Sigismund III; he not only imported some of the musical styles from southern Europe but blended them with native folk music.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Music_Courts_of_the_Polish_Vasas_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Music_Courts_of_the_Polish_Vasas-350">[342]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table role="presentation" class="mbox-small-left noprint" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;float:left"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div class="center">
           <div class="floatnone">
            <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="50" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160">
           </div>
          </div></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em">
          <div style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding:2px">
           <b><a href="/wiki/Fryderyk_Chopin" class="mw-redirect" title="Fryderyk Chopin">Fryderyk Chopin</a></b>
          </div> 
          <div class="haudio"> 
           <div style="padding:4px 0">
            <a href="/wiki/File:Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor,_op._17.ogg" title="File:Frederic Chopin - mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17.ogg">Mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17</a>
           </div> 
           <div>
            <div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px">
             <audio id="mwe_player_1" controls="" preload="none" style="width:220px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="334.95616780045" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor,_op._17.ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons">
              <source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ca/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file (153 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="152769">
              <source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/c/ca/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg/Frederic_Chopin_-_mazurka_no._4_in_a_minor%2C_op._17.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-title="MP3" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="192112">
             </audio>
            </div>
           </div> 
           <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
            <a href="/wiki/Mazurka" title="Mazurka">Mazurka</a> (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">mazurek</i>), stylized <a href="/wiki/Folk_dance" title="Folk dance">folk dance</a> in <a href="/wiki/Triple_meter" class="mw-redirect" title="Triple meter">triple meter</a> (1832), commemorating the <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">November Uprising</a>
           </div>
          </div></td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>In the 17th and 18th centuries, Polish baroque composers wrote <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_music" title="Liturgical music">liturgical music</a> and secular compositions such as <a href="/wiki/Concerto" title="Concerto">concertos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sonata" title="Sonata">sonatas</a> for voices or instruments. At the end of the 18th century, Polish classical music evolved into national forms like the <a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonaise (dance)">polonaise</a>. <a href="/wiki/Wojciech_Bogus%C5%82awski" title="Wojciech Bogusławski">Wojciech Bogusławski</a> is accredited with composing the first Polish national <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a>, titled <i><a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krakowiacy_i_G%C3%B3rale" class="extiw" title="pl:Krakowiacy i Górale">Krakowiacy i Górale</a></i>, which premiered in 1794.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[343]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Traditional Polish folk music has had a major effect on the works of many Polish composers, and no more so than on Fryderyk Chopin, a widely recognised national hero of the arts. All of Chopin's <a href="/wiki/List_of_compositions_by_Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" class="mw-redirect" title="List of compositions by Frédéric Chopin">works</a> involve the piano and are technically demanding, emphasising nuance and expressive depth. As a great composer, Chopin invented the <a href="/wiki/Musical_form" title="Musical form">musical form</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Ballade_(classical_music)#Instrumental_ballades" title="Ballade (classical music)">instrumental ballade</a> and made major innovations to the <a href="/wiki/Piano_sonata" title="Piano sonata">piano sonata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazurka" title="Mazurka">mazurka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waltz" title="Waltz">waltz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nocturne" title="Nocturne">nocturne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonaise (dance)">polonaise</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tude" title="Étude">étude</a>, <a href="/wiki/Impromptu" title="Impromptu">impromptu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prelude_(music)" title="Prelude (music)">prélude</a>, he was also the composer of a number of polonaises which borrowed heavily from traditional Polish folk music. It is largely thanks to him that such pieces gained great popularity throughout Europe during the 19th century. Several Polish composers such as <a href="/wiki/Karol_Szymanowski" title="Karol Szymanowski">Szymanowski</a> drew inspiration from Chopin's folk-influenced style. Nowadays the most distinctive folk music can be heard in the towns and villages of the mountainous south, particularly in the region surrounding the winter resort town of <a href="/wiki/Zakopane" title="Zakopane">Zakopane</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[344]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table role="presentation" class="mbox-small noprint" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div class="center">
           <div class="floatnone">
            <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="50" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160">
           </div>
          </div></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em">
          <div style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding:2px">
           <b><a href="/wiki/Ballades_(Chopin)" title="Ballades (Chopin)">Ballade form</a> invented by <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Chopin" title="Frédéric Chopin">Chopin</a></b>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[345]</a></sup>
          </div> 
          <div class="haudio"> 
           <div style="padding:4px 0">
            <a href="/wiki/File:Frederic_Chopin_-_ballade_no._3_in_a_flat_major,_op._47.ogg" title="File:Frederic Chopin - ballade no. 3 in a flat major, op. 47.ogg">Ballade no. 3 in a-flat major, op. 47</a>
           </div> 
           <div>
            <div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px">
             <audio id="mwe_player_2" controls="" preload="none" style="width:220px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="557.04922902494" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Frederic_Chopin_-_ballade_no._3_in_a_flat_major,_op._47.ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons">
              <source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c8/Frederic_Chopin_-_ballade_no._3_in_a_flat_major%2C_op._47.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file (147 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="147307">
              <source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/c/c8/Frederic_Chopin_-_ballade_no._3_in_a_flat_major%2C_op._47.ogg/Frederic_Chopin_-_ballade_no._3_in_a_flat_major%2C_op._47.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-title="MP3" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="189096">
             </audio>
            </div>
           </div> 
           <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
            Inspired by poems of <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz" title="Adam Mickiewicz">Adam Mickiewicz</a>
           </div>
          </div></td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Poland today has an active music scene, with the jazz and metal genres being particularly popular among the contemporary populace. Polish jazz musicians such as <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Komeda" title="Krzysztof Komeda">Krzysztof Komeda</a> created a unique style, which was most famous in the 1960s and 1970s and continues to be popular to this day. Poland has also become a major venue for large-scale music festivals, chief among which are the <a href="/wiki/Open%27er_Festival" title="Open'er Festival">Open'er Festival</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opole_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Opole Festival">Opole Festival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sopot_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Sopot Festival">Sopot Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[346]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Art_in_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Art in Poland">Art in Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Young_Poland" title="Young Poland">Young Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Polish_artists" title="List of Polish artists">List of Polish artists</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/180px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="242" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/270px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/360px-Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="30894" data-file-height="41545"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lady_with_an_Ermine_-_Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Lady_with_an_Ermine" title="Lady with an Ermine">Lady with an Ermine</a></i> (1490) by <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>. Though not Polish in its origin, the painting symbolizes Poland's cultural heritage and is among the country's most precious treasures.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Art in Poland has always reflected European trends while maintaining its unique character. The <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" class="mw-redirect" title="Kraków Academy of Fine Arts">Kraków Academy of Fine Arts</a>, later developed by <a href="/wiki/Jan_Matejko" title="Jan Matejko">Jan Matejko</a>, produced monumental portrayals of customs and significant events in Polish history.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[347]</a></sup> Other institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Fine_Arts_in_Warsaw" title="Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw">Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw</a> were more innovative and focused on both historical and contemporary styles.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[348]</a></sup> Notable art academies include the <a href="/wiki/Cracow_School_of_Art_and_Fashion_Design" class="mw-redirect" title="Cracow School of Art and Fashion Design">Kraków School of Art and Fashion Design</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_Academy_of_Szczecin" title="Art Academy of Szczecin">Art Academy of Szczecin</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Fine_Arts_in_Pozna%C5%84" title="University of Fine Arts in Poznań">University of Fine Arts in Poznań</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eugeniusz_Geppert_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" title="Eugeniusz Geppert Academy of Fine Arts">Geppert Academy of Fine Arts in Wrocław</a>. </p>
      <p>Perhaps the most prominent and internationally admired Polish artist was <a href="/wiki/Tamara_de_Lempicka" title="Tamara de Lempicka">Tamara de Lempicka</a>, who specialized in the style of <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[349]</a></sup> Lempicka was described as "the first woman artist to become a glamour star."<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[350]</a></sup> Another notable was <a href="/wiki/Caziel" title="Caziel">Caziel</a>, born Zielenkiewicz, who represented <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abstraction" title="Abstraction">Abstraction</a> in France and England.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[351]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Prior to the 19th century only <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Schultz" title="Daniel Schultz">Daniel Schultz</a> and Italian-born <a href="/wiki/Marcello_Bacciarelli" title="Marcello Bacciarelli">Marcello Bacciarelli</a> had the privilege of being recognized abroad. The <a href="/wiki/Young_Poland" title="Young Poland">Young Poland</a> movement witnessed the birth of modern Polish art, and engaged in a great deal of formal experimentation led by <a href="/wiki/Jacek_Malczewski" title="Jacek Malczewski">Jacek Malczewski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Wyspia%C5%84ski" title="Stanisław Wyspiański">Stanisław Wyspiański</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Mehoffer" title="Józef Mehoffer">Józef Mehoffer</a>, and a group of Polish <a href="/wiki/Impressionists" class="mw-redirect" title="Impressionists">Impressionists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Witkiewicz" title="Stanisław Witkiewicz">Stanisław Witkiewicz</a> was an ardent supporter of <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">Realism</a>, its main representative being <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Marian_Che%C5%82mo%C5%84ski" class="mw-redirect" title="Józef Marian Chełmoński">Józef Chełmoński</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Artur_Grottger" title="Artur Grottger">Artur Grottger</a> specialized in <a href="/wiki/Romanticism_in_Poland" title="Romanticism in Poland">Romanticism</a>. Within historically-orientated circles, <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Siemiradzki" title="Henryk Siemiradzki">Henryk Siemiradzki</a> dominated with his monumental <a href="/wiki/Academic_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Academic Art">Academic Art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">ancient Roman</a> theme.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[353]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg/220px-2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg/330px-2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg/440px-2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1339"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2658_Muzeum_Narodowe._Foto_Barbara_Maliszewska.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Interior of the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_in_Wroc%C5%82aw" class="mw-redirect" title="National Museum in Wrocław">National Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a>, which holds one of the largest collections of contemporary art in the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the inter-war years, Polish art and documentary photography has enjoyed worldwide fame and in the 1960s the <a href="/wiki/Polish_School_of_Posters" title="Polish School of Posters">Polish School of Posters</a> was formed.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_336-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA-336">[328]</a></sup> Throughout the entire country, many national museum and art institutions hold valuable works by famous masters. Major museums in Poland include the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Warsaw" title="National Museum, Warsaw">National Museum in Warsaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Pozna%C5%84" title="National Museum, Poznań">Poznań</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Wroc%C5%82aw" title="National Museum, Wrocław">Wrocław</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="National Museum, Kraków">Kraków</a>, and <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Gda%C5%84sk" title="National Museum, Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_John_Paul_II_Collection" title="Museum of John Paul II Collection">Museum of John Paul II Collection</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_King_John_III%27s_Palace_at_Wilan%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Museum of King John III's Palace at Wilanów">Wilanów Museum</a>. Important collections are also held at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Castle,_Warsaw" title="Royal Castle, Warsaw">Royal Castle in Warsaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wawel_Castle" title="Wawel Castle">Wawel Castle</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Palace_on_the_Isle" title="Palace on the Isle">Palace on the Isle</a>. The most distinguished painting of Poland is <i><a href="/wiki/Lady_with_an_Ermine" title="Lady with an Ermine">Lady with an Ermine</a></i> by Leonardo da Vinci, held at the <a href="/wiki/Czartoryski_Museum" title="Czartoryski Museum">Czartoryski Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>. Although not Polish, the work had a strong influence on Polish culture and has been often associated with Polish identity.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[354]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Poland" title="Architecture of Poland">Architecture of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Polish cities and towns reflect a whole spectrum of European architectural styles. <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque architecture</a> is represented by <a href="/wiki/St._Andrew%27s_Church,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="St. Andrew's Church, Kraków">St. Andrew's Church, Kraków</a>, and <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Church,_Gda%C5%84sk" title="St. Mary's Church, Gdańsk">St. Mary's Church, Gdańsk</a>, is characteristic for the <a href="/wiki/Brick_Gothic" title="Brick Gothic">Brick Gothic</a> style found in Poland. Richly decorated <a href="/wiki/Attic_style" class="mw-redirect" title="Attic style">attics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arcade_(architecture)" title="Arcade (architecture)">arcade</a> <a href="/wiki/Loggia" title="Loggia">loggias</a> are the common elements of the Polish Renaissance architecture,<sup id="cite_ref-szydlowiec_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-szydlowiec-363">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RENAISSANCE_CULTURAL_BACKGROUND_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RENAISSANCE_CULTURAL_BACKGROUND-364">[356]</a></sup> as evident in the <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84_City_Hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Poznań City Hall">City Hall</a> in Poznań. For some time the late renaissance style known as <a href="/wiki/Mannerism" title="Mannerism">mannerism</a>, most notably in the <a href="/wiki/Cracow_Bishops%27_Palace_in_Kielce" class="mw-redirect" title="Cracow Bishops' Palace in Kielce">Bishop's Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kielce" title="Kielce">Kielce</a>, coexisted with the early baroque style, typified in the <a href="/wiki/Saints_Peter_and_Paul_Church,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="Saints Peter and Paul Church, Kraków">Church of Saints Peter and Paul in Kraków</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:309px;max-width:309px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:163px;max-width:163px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Saint Mary's Church in Kraków" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/161px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg" decoding="async" width="161" height="230" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/242px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg/322px-St_Mary%27s_Krakow.jpg 2x" data-file-width="847" data-file-height="1211"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_Basilica,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków">St. Mary's Basilica</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Main_Market_Square,_Krak%C3%B3w" class="mw-redirect" title="Main Market Square, Kraków">Main Market Square</a> in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a> is an example of <a href="/wiki/Brick_Gothic" title="Brick Gothic">Brick Gothic</a> architecture.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:142px;max-width:142px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ayuntamiento,_Poznan,_Polonia,_2014-09-18,_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Poznań City Hall" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/140px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg" decoding="async" width="140" height="230" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/210px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg/280px-Ayuntamiento%2C_Poznan%2C_Polonia%2C_2014-09-18%2C_DD_67-72_HDR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3088" data-file-height="5064"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Ratusz" title="Ratusz">Ratusz</a>, the 16th-century <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Renaissance</a> City Hall in <a href="/wiki/Pozna%C5%84" title="Poznań">Poznań</a> designed by Italian architects
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>History has not been kind to Poland's architectural monuments. Nonetheless, a number of ancient structures have survived: castles, churches, and stately homes, often unique in the regional or European context. Some of them have been painstakingly restored, like <a href="/wiki/Wawel_Castle" title="Wawel Castle">Wawel Castle</a>, or completely reconstructed, including the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Old_Town" title="Warsaw Old Town">Old Town</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Castle_in_Warsaw" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Castle in Warsaw">Royal Castle</a> of Warsaw and the Old Town of <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk" title="Gdańsk">Gdańsk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[358]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The architecture of Gdańsk is mostly of the Hanseatic variety, a Gothic-style common among the former trading cities along the Baltic Sea and in the northern part of Central Europe. The architectural style of <a href="/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw" title="Wrocław">Wrocław</a> is mainly representative of German architecture, since it was for centuries located within the Holy Roman Empire. The centres of <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Dolny" title="Kazimierz Dolny">Kazimierz Dolny</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sandomierz" title="Sandomierz">Sandomierz</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Vistula" title="Vistula">Vistula</a> are good examples of well-preserved medieval towns. Poland's ancient capital, <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>, ranks among the best-preserved <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">Gothic</a> and Renaissance urban complexes in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[359]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The second half of the 17th century is marked by <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">baroque</a> architecture. Side towers, such as those of <a href="/wiki/Branicki_Palace,_Bia%C5%82ystok" title="Branicki Palace, Białystok">Branicki Palace</a> in Białystok, are typical for the Polish baroque. The classical <a href="/wiki/Silesian_architecture" title="Silesian architecture">Silesian baroque</a> is represented by the University in Wrocław. The profuse decorations of the <a href="/wiki/Branicki_Palace,_Warsaw" title="Branicki Palace, Warsaw">Branicki Palace</a> in Warsaw are characteristic of the <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">rococo</a> style. The centre of Polish classicism was Warsaw under the rule of the last Polish king <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_II_Augustus" class="mw-redirect" title="Stanisław II Augustus">Stanisław II Augustus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[360]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Palace_on_the_Isle" title="Palace on the Isle">Palace on the Isle</a> is a chief example of Polish <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">neoclassical architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lublin_Castle" title="Lublin Castle">Lublin Castle</a> represents the <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">Gothic Revival</a> style in architecture,<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[361]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Izrael_Pozna%C5%84ski_Palace" title="Izrael Poznański Palace">Izrael Poznański Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA" title="Łódź">Łódź</a> is an example of <a href="/wiki/Eclecticism" title="Eclecticism">eclecticism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[362]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg/220px-Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg/330px-Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg/440px-Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1071"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kazimierz_Dolny_Market_Square.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Dolny" title="Kazimierz Dolny">Kazimierz Dolny</a>, the town exemplifies traditional provincial Polish folk architecture.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditional folk architecture in the villages and small towns scattered across the vast Polish countryside was characterized by its extensive use of wood and <a href="/wiki/Brick" title="Brick">red brick</a> as primary building materials, common for Central Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[363]</a></sup> Some of the best preserved and oldest structures include ancient stone temples in <a href="/wiki/Silesia" title="Silesia">Silesia</a> and fortified wooden <a href="/wiki/Wooden_churches_of_Southern_Lesser_Poland" title="Wooden churches of Southern Lesser Poland">churches</a> across southeastern Poland in the <a href="/wiki/Beskids" title="Beskids">Beskids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bieszczady_Mountains" title="Bieszczady Mountains">Bieszczady</a> regions of the Carpathian mountains.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[365]</a></sup> Numerous examples of secular structures such as <a href="/wiki/Dw%C3%B3r_(manor_house)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dwór (manor house)">Polish manor houses</a> (<i>dworek</i>), <a href="/wiki/Farmhouses" class="mw-redirect" title="Farmhouses">farmhouses</a> (<a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/chata" class="extiw" title="pl:chata"><i>chata</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Granary" title="Granary">granaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gristmill" title="Gristmill">mills</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barn" title="Barn">barns</a> and country inns (<a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/karczma" class="extiw" title="pl:karczma"><i>karczma</i></a>) can still be found in some Polish regions. However, traditional construction methods faded in the early-mid 20th century, when Poland's population experienced a <a href="/wiki/Urbanisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Urbanisation">demographic shift to urban dwelling</a> away from the countryside.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[366]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">Polish literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_philosophy_in_Poland" title="History of philosophy in Poland">History of philosophy in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest examples of <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">Polish literature</a> date to the 12th century,<sup id="cite_ref-LIT01_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LIT01-375">[367]</a></sup> when Poland's official language was <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, and early published works were predominantly written by foreigners. <a href="/wiki/Gallus_Anonymus" title="Gallus Anonymus">Gallus Anonymus</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Monk" title="Monk">monk</a> of disputed origin, was the first chronicler who meticulously described Poland's culture, language and territories in <i><a href="/wiki/Gesta_principum_Polonorum" title="Gesta principum Polonorum">Gesta principum Polonorum</a></i> (c. 1112–1118).<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[368]</a></sup> Latin remained the principal tool of literary expression in Poland until the 18th century, when it was replaced in favour of Polish and <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>. Historically, Polish literature concentrated extensively around the themes of true <a href="/wiki/Drama" title="Drama">drama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poem" class="mw-redirect" title="Poem">poetic</a>-expressive romanticism than on <a href="/wiki/Literary_fiction" title="Literary fiction">fiction</a>. <a href="/wiki/Patriotism" title="Patriotism">Patriotism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spirituality" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aphorism" title="Aphorism">aphorisms</a> were paramount and political or social <a href="/wiki/Allegory" title="Allegory">allegories</a> were common <a href="/wiki/Moral" title="Moral">moral</a> narratives.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[369]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[370]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:298px;max-width:298px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:160px;max-width:160px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG" class="image"><img alt="Adam Mickiewicz" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG/158px-Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG" decoding="async" width="158" height="195" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG/237px-Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG/316px-Adam_Mickiewicz.PNG 2x" data-file-width="528" data-file-height="650"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz" title="Adam Mickiewicz">Adam Mickiewicz</a> was an untiring promoter of Poland's culture and heritage. His <a href="/wiki/Epic_poetry" title="Epic poetry">national epic poem</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Pan_Tadeusz" title="Pan Tadeusz">Pan Tadeusz</a></i> is considered a masterpiece of <a href="/wiki/Polish_literature" title="Polish literature">Polish literature</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:134px;max-width:134px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Conrad.PNG" class="image"><img alt="Joseph Conrad-Korzeniowski" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Joseph_Conrad.PNG/132px-Joseph_Conrad.PNG" decoding="async" width="132" height="195" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Joseph_Conrad.PNG/198px-Joseph_Conrad.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Joseph_Conrad.PNG/264px-Joseph_Conrad.PNG 2x" data-file-width="506" data-file-height="748"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, one of the greatest novelists of all time. He was the author of popular books such as <i><a href="/wiki/Nostromo" title="Nostromo">Nostromo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Heart_of_Darkness" title="Heart of Darkness">Heart of Darkness</a></i>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The first documented phrase in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish language</a> reads "<i>Day ut ia pobrusa, a ti poziwai</i>" ("Let me grind, and you take a rest"), reflecting the use of <a href="/wiki/Quern-stone" title="Quern-stone">quern-stone</a> in early Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[371]</a></sup> The phrase was recorded by an abbot in the Latin-based <i><a href="/wiki/Liber_fundationis" class="mw-redirect" title="Liber fundationis">Liber fundationis</a></i> from 1269–1273, which outlined the history of a <a href="/wiki/Cistercian" class="mw-redirect" title="Cistercian">Cistercian</a> monastery in the <a href="/wiki/Silesia" title="Silesia">Silesian</a> village of <a href="/wiki/Henryk%C3%B3w,_Lower_Silesian_Voivodeship" title="Henryków, Lower Silesian Voivodeship">Henryków</a>. The sentence has been included in the <a href="/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Programme" title="Memory of the World Programme">UNESCO Memory of World Register</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[372]</a></sup> The oldest extant manuscript of fine <a href="/wiki/Prose" title="Prose">prose</a> in <a href="/wiki/Old_Polish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Polish language">Old Polish</a> is the <i><a href="/wiki/Holy_Cross_Sermons" title="Holy Cross Sermons">Holy Cross Sermons</a></i>, and the earliest religious text is the <a href="/wiki/Bible_of_Queen_Sophia" title="Bible of Queen Sophia">Bible of Queen Sophia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[373]</a></sup> One of the first printing houses was established by <a href="/wiki/Kasper_Straube" title="Kasper Straube">Kasper Straube</a> in the 1470s, while <a href="/wiki/Jan_Haller" class="mw-redirect" title="Jan Haller">Jan Haller</a> was considered the pioneer of commercial print in Poland. Haller's <a href="/wiki/Almanach_cracoviense_ad_annum_1474" title="Almanach cracoviense ad annum 1474">Calendarium cracoviense</a>, an astronomical wall calendar from 1474, is Poland's oldest surviving print.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[374]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The tradition of extending Polish historiography in Latin was subsequently inherited by <a href="/wiki/Vincent_Kad%C5%82ubek" class="mw-redirect" title="Vincent Kadłubek">Vincent Kadłubek</a>, Bishop of <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a> in the 13th century, and <a href="/wiki/Jan_D%C5%82ugosz" title="Jan Długosz">Jan Długosz</a> in the 15th century.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[375]</a></sup> This practice, however, was abandoned by <a href="/wiki/Jan_Kochanowski" title="Jan Kochanowski">Jan Kochanowski</a>, who became one of the first <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Poland" title="Renaissance in Poland">Polish Renaissance</a> authors to write most of his works in Polish, along with <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Rey" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicholas Rey">Nicholas Rey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[376]</a></sup> Other writers of the Polish Renaissance include <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Dantiscus" title="Johannes Dantiscus">Johannes Dantiscus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andreus_Fricius_Modrevius" class="mw-redirect" title="Andreus Fricius Modrevius">Andreus Fricius Modrevius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matthias_Sarbievius" class="mw-redirect" title="Matthias Sarbievius">Matthias Sarbievius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piotr_Skarga" title="Piotr Skarga">Piotr Skarga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Klemens_Janicki" title="Klemens Janicki">Klemens "Ianicius" Janicki</a>, who was laureled by the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>.
