The leading figure of the Polish Reformation was theologian and writer <a href="/wiki/John_Laski" class="mw-redirect" title="John Laski">John Laski</a>, who, with the permission of King <a href="/wiki/Edward_VI_of_England" title="Edward VI of England">Edward VI of England</a>, created the European Protestant Congregation of London in 1550.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[377]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg/220px-Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg/330px-Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg/440px-Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="774" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Banquet_in_Nero%27s_palace_-_Ulpiano_Checa_y_Sanz.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>Banquet in Nero's Palace</i>, an illustration from a 1910 print of <i><a href="/wiki/Quo_Vadis_(novel)" title="Quo Vadis (novel)">Quo Vadis</a></i>, a historical novel written by <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Sienkiewicz" title="Henryk Sienkiewicz">Henryk Sienkiewicz</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Baroque">Baroque</a> era, the <a href="/wiki/Jesuits" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesuits">Jesuits</a> greatly influenced Polish literature and literary techniques, often relying on God and religious matters.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[378]</a></sup> The leading baroque poet was <a href="/wiki/Jan_Andrzej_Morsztyn" title="Jan Andrzej Morsztyn">Jan Andrzej Morsztyn</a>, who incorporated <a href="/wiki/Marinism" title="Marinism">Marinism</a> into his publications. <a href="/wiki/Jan_Chryzostom_Pasek" title="Jan Chryzostom Pasek">Jan Chryzostom Pasek</a>, also a respected baroque writer, is mostly remembered for his tales and memoirs reflecting <a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">sarmatian</a> culture in the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[379]</a></sup> Subsequently, the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Enlightenment" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Enlightenment">Polish Enlightenment</a> was headed by <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Linde" title="Samuel Linde">Samuel Linde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ko%C5%82%C5%82%C4%85taj" title="Hugo Kołłątaj">Hugo Kołłątaj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Izabela_Czartoryska" title="Izabela Czartoryska">Izabela Czartoryska</a> and <a href="/wiki/Julian_Ursyn_Niemcewicz" title="Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz">Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz</a>. In 1776, <a href="/wiki/Ignacy_Krasicki" title="Ignacy Krasicki">Ignacy Krasicki</a> composed the first milestone novel entitled <i><a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Mr._Nicholas_Wisdom" title="The Adventures of Mr. Nicholas Wisdom">The Adventures of Mr. Nicholas Wisdom</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[380]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among the best known <a href="/wiki/Romanticism_in_Poland" title="Romanticism in Poland">Polish Romantics</a> are the "<a href="/wiki/Three_Bards" title="Three Bards">Three Bards</a>" – the three <a href="/wiki/National_poets" class="mw-redirect" title="National poets">national poets</a> active in the <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">age of foreign partitions</a> – <a href="/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz" title="Adam Mickiewicz">Adam Mickiewicz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juliusz_S%C5%82owacki" title="Juliusz Słowacki">Juliusz Słowacki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zygmunt_Krasi%C5%84ski" title="Zygmunt Krasiński">Zygmunt Krasiński</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[381]</a></sup> The narrative poem <i><a href="/wiki/Pan_Tadeusz" title="Pan Tadeusz">Pan Tadeusz</a></i> by Mickiewicz is Poland's <a href="/wiki/National_epic" title="National epic">national epic</a> and a compulsory reading (<i>lektura</i>) in the country's schools.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[382]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, the son of dramatist <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Korzeniowski" title="Apollo Korzeniowski">Apollo Korzeniowski</a>, came to fame with his English-language novels and stories that are informed with elements of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Poland" title="History of Poland">Polish national experience</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[384]</a></sup> Conrad's <i><a href="/wiki/Heart_of_Darkness" title="Heart of Darkness">Heart of Darkness</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Nostromo" title="Nostromo">Nostromo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lord_Jim" title="Lord Jim">Lord Jim</a></i> are believed to be one of the finest works ever written, placing him among the greatest novelists of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[386]</a></sup> Modern Polish literature is versatile, with its <a href="/wiki/Fantasy_literature" title="Fantasy literature">fantasy</a> genre having been particularly praised.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[387]</a></sup> The philosophical <a href="/wiki/Science-fiction" class="mw-redirect" title="Science-fiction">sci-fi</a> novel <i><a href="/wiki/Solaris_(novel)" title="Solaris (novel)">Solaris</a></i> is an acclaimed example of <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Lem" title="Stanisław Lem">Stanisław Lem's</a> literary legacy, whereas <i><a href="/wiki/The_Witcher" title="The Witcher">The Witcher</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/Fantasy" title="Fantasy">fantasy</a> series by <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Sapkowski" title="Andrzej Sapkowski">Andrzej Sapkowski</a>, is a much-celebrated work of contemporary Polish fiction.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 20th century, five Polish authors were awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> – <a href="/wiki/Henryk_Sienkiewicz" title="Henryk Sienkiewicz">Henryk Sienkiewicz</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Quo_Vadis_(novel)" title="Quo Vadis (novel)">Quo Vadis</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Reymont" title="Władysław Reymont">Władysław Reymont</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Peasants" title="The Peasants">The Peasants</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Bashevis_Singer" title="Isaac Bashevis Singer">Isaac Bashevis Singer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czes%C5%82aw_Mi%C5%82osz" title="Czesław Miłosz">Czesław Miłosz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wis%C5%82awa_Szymborska" title="Wisława Szymborska">Wisława Szymborska</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Facts_on_the_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Facts_on_the_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature-397">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Szymborska's_'View':_Small_Truths_Sharply_Etched_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Szymborska's_'View':_Small_Truths_Sharply_Etched-398">[390]</a></sup> In 2019, Polish author <a href="/wiki/Olga_Tokarczuk" title="Olga Tokarczuk">Olga Tokarczuk</a> was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature for the year 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[391]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Polish_cuisine" title="Polish cuisine">Polish cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/220px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/330px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg/440px-07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:07425_Jahrmarkt_in_Sanok_am_17_Juli_2011.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Selection of hearty traditional comfort food from Poland including <a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">bigos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabbage_roll" title="Cabbage roll">cabbage rolls</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurek" class="mw-redirect" title="Żurek">żurek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscypek" title="Oscypek">oscypek</a> and specialty breads
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Polish cuisine has evolved over the centuries to become highly eclectic due to Poland's history. Polish cuisine shares many similarities with other <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central European</a> cuisines, especially <a href="/wiki/German_cuisine" title="German cuisine">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austrian_cuisine" title="Austrian cuisine">Austrian</a><sup id="cite_ref-Zibart_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-400">[392]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">Jewish</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ashkenazic_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ashkenazic-401">[393]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">Italian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish</a> culinary traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Jerzy_Pasikowski_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jerzy_Pasikowski-402">[394]</a></sup> Polish-styled cooking in other cultures is often referred to as <i>cuisine à la polonaise</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[395]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Polish dishes are usually rich in meat, especially pork, chicken and beef (depending on the region), winter vegetables (sauerkraut cabbage in <i><a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">bigos</a></i>), and spices.<sup id="cite_ref-polishmeals_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polishmeals-404">[396]</a></sup> It is also characteristic in its use of various kinds of <a href="/wiki/Noodle" title="Noodle">noodles</a>, the most notable of which are <a href="/wiki/Kluski" title="Kluski">kluski</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereals</a> such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kasha" title="Kasha">kasha</a></i> (from the Polish word <a href="/wiki/Kasza" class="mw-redirect" title="Kasza">kasza</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-websters_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-websters-405">[397]</a></sup> and a variety of breads like the world-renowned <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">bagel</a>. Polish cuisine is hearty and uses a lot of cream and eggs. Festive meals such as the meatless Christmas Eve dinner (<i><a href="/wiki/Wigilia" title="Wigilia">Wigilia</a></i>) or <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a> breakfast could take days to prepare in their entirety.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[398]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bagel_Bialy.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bagel_Bialy.JPG/220px-Bagel_Bialy.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bagel_Bialy.JPG/330px-Bagel_Bialy.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bagel_Bialy.JPG/440px-Bagel_Bialy.JPG 2x" data-file-width="662" data-file-height="546"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bagel_Bialy.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">Bagels</a>, made from <a href="/wiki/Yeast" title="Yeast">yeasted</a> <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a> dough, originated in Poland.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The main course usually includes a serving of meat, such as roast, chicken, or <i><a href="/wiki/Kotlet_schabowy" title="Kotlet schabowy">kotlet schabowy</a></i> (breaded pork cutlet), vegetables, side dishes and salads, including <i>surówka</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[suˈrufka]</a></span> – shredded root vegetables with lemon and sugar (carrot, celeriac, <a href="/wiki/Searing" title="Searing">seared</a> beetroot) or sauerkraut (<a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>: <i lang="pl">kapusta kiszona</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[kaˈpusta kʲiˈʂɔna]</a></span>). The side dishes are usually potatoes, rice or cereal. Meals conclude with a dessert such as <i><a href="/wiki/Cheesecake" title="Cheesecake">sernik</a></i> (cheesecake), <i><a href="/wiki/Makowiec_(pastry)" class="mw-redirect" title="Makowiec (pastry)">makowiec</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Poppy_seed" title="Poppy seed">poppy seed</a> pastry), or <i><a href="/wiki/Napoleonka" title="Napoleonka">napoleonka</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Cream_pie" title="Cream pie">cream pie</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[399]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Polish national dishes are <i><a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">bigos</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈbiɡɔs]</a></span>; <i><a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[pʲɛˈrɔɡʲi]</a></span>; <i><a href="/wiki/Kielbasa" title="Kielbasa">kielbasa</a></i>; <i><a href="/wiki/Kotlet_schabowy" title="Kotlet schabowy">kotlet schabowy</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈkɔtlɛt sxaˈbɔvɨ]</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Breaded_cutlet" title="Breaded cutlet">breaded cutlet</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Go%C5%82%C4%85bki" title="Gołąbki">gołąbki</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ɡɔˈwɔ̃pkʲi]</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Cabbage_roll" title="Cabbage roll">cabbage rolls</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Zrazy" title="Zrazy">zrazy</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈzrazɨ]</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Roulade" title="Roulade">roulade</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Roast" class="mw-redirect" title="Roast">pieczeń</a></i> roast <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈpʲɛt͡ʂɛɲ]</a></span>; sour <a href="/wiki/Cucumber_soup" title="Cucumber soup">cucumber soup</a> (<i>zupa ogórkowa</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈzupa ɔɡurˈkɔva]</a></span>); mushroom soup, (<i>zupa grzybowa</i>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈzupa ɡʐɨˈbɔva]</a></span> quite different from the North American <a href="/wiki/Cream_of_mushroom_soup" title="Cream of mushroom soup">cream of mushroom</a>); <i>zupa pomidorowa</i> <a href="/wiki/Tomato_soup" title="Tomato soup">tomato soup</a> <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈzupa pɔmidɔˈrɔva]</a></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-Marc_Heine_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marc_Heine-408">[400]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Ros%C3%B3%C5%82" title="Rosół">rosół</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈrɔɕuw]</a></span> variety of meat broth; <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurek" class="mw-redirect" title="Żurek">żurek</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈʐurɛk]</a></span> sour rye soup; <i><a href="/wiki/Flaki" title="Flaki">flaki</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈflakʲi]</a></span> <a href="/wiki/Tripe_soup" title="Tripe soup">tripe soup</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Barszcz" class="mw-redirect" title="Barszcz">barszcz</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[barʂt͡ʂ]</a></span> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%82odnik" class="mw-redirect" title="Chłodnik">chłodnik</a></i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Polish" title="Help:IPA/Polish">[ˈxwɔdɲik]</a></span> among others.<sup id="cite_ref-Robert_Strybel_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robert_Strybel-409">[401]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Traditional alcoholic beverages include honey <a href="/wiki/Mead" title="Mead">mead</a>, widespread since the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Poland" title="Beer in Poland">beer</a>, wine and <a href="/wiki/Vodka" title="Vodka">vodka</a> (old Polish names include <i>okowita</i> and <i>gorzała</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[402]</a></sup> The world's first written mention of vodka originates from Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[403]</a></sup> The most popular alcoholic drinks at present are beer and wine which took over from vodka more popular in the years 1980–1998.<sup id="cite_ref-beverages_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beverages-412">[404]</a></sup> Tea remains common in Polish society since the 19th century, whilst coffee is drunk widely since the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[405]</a></sup> Other frequently consumed beverages include various mineral waters and juices, soft drinks popularized by the fast-food chains since the late 20th century, as well as <a href="/wiki/Buttermilk" title="Buttermilk">buttermilk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soured_milk" title="Soured milk">soured milk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kefir" title="Kefir">kefir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[406]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_design">Fashion and design</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Category:Polish_fashion" title="Category:Polish fashion">Category:Polish fashion</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/170px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/255px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg/340px-Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="1861"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Robe_%C3%A0_la_Polonaise_MET_DT11155.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Traditional Polish <i><a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(clothing)" title="Polonaise (clothing)">polonaise</a></i> dresses, 1780–85
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The particular clothing styles in Poland evolved with each century. In the 1600s high-class <a href="/wiki/Szlachta" title="Szlachta">noblemen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magnate" title="Magnate">magnates</a> developed a strong sympathy for <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">Orientalism</a>, which was also common in other parts of Europe and became known as <a href="/wiki/Sarmatism" title="Sarmatism">Sarmatism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-visegradinsight.eu_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-visegradinsight.eu-415">[407]</a></sup> The attire mediated between <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> styles<sup id="cite_ref-visegradinsight.eu_415-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-visegradinsight.eu-415">[407]</a></sup> and outfits included a <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBupan" title="Żupan">żupan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Delia" title="Delia">delia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kontusz" title="Kontusz">kontusz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pas_kontuszowy" title="Pas kontuszowy">pas</a>, decorative <a href="/wiki/Karabela" title="Karabela">karabela</a> swords and less often <a href="/wiki/Turbans" class="mw-redirect" title="Turbans">turbans</a> brought by foreign merchants. The period of Polish Sarmatism eventually faded in the wake of the 18th century. </p>
      <p>The Polish national dress as well as the fashion and etiquette of Poland also reached the royal court at <a href="/wiki/Versailles" class="mw-redirect" title="Versailles">Versailles</a> in the 1700s. French dresses inspired by Polish attire were called <i>à la polonaise</i>, meaning "Polish-styled". The most famous example is the <i><a href="/wiki/Polonaise_(clothing)" title="Polonaise (clothing)">robe à la polonaise</a></i>, a woman's garment with draped and swagged <a href="/wiki/Overskirt" title="Overskirt">overskirt</a>, worn over an underskirt or <a href="/wiki/Petticoat" title="Petticoat">petticoat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[408]</a></sup> Another notable example is the <a href="/wiki/Witzchoura" title="Witzchoura">Witzchoura</a>, a long mantle with collar and hood, which was possibly introduced by <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s Polish mistress <a href="/wiki/Maria_Walewska" class="mw-redirect" title="Maria Walewska">Maria Walewska</a>. The scope of influence also entailed furniture; rococo <a href="/wiki/Polish_bed" title="Polish bed">Polish beds</a> with <a href="/wiki/Canopy_bed" title="Canopy bed">canopies</a> became commonplace in French palaces during the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[409]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG/220px-Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG/330px-Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG/440px-Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG 2x" data-file-width="664" data-file-height="457"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gda%C5%84sk_Alfa_Centrum_sklep_Reserved.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Reserved" title="Reserved">Reserved</a> is Poland's most successful clothing retailer, operating over 1,700 stores worldwide.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Several Polish designers and stylists left a lifelong legacy of beauty inventions and <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">cosmetics</a>, most notable being <a href="/wiki/Maksymilian_Faktorowicz" class="mw-redirect" title="Maksymilian Faktorowicz">Maksymilian Faktorowicz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Helena_Rubinstein" title="Helena Rubinstein">Helena Rubinstein</a>. Faktorowicz created a line of cosmetics company in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Max_Factor" title="Max Factor">Max Factor</a> and coined the term "make-up" based on the verb phrase "to make up" one's face, now widely used as an alternative for describing cosmetics.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[410]</a></sup> Faktorowicz also raised to fame by inventing modern <a href="/wiki/Eyelash_extensions" title="Eyelash extensions">eyelash extensions</a> and by providing services to <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> artists.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[411]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[412]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2020, Poland possesses the fifth-largest cosmetic market in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[414]</a></sup> Founded in 1983, <a href="/wiki/Inglot_Cosmetics" title="Inglot Cosmetics">Inglot Cosmetics</a> is the country's largest beauty products manufacturer and retailer active in 700 locations worldwide, including retail salons in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dubai" title="Dubai">Dubai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas" title="Las Vegas">Las Vegas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[415]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[416]</a></sup> Established in 1999, the retail store <a href="/wiki/Reserved" title="Reserved">Reserved</a> is Poland's most successful clothing store chain, operating over 1,700 retail shops in 19 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[417]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[418]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[419]</a></sup> Internationally successful models from Poland include <a href="/wiki/Anja_Rubik" title="Anja Rubik">Anja Rubik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joanna_Krupa" title="Joanna Krupa">Joanna Krupa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jac_Jagaciak" title="Jac Jagaciak">Jac Jagaciak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kasia_Struss" title="Kasia Struss">Kasia Struss</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ma%C5%82gosia_Bela" title="Małgosia Bela">Małgosia Bela</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_Fr%C4%85ckowiak" title="Magdalena Frąckowiak">Magdalena Frąckowiak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[420]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Poland" title="Cinema of Poland">Cinema of Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Poland" title="Theatre of Poland">Theatre of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/220px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/330px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg/440px-Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1702"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Andrzej_Wajda_1974.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Wajda" title="Andrzej Wajda">Andrzej Wajda</a> was one of the greatest Polish film directors, and the recipient of a <a href="/wiki/Honorary_Oscar" class="mw-redirect" title="Honorary Oscar">Honorary Oscar</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a>, as well as Honorary <a href="/wiki/Golden_Lion" title="Golden Lion">Golden Lion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a> Awards.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The history of Polish cinema is as long as the history of <a href="/wiki/Cinematography" title="Cinematography">cinematography</a> itself. Over the decades, Poland has produced outstanding directors, film producers, cartoonists and actors that achieved world fame, especially in <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>. Moreover, Polish inventors played an important role in the development of world cinematography and modern-day television. Among the most famous directors and producers, who worked in Poland as well as abroad are <a href="/wiki/Roman_Pola%C5%84ski" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Polański">Roman Polański</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_Wajda" title="Andrzej Wajda">Andrzej Wajda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Goldwyn" title="Samuel Goldwyn">Samuel Goldwyn</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Warner_Brothers" class="mw-redirect" title="Warner Brothers">Warner brothers</a> (<a href="/wiki/Harry_Warner" title="Harry Warner">Harry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Warner" title="Albert Warner">Albert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sam_Warner" title="Sam Warner">Sam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jack_L._Warner" title="Jack L. Warner">Jack</a>), <a href="/wiki/Max_Fleischer" title="Max Fleischer">Max Fleischer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lee_Strasberg" title="Lee Strasberg">Lee Strasberg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnieszka_Holland" title="Agnieszka Holland">Agnieszka Holland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Kie%C5%9Blowski" title="Krzysztof Kieślowski">Krzysztof Kieślowski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[421]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 19th century, throughout partitioned Poland, numerous amateur inventors, such as <a href="/wiki/Kazimierz_Pr%C3%B3szy%C5%84ski" title="Kazimierz Prószyński">Kazimierz Prószyński</a>, were eager to construct a film projector. In 1894, Prószyński was successful in creating a <a href="/wiki/Pleograph" title="Pleograph">Pleograph</a>, one of the first cameras in the world. The invention, which took photographs and projected pictures, was built before the <a href="/wiki/Lumi%C3%A8re_brothers" class="mw-redirect" title="Lumière brothers">Lumière brothers</a> lodged their patent.<sup id="cite_ref-culture.pl_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture.pl-430">[422]</a></sup> He also patented an <a href="/wiki/Aeroscope" title="Aeroscope">Aeroscope</a>, the first successful hand-held operated film camera. In 1897, <a href="/wiki/Jan_Szczepanik" title="Jan Szczepanik">Jan Szczepanik</a>, obtained a British patent for his <a href="/wiki/Telectroscope" title="Telectroscope">Telectroscope</a>. This prototype of television could easily transmit image and sound, thus allowing a live remote view.<sup id="cite_ref-culture.pl_430-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-culture.pl-430">[422]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Polish cinema developed rapidly in the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">interwar period</a>. The most renowned star of the <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent film</a> era was Polish actress <a href="/wiki/Pola_Negri" title="Pola Negri">Pola Negri</a>. During this time, the <a href="/wiki/Yiddish_cinema" title="Yiddish cinema">Yiddish cinema</a> also evolved in Poland. Films in the <a href="/wiki/Yiddish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Yiddish language">Yiddish language</a> with Jewish themes, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dybbuk_(film)" title="The Dybbuk (film)">The Dybbuk</a></i> (1937), played an important part in pre-war Polish cinematography. In 1945 the government established '<a href="/wiki/Film_Polski" title="Film Polski">Film Polski</a>', a state-run film production and distribution organization, with director <a href="/wiki/Aleksander_Ford" title="Aleksander Ford">Aleksander Ford</a> as the head of the company. Ford's <i><a href="/wiki/Knights_of_the_Teutonic_Order_(film)" title="Knights of the Teutonic Order (film)">Knights of the Teutonic Order</a></i> (1960) was viewed by millions of people in the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and France.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[423]</a></sup> This success was followed by the historical films of <a href="/wiki/Jerzy_Hoffman" title="Jerzy Hoffman">Jerzy Hoffman</a> and Andrzej Wajda. Wajda's 1975 film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Promised_Land_(1975_film)" title="The Promised Land (1975 film)">The Promised Land</a></i> was nominated at the <a href="/wiki/48th_Academy_Awards" title="48th Academy Awards">48th Academy Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[424]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2015, <i><a href="/wiki/Ida_(film)" title="Ida (film)">Ida</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Pawe%C5%82_Pawlikowski" title="Paweł Pawlikowski">Paweł Pawlikowski</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[425]</a></sup> In 2019, Pawlikowski received an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director" title="Academy Award for Best Director">Academy Award for Best Director</a> nomination for his historical drama <i><a href="/wiki/Cold_War_(2018_film)" title="Cold War (2018 film)">Cold War</a></i>. Other well-known Polish Oscar-winning productions include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pianist_(2002_film)" title="The Pianist (2002 film)">The Pianist</a></i> (2002) by Roman Polański.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[426]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Poland" title="Television in Poland">Television in Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Poland">Media of Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Category:Video_gaming_in_Poland" title="Category:Video gaming in Poland">Category:Video gaming in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg/220px-Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg/330px-Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg/440px-Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6940" data-file-height="4605"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Siedziba_Telewizji_Polskiej_w_Warszawie_2017.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Headquarters of the publicly funded national television network <a href="/wiki/Telewizja_Polska" title="Telewizja Polska">TVP</a> in Warsaw
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poland has a number of major media outlets, chief among which are the national television channels. <a href="/wiki/Telewizja_Polska" title="Telewizja Polska">TVP</a> is Poland's <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">public broadcasting</a> corporation; about a third of its income comes from a <a href="/wiki/Television_licence" title="Television licence">broadcast receiver licence</a>, while the rest is made through revenue from <a href="/wiki/Television_advertisement" title="Television advertisement">commercials</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sponsor_(commercial)" title="Sponsor (commercial)">sponsorships</a>. State television operates two mainstream channels, TVP 1 and TVP 2, as well as regional programs for each of the country's 16 <a href="/wiki/Voivodeship" title="Voivodeship">voivodeships</a> (as <a href="/wiki/TVP3" title="TVP3">TVP 3</a>). In addition to these general channels, TVP runs a number of genre-specific programmes such as <a href="/wiki/TVP_Sport" title="TVP Sport">TVP Sport</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Historia" title="TVP Historia">TVP Historia</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Kultura" title="TVP Kultura">TVP Kultura</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Rozrywka" title="TVP Rozrywka">TVP Rozrywka</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Seriale" title="TVP Seriale">TVP Seriale</a> and <a href="/wiki/TVP_Polonia" title="TVP Polonia">TVP Polonia</a>, the latter is a state-run channel dedicated to the transmission of Polish language television for the <a href="/wiki/Polish_diaspora" title="Polish diaspora">Polish diaspora</a> abroad. Poland has several 24-hour news channels such as <a href="/wiki/Polsat_News" title="Polsat News">Polsat News</a>, <a href="/wiki/TVP_Info" title="TVP Info">TVP Info</a> and <a href="/wiki/TVN_24" class="mw-redirect" title="TVN 24">TVN 24</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[427]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_(8464360471).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg/220px-Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg/330px-Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg/440px-Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_%288464360471%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Podczas_zawod%C3%B3w_IEM_(8464360471).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Intel_Extreme_Masters" title="Intel Extreme Masters">Intel Extreme Masters</a>, an <a href="/wiki/ESports" class="mw-redirect" title="ESports">eSports</a> video game tournament in <a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In Poland, there are also daily newspapers like <i><a href="/wiki/Gazeta_Wyborcza" title="Gazeta Wyborcza">Gazeta Wyborcza</a></i> ("Electoral Gazette"), <i><a href="/wiki/Rzeczpospolita_(newspaper)" title="Rzeczpospolita (newspaper)">Rzeczpospolita</a></i> ("The Republic") and <i><a href="/wiki/Gazeta_Polska_Codziennie" title="Gazeta Polska Codziennie">Gazeta Polska Codziennie</a></i> ("Polish Daily Newspaper") which provide traditional opinion and news, and <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">tabloids</a> such as <i><a href="/wiki/Fakt" title="Fakt">Fakt</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Super_Express_(newspaper)" title="Super Express (newspaper)">Super Express</a></i>. <i>Rzeczpospolita</i>, founded in 1920 is one of the oldest newspapers still in operation in the country. Weeklies include <i><a href="/wiki/Tygodnik_Angora" title="Tygodnik Angora">Tygodnik Angora</a></i>, <i><a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/W_Sieci" class="extiw" title="pl:W Sieci">W Sieci</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Polityka" title="Polityka">Polityka</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Wprost" title="Wprost">Wprost</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Newsweek_Polska" title="Newsweek Polska">Newsweek Polska</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Go%C5%9B%C4%87_Niedzielny" title="Gość Niedzielny">Gość Niedzielny</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gazeta_Polska" title="Gazeta Polska">Gazeta Polska</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[428]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland has also emerged as a major hub for video game developers in Europe, with the country now being home to hundreds of studios. Among the most successful ones are <a href="/wiki/CD_Projekt" title="CD Projekt">CD Projekt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Techland" title="Techland">Techland</a>, <a href="/wiki/CI_Games" title="CI Games">CI Games</a> and <a href="/wiki/People_Can_Fly" title="People Can Fly">People Can Fly</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[429]</a></sup> Some of the most popular video games developed in Poland include <a href="/wiki/The_Witcher_(video_game_series)" title="The Witcher (video game series)">The Witcher</a> trilogy.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[430]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[431]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a> hosts <a href="/wiki/Intel_Extreme_Masters" title="Intel Extreme Masters">Intel Extreme Masters</a>, one of the biggest <a href="/wiki/ESports" class="mw-redirect" title="ESports">eSports</a> events in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[432]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Poland" title="Sport in Poland">Sport in Poland</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg/260px-Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg/390px-Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg/520px-Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="1800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Stadion_Narodowy_w_Warszawie_20120422.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Stadium,_Warsaw" title="National Stadium, Warsaw">National Stadium</a> in Warsaw, home of the <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">national football team</a>, and one of the host stadiums of <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">Euro 2012</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">Volleyball</a> and <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> are among the country's most popular sports, with a rich history of international competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-FIFA_World_Cup_Statistics-Poland_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIFA_World_Cup_Statistics-Poland-441">[433]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FIFA_Statistics_–_Poland_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIFA_Statistics_–_Poland-442">[434]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field_athletics" class="mw-redirect" title="Track and field athletics">Track and field</a>, basketball, <a href="/wiki/Team_handball" class="mw-redirect" title="Team handball">handball</a>, boxing, <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">MMA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway" title="Motorcycle speedway">motorcycle speedway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ski_jumping" title="Ski jumping">ski jumping</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">cross-country skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a>, tennis, fencing, swimming and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a> are other popular sports. Notable Polish sportspeople include <a href="/wiki/Zbigniew_Boniek" title="Zbigniew Boniek">Zbigniew Boniek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marcin_Gortat" title="Marcin Gortat">Marcin Gortat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justyna_Kowalczyk" class="mw-redirect" title="Justyna Kowalczyk">Justyna Kowalczyk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski" title="Robert Lewandowski">Robert Lewandowski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnieszka_Radwa%C5%84ska" title="Agnieszka Radwańska">Agnieszka Radwańska</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kamil_Stoch" title="Kamil Stoch">Kamil Stoch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irena_Szewi%C5%84ska" title="Irena Szewińska">Irena Szewińska</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anita_W%C5%82odarczyk" title="Anita Włodarczyk">Anita Włodarczyk</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[435]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Iga_Swiatek" class="mw-redirect" title="Iga Swiatek">Iga Swiatek</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[436]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The golden era of <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Poland" title="Football in Poland">football in Poland</a> occurred throughout the 1970s and went on until the early 1980s when the <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">Polish national football team</a> achieved their best results in any FIFA World Cup competitions finishing 3rd place in <a href="/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1974 FIFA World Cup">the 1974</a> and <a href="/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1982 FIFA World Cup">the 1982</a> tournaments. The team won a gold medal <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Football at the Summer Olympics">in football</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> and two silver medals, <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">in 1976</a> and <a href="/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics" title="1992 Summer Olympics">in 1992</a>. Poland, along with Ukraine, hosted the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">UEFA European Football Championship in 2012</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-warsaw-life_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warsaw-life-445">[437]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Derby_Pomorza_2009_(Bydgoszcz).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg/220px-Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg/330px-Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg/440px-Derby_Pomorza_2009_%28Bydgoszcz%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Derby_Pomorza_2009_(Bydgoszcz).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway" title="Motorcycle speedway">Motorcycle speedway</a> (<i>żużel</i>) racing is a very popular motorsport in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[438]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Poland_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Poland men's national volleyball team">Polish men's national volleyball team</a> is ranked <a href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" class="mw-redirect" title="FIVB World Rankings">as 3rd</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[439]</a></sup> Volleyball team won a gold medal in <a href="/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_1976_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Volleyball at the 1976 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament">Olympic 1976 Montreal</a> and three gold medals in <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">FIVB World Championship</a> <a href="/wiki/1974_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="1974 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">1974</a>, <a href="/wiki/2014_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="2014 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">2014</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="2018 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">2018</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[440]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[441]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mariusz_Pudzianowski" title="Mariusz Pudzianowski">Mariusz Pudzianowski</a> is a highly successful strongman competitor and has won more <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Strongest_Man" title="World's Strongest Man">World's Strongest Man</a> titles than any other competitor in the world, winning the event in 2008 for the fifth time. The first Polish <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> driver, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Kubica" title="Robert Kubica">Robert Kubica</a>, has brought greater awareness of Formula One racing to Poland, winning the <a href="/wiki/2008_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="2008 Canadian Grand Prix">2008 Canadian Grand Prix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[442]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poland has made a distinctive mark <a href="/wiki/Speedway_in_Poland" title="Speedway in Poland">in motorcycle speedway racing</a> thanks to <a href="/wiki/Tomasz_Gollob" title="Tomasz Gollob">Tomasz Gollob</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bartosz_Zmarzlik" title="Bartosz Zmarzlik">Bartosz Zmarzlik</a>, highly successful Polish riders. The top <a href="/wiki/Speedway_Ekstraliga" class="mw-redirect" title="Speedway Ekstraliga">Ekstraliga</a> division has one of <a href="/wiki/List_of_attendance_figures_at_domestic_professional_sports_leagues#Outdoor" title="List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues">the highest average attendances</a> for any sport in Poland. The <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_speedway_team" title="Poland national speedway team">national speedway team of Poland</a> is one of the major teams in international speedway.<sup id="cite_ref-Speedway_World_Cup:_Poland_win_2010_Speedway_World_Cup_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Speedway_World_Cup:_Poland_win_2010_Speedway_World_Cup-451">[443]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poles made significant achievements in mountaineering, in particular, in the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> and the winter ascending of the <a href="/wiki/Eight-thousander" title="Eight-thousander">eight-thousanders</a>. Polish mountains are one of the tourist attractions of the country. Hiking, climbing, skiing and mountain biking and attract numerous tourists every year from all over the world.<sup id="cite_ref-turism_247-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turism-247">[239]</a></sup> Water sports are the most popular summer recreation activities, with ample locations for fishing, canoeing, kayaking, sailing and windsurfing especially in the northern regions of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[444]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:left;"></div>

       <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Poles" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Poles">List of Poles</a></li>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many declared more than one ethnic or national identity. The percentages of ethnic Poles and minorities depend on how they are counted. 94.83% declared exclusively Polish identity, 96.88% declared Polish as their first identity and 97.10% as either first or second identity. Around 98% declared <a href="/wiki/Poles#Ethnography" title="Poles">some sort of Polish</a> as their first identity.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The adoption of Christianity in Poland is seen by many Poles, regardless of their religious affiliation or lack thereof, as one of the most significant events in their country's history, as it was used to unify the <a href="/wiki/Polish_tribes" title="Polish tribes">Polish tribes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[5]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The area of Poland, as given by the Central Statistical Office, is 312,679&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (120,726&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), of which 311,888&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (120,421&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) is land and 791&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (305&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) is internal water surface area.<sup id="cite_ref-CSO_2008_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSO_2008-10">[8]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In other <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Poland" title="Languages of Poland">languages of Poland</a>: <a href="/wiki/Kashubian_language" title="Kashubian language">Kashubian</a>: <i lang="csb">Repùblika Pòlskô</i></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Polish word "sanacja" is defined identically as "ł[aciński]: <i>uzdrowienie</i> (<i>L[atin]</i>: healing) in <i>Słownik wyrazów obcych</i> [<i>Dictionary of Foreign Expressions</i>], 1918 (8 years before Piłsudski's May Coup);<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup> and in <i>M. Arcta słownik wyrazów obcych</i> [<i><a href="https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Arct" class="extiw" title="pl:Michał Arct">Michał Arct</a>'s Dictionary of Foreign Expressions</i>], 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup> <i>Słownik wyrazów obcych PWN</i> [<i>PWN Dictionary of Foreign Expressions</i>], 1971,<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> defines the expression as follows: "sanacja łac. <i>sanatio</i> = uzdrowienie" (<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sanation" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:sanation">sanation</a>, from Lat[in] <i>sanatio</i> = healing) 1. w Polsce międzywojennej — obóz Józefa Piłsudskiego, który pod hasłem uzdrowienia stosunków politycznych i życia publicznego dokonał przewrotu wojskowego w maju 1926 r.... (1. in interwar Poland, the camp of <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="Józef Piłsudski">Józef Piłsudski</a>, who worked in a military coup in May 1926 under the banner of healing politics and public life...) 2. rzad[ko używany]: uzdrowienie, np. stosunków w jakiejś instytucji, w jakimś kraju. (2. rare[ly used]: healing, e.g., of an institution, of a country.)</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">British code-breaker <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Welchman" title="Gordon Welchman">Gordon Welchman</a> said: "<a href="/wiki/Ultra" title="Ultra">Ultra</a> would never have gotten off the ground if we had not learned from the Poles, in the nick of time, the details both of the German military version of the commercial Enigma machine, and of the operating procedures that were in use."<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[79]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Numerous sources state that Polish Army was the Allies' fourth biggest fighting contingent. <a href="/wiki/Steven_J._Zaloga" class="mw-redirect" title="Steven J. Zaloga">Steven J. Zaloga</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Hook&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Hook (page does not exist)">Richard Hook</a> write that "by the war's end the Polish Army was the fourth largest contingent of the Allied coalition after the armed forces of the Soviet Union, the United States and the United Kingdom".<sup id="cite_ref-ZalogaHook1982_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ZalogaHook1982-86">[80]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jerzy_Jan_Lerski" title="Jerzy Jan Lerski">Jerzy Jan Lerski</a> writes "All in all, the Polish units, although divided and controlled by different political orientation, constituted the fourth largest Allied force, after the America, British and Soviet Armies."<sup id="cite_ref-Lerski1996_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerski1996-87">[81]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/M._K._Dziewanowski" class="mw-redirect" title="M. K. Dziewanowski">M. K. Dziewanowski</a> has noted that "if Polish forces fighting in the east and west were added to the resistance fighters, Poland had the fourth largest Allied army in the war (after the USSR, the U.S. and Britain)".<sup id="cite_ref-Walters1988_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters1988-88">[82]</a></sup><br>The claim of the fourth biggest Ally needs to be reconsidered, however. Throughout the war, Poland's position varied from the 2nd biggest Ally (after the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Fall of France">fall of France</a>, when Polish army outnumbered the French) to perhaps the 5th at the end of it (after the US, Soviet Union, China and Britain). Please see the analysis in <a href="/wiki/Polish_contribution_to_World_War_II" title="Polish contribution to World War II">Polish contribution to World War II</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sources vary with regards to what was the largest resistance movement during World War II. The confusion often stems from the fact that as the war progressed, some resistance movements grew larger – and other diminished. Polish territories were mostly freed from Nazi German control in the years 1944–45, eliminating the need for their respective (anti-Nazi) partisan forces in Poland (although the <a href="/wiki/Cursed_soldiers" title="Cursed soldiers">cursed soldiers</a> continued to fight against the Soviets). Several sources note that Polish <a href="/wiki/Armia_Krajowa" class="mw-redirect" title="Armia Krajowa">Armia Krajowa</a> was the largest resistance movement in Nazi-occupied Europe. <a href="/wiki/Norman_Davies" title="Norman Davies">Norman Davies</a> wrote: "Armia Krajowa (Home Army), the AK, which could fairly claim to be the largest of European resistance";<sup id="cite_ref-google12_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google12-93">[86]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gregor_Dallas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gregor Dallas (page does not exist)">Gregor Dallas</a> wrote "Home Army (Armia Krajowa or AK) in late 1943 numbered around 400000, making it the largest resistance organization in Europe";<sup id="cite_ref-google13_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google13-94">[87]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Wyman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Wyman (page does not exist)">Mark Wyman</a> wrote "Armia Krajowa was considered the largest underground resistance unit in wartime Europe".<sup id="cite_ref-google14_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google14-95">[88]</a></sup> Certainly, Polish resistance was the largest resistance till German <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="Invasion of Yugoslavia">invasion of Yugoslavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_the_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Invasion of the Soviet Union">invasion of the Soviet Union</a> in 1941. After that point, the numbers of <a href="/wiki/Soviet_partisans" title="Soviet partisans">Soviet partisans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_partisans" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav partisans">Yugoslav partisans</a> begun growing rapidly. The numbers of <a href="/wiki/Soviet_partisans" title="Soviet partisans">Soviet partisans</a> quickly caught up and were similar to that of the Polish resistance.<sup id="cite_ref-historiographical_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-historiographical-96">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vukšić2003_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vukšić2003-97">[90]</a></sup> The numbers of Tito's <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_partisans" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav partisans">Yugoslav partisans</a> were roughly similar to those of the Polish and Soviet partisans in the first years of the war (1941–42), but grew rapidly in the latter years, outnumbering the Polish and Soviet partisans by 2:1 or more (estimates give Yugoslavian forces about 800,000 in 1945, to Polish and Soviet forces of 400,000 in 1944).<sup id="cite_ref-Vukšić2003_97-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vukšić2003-97">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ac_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ac-98">[91]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&amp;init=1&amp;language=en&amp;pcode=tessi190&amp;plugin=1">"Gini coefficient of equivalised disposable income – EU-SILC survey"</a>. <i>ec.europa.eu</i>. <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Norman Davies, <i>Europe: A History</i>, Pimlico 1997, p. 554: <i>Poland-Lithuania was another country which experienced its 'Golden Age' during the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries.          <li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Lerski1996-2-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Lerski1996-2_92-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lerski1996-2_92-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-google12-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-google12_93-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Norman_Davies" title="Norman Davies">Norman Davies</a>, <i>God's Playground: A History of Poland</i>, Columbia University Press, 2005, 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-231-12819-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-231-12819-3">0-231-12819-3</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/godsplaygroundhi00norm_0/page/344">Google Print p. 344</a></span> </li>

This was about 90% of the 3.3 million Jews living in prewar Poland. <i>Source:</i> IPN.</span> </li>

This was 11.3% of the 24.4 million ethnic Poles in prewar Poland.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Grzegorz Motyka, Od rzezi wołyńskiej do akcji "Wisła".            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEberhardt2011" class="citation book cs1">Eberhardt, Piotr (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://rcin.org.pl/Content/15652/WA51_13607_r2011-nr12_Monografie.pdf"><i>Political Migrations On Polish Territories (1939–1950)</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.          <li id="cite_note-bbc5-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-bbc5_119-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/history/worldwars/wwtwo/refugees_01.shtml">European Refugee Movements After World War Two</a>".          <li id="cite_note-indianapolis-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-indianapolis_120-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Arthur_Bliss_Lane" title="Arthur Bliss Lane">Arthur Bliss Lane</a> <i><a href="/wiki/I_saw_Poland_betrayed" class="mw-redirect" title="I saw Poland betrayed">I saw Poland betrayed</a>: An American Ambassador Reports to the American People</i>.          <li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">GUS, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140923154900/http://forsal.pl/artykuly/808705%2Cnajwieksi-partnerzy-handlowi-polski-kto-kupuje-nasze-produkty.html">Najwięksi partnerzy handlowi Polski: kto kupuje nasze produkty?</a> 9 July 2014 (Internet Archive)</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ministerstwo Gospodarki, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131208094250/http://euro-dane.com.pl/polska---kierunki-eksportu">Polska – kierunki eksportu i najchętniej kupowane produkty z naszego kraju.</a> 8 December 2013 Euro-Dane&nbsp;:: Ekonomia Unii Europejskiej (Internet Archive).          <li id="cite_note-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-238">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Worldbank.org, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTGLOBALFINREPORT/Resources/8816096-1361888425203/9062080-1364927957721/GFDR-2014_Statistical_Appendix_B.pdf">Global Financial Development Report 2014.</a> Appendix B. Key Aspects of Financial Inclusion (PDF file, direct download). Retrieved 6 November 2014. There are 32.3 providers per 100,000 adults in Poland by IMF's Financial Access Survey (FAS).            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.indexmundi.com/poland/demographics_profile.html">"Poland Demographics Profile 2019"</a>. <i>www.indexmundi.com</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.indexmundi.com&amp;rft.atitle=Poland+Demographics+Profile+2019&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.indexmundi.com%2Fpoland%2Fdemographics_profile.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APoland" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-284"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-284">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a> the following Romani languages are spoken in Poland: <a href="/wiki/Vlax_Romani_language" title="Vlax Romani language">Romani Vlax</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Central_Romani" class="mw-redirect" title="North Central Romani">Romani Carpathian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sinte_Romani" title="Sinte Romani">Romani Sinte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Baltic Romani</a>. See: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=PL"><i>Ethnologue. Languages of the World</i>, Ethnologue report for Poland</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130104034421/http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=PL">Archived</a> 4 January 2013 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-GUS2016-288"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-GUS2016_288-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGUS" class="citation web cs1">GUS. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://stat.gov.pl/en/infographics-and-widgets/infographics/infographic-religiousness-of-polish-inhabitiants,4,1.html">"Infographic – Religiousness of Polish inhabitiants"</a>. <i>stat.gov.pl</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-studies.info-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-studies.info_329-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/Individuals_and_Their_Social_Contexts/T2YLEAAAQBAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=0"><i>Individuals and Their Social Context</i></a>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060623020259/http://www.szydlowiec.pl/grafika/index/szydl1.pdf">"Szydłowiec"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>www.szydlowiec.pl</i>. p.&nbsp;9.          <li id="cite_note-RENAISSANCE_CULTURAL_BACKGROUND-364"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-RENAISSANCE_CULTURAL_BACKGROUND_364-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many designs imitated the arcaded courtyard and arched loggias of the Wawel palace. 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMichael_J._Mikoś" class="citation web cs1">Michael J. Mikoś. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.staropolska.pl/ang/renaissance/Mikos_renaissance/Cultural_r.html">"Renaissance Cultural Background"</a>. <i>www.staropolska.pl</i>. p.&nbsp;9<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-365"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-365">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMiłobędzki1994" class="citation book cs1">Miłobędzki, Adam (1994). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/Architektura_Ziem_Polski/QAMtAQAAIAAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=0&amp;bsq=pa%C5%82ac%20biskup%C3%B3w%20kielce%20manieryzm"><i>The architecture of Poland&nbsp;: a chapter of the European heritage</i></a> (in Polish). Poland: International Cultural Centre-Międzynarodowe Centrum Kultury w Krakowie. pp.&nbsp;52–56. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9788385739142" title="Special:BookSources/9788385739142"><bdi>9788385739142</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+architecture+of+Poland+%3A+a+chapter+of+the+European+heritage&amp;rft.place=Poland&amp;rft.pages=52-56&amp;rft.pub=International+Cultural+Centre-Mi%C4%99dzynarodowe+Centrum+Kultury+w+Krakowie&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft.isbn=9788385739142&amp;rft.aulast=Mi%C5%82ob%C4%99dzki&amp;rft.aufirst=Adam&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com.au%2Fbooks%2Fedition%2FArchitektura_Ziem_Polski%2FQAMtAQAAIAAJ%3Fhl%3Den%26gbpv%3D0%26bsq%3Dpa%25C5%2582ac%2520biskup%25C3%25B3w%2520kielce%2520manieryzm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APoland" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-366"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-366">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCentroni2016" class="citation book cs1">Centroni, Alessandra (3 January 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/Restauro_e_ricostruzione/vXJTCwAAQBAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=0"><i>Restauro e ricostruzione</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-381"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-381">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://polishlibraries.pl/article.php?a=14">"Polish Libraries – Wiesław Wydra: The Oldest Extant Prose Text in the Polish language.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAdam_Gopnik2007" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Adam_Gopnik" title="Adam Gopnik">Adam Gopnik</a> (5 June 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=10721773">"Szymborska's 'View': Small Truths Sharply Etched"</a>. <i>npr.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-399">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-49976107">"Tokarczuk and Handke win Nobel Literature Prizes"</a>. 10 October 2019 – via www.bbc.com.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Tokarczuk+and+Handke+win+Nobel+Literature+Prizes&amp;rft.date=2019-10-10&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fentertainment-arts-49976107&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APoland" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Zibart-400"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Zibart_400-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Eve Zibart, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/ethnicfoodlovers0000ziba/page/114"><i>The Ethnic Food Lover's Companion</i>, p. 114.</a> "Polish cuisine displays its German-Austrian history in its sausages, particularly the garlicky kielbasa (or kolbasz), and its smoked meats." (p. 108.)</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Robert_Strybel-409"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Robert_Strybel_409-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Tu się w lasy schroniły wygnane ze zbytkowych stołów, narodowe potrawy, <a href="/wiki/Barszcz" class="mw-redirect" title="Barszcz">Barszcz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">Bigos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zrazy" title="Zrazy">Zrazy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">Pirogi</a> i <a href="/wiki/Roast" class="mw-redirect" title="Roast">Pieczeń</a>" [in:] Jan N. de Bobrowicz. Maxymilian arcyksiąże Austryacki obrany Król polski. 1848. s. 74; "<a href="/wiki/Barszcz" class="mw-redirect" title="Barszcz">barszcz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ros%C3%B3%C5%82" title="Rosół">rosół</a>, sztuka mięsa, pieczenie huzarskie, <a href="/wiki/Bigos" title="Bigos">bigos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kie%C5%82basa" class="mw-redirect" title="Kiełbasa">kiełbasa</a> z kapustą, przede wszystkim zaś rozmaite kasze" Zbigniew Kuchowicz Obyczaje staropolskie XVII-XVIII wieku. 1975; "pieczeń cielęca pieczona (panierowana), pieczeń cielęca zapiekana w sosie beszamelowym, pieczeń huzarska (=pieczeń wołowa przekładana farszem), pieczeń rzymska (klops), pieczeń rzymska (klops z cielęciny) w sosie śmietanowym, pieczeń rzymska z królika " [in:] Stanisław Berger. Kuchnia polska. 1974.; Polish Holiday Cookery by Robert Strybel.

         <li id="cite_note-417"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-417">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=twGT8P_68lEC&amp;q=lit+a+polonaise+marie+leszczynska&amp;pg=PA586">"The Wrightsman Collection.
